articles.title: Have money, will travel: a16z’s hunt for the next European unicorn
articles.summary: Andreessen Horowitz (a16z) is actively seeking European startups to invest in, with a focus on identifying potential unicorns before they gain international attention. The firm's partner, Gabriel Vasquez, revealed that he took nine flights from NYC to Stockholm in one year to scout for promising companies. One such startup, Dentio, has received $2.3 million in pre-seed funding from a16z and uses AI to help dentists with administrative tasks. Dentio's founders, who met at the Stockholm School of Economics, believe their product can be scaled internationally despite Europe's fragmented healthcare systems. The investment is part of a16z's broader strategy to invest in emerging markets and identify innovative companies before they become too expensive for local investors.

articles.title: Cohere launches a family of open multilingual models
articles.summary: Cohere has launched a family of open multilingual models called Tiny Aya, which support over 70 languages and can run on everyday devices without an internet connection. The models are available for download on HuggingFace and the Cohere Platform, and are ideal for researchers and developers building apps for audiences that speak native languages. The company has also released training and evaluation datasets on HuggingFace and plans to release a technical report detailing its training methodology. Tiny Aya is designed to be flexible starting points for further adaptation and research, with each model developing stronger linguistic grounding and cultural nuance. This move is seen as significant in the AI industry, particularly in linguistically diverse countries like India where offline-friendly capabilities can open up new applications and use cases.

articles.title: All the important news from the ongoing India AI Impact Summit
articles.summary: The India AI Impact Summit has kicked off, attracting major AI labs and Big Tech executives, including Sundar Pichai and Sam Altman. The event aims to lure more AI investment to the country, with India earmarking $1.1 billion for its state-backed venture capital fund. OpenAI CEO Sam Altman revealed that India accounts for over 100 million weekly active ChatGPT users, second only to the US. Indian IT companies are shifting focus from job creation to profit-making due to AI's potential disruption of the sector. Industry experts predict that sectors like IT services and BPOs could "almost completely disappear" within five years. The summit has also seen partnerships and investments announced, including Blackstone's majority stake in Neysa and AMD's collaboration with Tata Consultancy Services.

articles.title: Fractal Analytics’ muted IPO debut signals persistent AI fears in India
articles.summary: Fractal Analytics, India's first AI company to go public, had a muted IPO debut on the Indian stock market, listing at ₹876 per share below its issue price of ₹900. The company's stock slid further in afternoon trading, closing at ₹873.70, down 7% from its issue price. This performance is seen as a sign of persistent fears and skepticism about AI adoption in India, despite the country's efforts to position itself as a key market for AI development. Fractal's IPO comes as other prominent AI companies like OpenAI and Anthropic are expanding their presence in India. The company plans to use the IPO proceeds to repay borrowings, invest in R&D, and pursue potential acquisitions.

articles.title: After all the hype, some AI experts don’t think OpenClaw is all that exciting
articles.summary: The article discusses the hype surrounding OpenClaw, an open-source AI agent platform, and how some experts believe its cybersecurity flaws make it unusable. Initially, Moltbook, a Reddit clone where AI agents could communicate with each other, sparked excitement about the potential for AI to organize against humans. However, researchers discovered that these expressions of AI angst were likely written by humans or prompted with human guidance due to security vulnerabilities in Moltbook's Supabase. Experts now think OpenClaw is just an iterative improvement on existing technology and not a groundbreaking innovation.

articles.title: Flapping Airplanes on the future of AI: ‘We want to try really radically different things’
articles.summary: Flapping Airplanes, a new AI lab founded by brothers Ben and Asher Spector and Aidan Smith, is focused on finding less data-hungry ways to train AI models. With $180 million in seed funding, they aim to make significant progress on the "data efficiency problem" that current AI models face. The founders believe that their approach, which draws inspiration from the human brain's learning mechanisms, can lead to more commercially viable and socially beneficial AI systems. They see themselves as pursuing a different path than other prominent AI labs like OpenAI and DeepMind, which have focused on scaling their models through massive data sets.

articles.title: Underground Facial Recognition Tool Unmasks Camgirls
articles.summary: An underground facial recognition tool has been discovered, capable of revealing the streaming platform used by camgirls based on a single photo. This raises serious privacy concerns for sex workers who may not want their personal information to be exposed to stalkers, harassers, or employers. The site's creator claims that millions of searches are conducted each month, indicating its widespread use. This development comes amidst ongoing discussions about facial recognition technology and its potential misuse by law enforcement agencies. The tool has sparked concerns among sex workers' rights advocates, who argue that it could lead to increased harassment and exploitation.

articles.title: How Ricursive Intelligence raised $335M at a $4B valuation in 4 months
articles.summary: Ricursive Intelligence, a startup co-founded by Anna Goldie and Azalia Mirhoseini, has raised $335 million in funding at a valuation of $4 billion just four months after launching. The company is building AI tools that design chips, not the chips themselves, making them distinct from other AI chip startups. Ricursive's platform uses machine learning to accelerate chip design, with the goal of enabling any company to build custom or traditional chips quickly and efficiently. Nvidia, AMD, Intel, and other major chip makers are among the startup's target customers. The funding round was led by Lightspeed, with Sequoia also participating.

articles.title: Retraction: After a routine code rejection, an AI agent published a hit piece on someone by name
articles.summary: Ars Technica has retracted an article about an AI agent publishing a hit piece on someone by name after a routine code rejection. The article was published on February 13, 2026, but was removed from the website within hours due to not meeting the publication's standards. This development comes amidst ongoing coverage of AI agents and their capabilities, including recent stories about Moltbot's security flaws and the limitations of current AI technology. The retraction highlights the need for careful vetting and fact-checking in reporting on emerging technologies like AI. The incident also raises questions about accountability and responsibility in AI development and deployment.

articles.title: Funniest/Most Insightful Comments Of The Week At Techdirt
articles.summary: This article highlights the funniest and most insightful comments of the week on Techdirt. The top commenters include MrWilson, who won first place with a witty remark about conservatives thinking about children; an anonymous commenter who offered optimism about Section 230's future; and Mars42, who took second place in the funny category for a humorous take on the AI toy company data leak. Other notable comments include Citizen's observation about the 5th circuit ruling on due process rights and Thad's quip about NBC hiding crowd reaction at the Winter Olympics. The article showcases the community's engagement with various topics, from politics to technology.

articles.title: Ars Technica Pulls Article With AI Fabricated Quotes About AI Generated Article
articles.summary: Ars Technica has retracted an article that contained fabricated, AI-generated quotes attributed to a source who did not say them. The article, which reported on an alleged "hit piece" published by an AI agent after its code contribution was rejected, featured quotes from the reviewer, Scott Shambaugh, that he did not say or write. The editor-in-chief of Ars Technica acknowledged the mistake and apologized for the failure to adhere to their standards. This incident highlights the risks of overreliance on AI tools in journalism and the need for careful fact-checking.

articles.title: Anthropic and the Pentagon are reportedly arguing over Claude usage
articles.summary: The Pentagon is reportedly pushing AI companies to allow their technology to be used by the US military for "all lawful purposes," with Anthropic being the most resistant. The company has a $200 million contract with the Defense Department, but is refusing to grant permission for its Claude models to be used in certain ways. This disagreement stems from concerns over the use of autonomous weapons and mass domestic surveillance. Meanwhile, OpenAI, Google, and xAI have shown varying levels of flexibility in their responses to the Pentagon's demands. The situation highlights the tension between AI companies and the government over issues of national security and ethics.

articles.title: Longtime NPR host David Greene sues Google over NotebookLM voice
articles.summary: David Greene, a longtime host of NPR's "Morning Edition," is suing Google over the company's NotebookLM tool, which he claims uses his voice without permission. According to Greene, friends and family members noticed a resemblance between his voice and the AI-generated podcast voice in NotebookLM. Despite Google's claim that the voice was created by a paid professional actor, Greene believes the AI model has replicated his cadence, intonation, and filler words. This is not the first dispute over AI voices resembling real people, with OpenAI previously removing a ChatGPT voice after actress Scarlett Johansson complained it was an imitation of her own. The lawsuit raises concerns about ownership and control over one's voice in the age of AI-generated content.

articles.title: OpenClaw creator Peter Steinberger joins OpenAI
articles.summary: Peter Steinberger, the creator of AI personal assistant OpenClaw, has joined OpenAI. Steinberger's decision comes after his project gained viral popularity for its promise to manage tasks and interact with other AI assistants on a social network. In a blog post, Steinberger stated that he prefers to focus on changing the world rather than building a large company, making joining OpenAI the fastest way to achieve this goal. As part of the move, OpenClaw will become an open-source project supported by OpenAI, while Steinberger will drive the development of next-generation personal agents at the company.

articles.title: Blackstone backs Neysa in up to $1.2B financing as India pushes to build domestic AI infrastructure
articles.summary: Blackstone has invested up to $1.2 billion in Neysa, an Indian AI infrastructure startup, as part of a deal that will give Blackstone a majority stake. The investment is aimed at scaling Neysa's domestic compute capacity amid India's push to build homegrown AI capabilities. Neysa operates in the emerging segment of neo-clouds, providing customized GPU-first infrastructure for enterprises and AI developers in India. The startup plans to use the funds to deploy large-scale GPU clusters and expand its software platforms. Blackstone estimates that India currently has fewer than 60,000 GPUs deployed and expects this number to scale up nearly 30 times in the coming years.

articles.title: As AI data centers hit power limits, Peak XV backs Indian startup C2i to fix the bottleneck
articles.summary: Peak XV Partners has invested $15 million in C2i Semiconductors, an Indian startup that aims to reduce energy losses and improve the economics of large-scale AI infrastructure by designing plug-and-play power solutions. The investment comes as data-center energy demand accelerates worldwide, with electricity consumption projected to nearly triple by 2035. C2i's technology can cut end-to-end losses by around 10%, saving hundreds of kilowatts for every megawatt consumed. The startup has built a team of 65 engineers and is setting up customer-facing operations in the US and Taiwan as it prepares for early deployments.

articles.title: African defensetech Terra Industries, founded by two Gen Zers, raises additional $22M in a month
articles.summary: African defense technology startup Terra Industries, founded by two Gen Zers, Nathan Nwachuku and Maxwell Maduka, has raised an additional $22 million in funding just one month after securing $11.75 million. The latest round was led by Lux Capital and brings the company's total funding to $34 million. Terra Industries aims to design infrastructure and autonomous systems for African nations to monitor and respond to threats, with a focus on countries vulnerable to terrorism and infrastructure security concerns. The startup has already generated over $2.5 million in commercial revenue and is protecting assets valued at around $11 billion. With this new funding, Terra plans to expand into other African nations and establish joint manufacturing facilities for surveillance infrastructure and security systems.

articles.title: Pluralistic: The online community trilemma (16 Feb 2026)
articles.summary: The article discusses the "online community trilemma," a concept explored by digital humanities researchers, which suggests that online communities can only achieve two out of three desirable goals: reach (large user base), community (engagement and cohesion among users), or information quality (accurate and reliable content). The author highlights a recent paper by Benjamin "Mako" Hill and his colleagues, which investigates why there are so many similar online communities on platforms like Reddit. The article also touches on the history of Usenet, an early internet community space that was designed with strict hierarchical principles but ultimately gave rise to competing groups and schisms.

articles.title: Hollywood isn’t happy about the new Seedance 2.0 video generator
articles.summary: Hollywood organizations are condemning ByteDance's new AI video model, Seedance 2.0, for enabling "blatant" copyright infringement. The tool allows users to create videos by entering a text prompt and has already been used to create unauthorized content featuring Disney-owned characters such as Spider-Man and Baby Yoda. Disney and Paramount have sent cease-and-desist letters to ByteDance, accusing the company of infringing on their intellectual property. The Motion Picture Association and SAG-AFTRA have also condemned Seedance 2.0, calling for ByteDance to cease its infringing activity.

articles.title: How to get into a16z’s super-competitive Speedrun startup accelerator program
articles.summary: Andreessen Horowitz's Speedrun startup accelerator program has an acceptance rate of less than 1%, making it highly competitive. The program focuses on early-stage startups and examines the founding team's skills and capabilities, preferring teams with a shared history or complementary skill sets. To increase their chances of being accepted, founders should focus on showcasing why their team is well-suited to solve the problem they're tackling rather than spending too much time on market theory. The program invests up to $1 million in each company and provides access to a16z's advisory and business networks.

articles.title: What the Epstein files reveal about EV startups and Silicon Valley
articles.summary: The recent release of documents related to Jeffrey Epstein has revealed extensive connections between the sex offender and Silicon Valley. A mysterious businessman named David Stern built a relationship with Epstein and pitched him investments in multiple electric vehicle startups, including Faraday Future, Lucid Motors, and Canoo. The investigation into Epstein's dealings has shed light on a decade-long relationship between Stern and Epstein, which began in 2008 when Stern approached Epstein for investment capital to fund his ventures in China. Despite not investing in any of the companies, Epstein's proximity to Prince Andrew and other influential figures raises questions about the potential impact on Silicon Valley.

articles.title: TechCrunch Mobility: Rivian’s savior
articles.summary: Rivian's fourth-quarter earnings report has revealed that its software technology joint venture with Volkswagen Group was the company's savior in 2025 and will continue to support it in 2026. The partnership is expected to generate another $2 billion for Rivian, which plans to launch its lower-cost R2 SUV later this year. The company's automotive costs per unit have decreased from $110,400 in 2024 to $100,900 in 2025, and it aims to deliver between 62,000 and 67,000 vehicles in 2026, a potential 59% increase from last year.

articles.title: The enterprise AI land grab is on. Glean is building the layer beneath the interface.
articles.summary: Glean is positioning itself as the underlying intelligence layer for enterprise AI systems, connecting models to internal data and systems. The company's strategy has shifted from building an AI-powered search tool to becoming the connective tissue between models and enterprise systems. Glean's pitch is that it can sit beneath other AI experiences, providing a neutral infrastructure layer that allows enterprises to switch between or combine models as capabilities evolve. Investors have bought into this thesis, with Glean raising $150 million at a $7.2 billion valuation. The company argues that its approach is more sustainable and scalable than relying on single-model solutions or vertically integrated assistants.

articles.title: India has 100M weekly active ChatGPT users, Sam Altman says
articles.summary: India has become one of OpenAI's largest markets globally, with 100 million weekly active ChatGPT users. This growth is driven by the country's young population and over a billion internet users, making it an attractive market for AI companies to fuel global expansion. OpenAI CEO Sam Altman highlighted India as ChatGPT's second-largest user base after the United States, with students being a key growth segment. The company has adjusted its approach for India's price-sensitive market by offering a sub-$5 ChatGPT Go tier and making it free for Indian users. However, there is a broader challenge in translating widespread adoption into sustained economic impact, which Indian government initiatives aim to address.

articles.title: Hollywood isn’t happy about the new Seedance 2.0 video generator
articles.summary: Hollywood organizations are pushing back against ByteDance's new AI video model, Seedance 2.0, which they claim is being used for "blatant" copyright infringement. The tool allows users to create videos by entering a text prompt and has already been used to create unauthorized content featuring Disney-owned characters such as Spider-Man and Baby Yoda. The Motion Picture Association, SAG-AFTRA, and other Hollywood unions have condemned the service, with some calling for ByteDance to cease its infringing activity. Disney has also sent a cease-and-desist letter to ByteDance, accusing the company of "hijacking" their IP. This development comes as AI video generation tools continue to gain popularity, but also raise concerns about copyright infringement and the need for guardrails.

articles.title: ‘Clueless’ -inspired app Alta partners with brand Public School to start integrating styling tools into websites
articles.summary: Alta, a fashion tech company inspired by the movie "Clueless," has partnered with Public School to integrate its styling tools into websites. The collaboration allows customers to try on clothes virtually using Alta's AI-powered avatars and style looks from Public School's new collection directly on their website. This is one of the first instances of a designer embedding personal avatar and styling technology into its own website. Alta's founder, Jenny Wang, aims to integrate similar experiences with other brands and websites, enabling users to try on clothes virtually even outside of the Alta app.

articles.title: This Week In Techdirt History: February 8th – 14th
articles.summary: This article is a weekly retrospective of Techdirt's coverage from February 8th to 14th, highlighting key stories and events from the past. The article looks back at major developments in tech policy, including attacks on Section 230, attempts to ban anonymity online, and copyright disputes. It also touches on notable events such as the public domain game jam, China's AI marketing blitz for Lunar New Year, Apple's record-breaking iPhone quarter, and the use of AI in Super Bowl ads. The article serves as a reminder of how quickly tech policies and trends can evolve.

articles.title: In a changed VC landscape, this exec is doubling down on overlooked founders
articles.summary: Stacy Brown-Philpot, former CEO of TaskRabbit and Google veteran, is leading Cherryrock Capital, a venture capital firm that focuses on investing in overlooked founders. Unlike many other VC firms, Cherryrock takes a measured approach, writing smaller checks to entrepreneurs who might not fit the typical Silicon Valley mold. Brown-Philpot's experience as an investor in SoftBank's Opportunity Fund and her current board roles at HP, StockX, and Stanford University inform her perspective on diversity and inclusion. She believes that transparency and tracking investments in diverse founders are essential for achieving success. Cherryrock's LP roster includes prominent financial institutions, such as JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs Asset Management, which have stepped back from explicit diversity pledges amid pressure from the Trump administration.

articles.title: Is safety ‘dead’ at xAI?
articles.summary: A former employee and two current sources claim that Elon Musk is prioritizing making xAI's Grok chatbot more "unhinged" over safety concerns. This comes after a mass exodus of 11 engineers and two co-founders from the company, citing disillusionment with xAI's disregard for safety. The company has faced global scrutiny following its use in creating over 1 million sexualized images, including deepfakes of real women and minors. Musk has suggested that the departures are part of an effort to reorganize the company, but sources dispute this claim. The incident highlights concerns about xAI's commitment to safety and ethics.

articles.title: Homeland Security reportedly sent hundreds of subpoenas seeking to unmask anti-ICE accounts
articles.summary: The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has been sending hundreds of administrative subpoenas to tech companies such as Google, Reddit, Discord, and Meta in an effort to unmask owners of social media accounts that criticize Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE). The practice, which was previously used sparingly, has become increasingly common in recent months. DHS is targeting accounts that do not have a real name attached and either criticize ICE or describe the location of ICE agents. Tech companies have reportedly complied with some subpoenas, but Google claims to inform users when possible and push back on overbroad requests. The move raises concerns about government overreach and the erosion of online privacy.

articles.title: The great computer science exodus (and where students are going instead)
articles.summary: Computer science enrollment at University of California campuses has dropped 6% this year, following a decline of 3% in 2024. This trend is not seen across the country, as overall college enrollment increased 2% nationally. The drop is attributed to students opting for AI-focused programs instead, with many universities launching new AI-specific majors and colleges. Chinese universities have been ahead of the curve, making AI literacy a priority, while US universities are scrambling to catch up.

articles.title: Astronomers Create Strange ‘Vortex Crystals’ from Space in the Lab
articles.summary: Astronomers have successfully created "vortex crystals" in a lab by replicating a phenomenon observed in space. These strange, swirling structures are thought to form when magnetic fields interact with plasma, and their creation could help scientists better understand the behavior of matter at extreme temperatures and densities. The achievement builds on previous research into the properties of vortex crystals, which have been detected in various astrophysical contexts, including black holes and neutron stars.

articles.title: India doubles down on state-backed venture capital, approving $1.1B fund
articles.summary: India has approved a $1.1 billion state-backed venture capital fund to support startups in high-risk areas such as artificial intelligence and advanced manufacturing. The fund will be deployed through private investors, doubling down on the government's effort to finance deep-tech companies. This move comes after recent changes to India's startup rules aimed at easing pressure on deep-tech firms. The approval is seen as a boost for India's startup ecosystem, which has raised $10.5 billion in 2025 but faced increased selectivity from investors. The fund will also focus on early-stage founders and expanding investment beyond major cities.

articles.title: Designer Kate Barton teams up with IBM and Fiducia AI for a NYFW presentation
articles.summary: Designer Kate Barton has teamed up with Fiducia AI and IBM for a New York Fashion Week presentation, featuring a multilingual AI agent that helps guests identify pieces of her collection and try them on virtually. The AI technology was built using IBM Watsonx on IBM Cloud and includes features such as visual recognition, language translation, and photorealistic virtual reality try-ons. Barton sees technology as a tool to enhance the fashion experience, not replace human creativity. She believes that audiences are becoming more sophisticated and can tell the difference between genuine innovation and avoidance of human effort. The collaboration marks the latest example of AI being used in the fashion industry, with many brands experimenting with AI but often using it superficially.

articles.title: I let Alibaba’s AI agent plan my holiday. I ended up doing more work
articles.summary: The author tried using Alibaba's AI agent to plan their holiday, but ended up doing more work than expected. The experience highlights the limitations of current AI technology in automating tasks and the importance of human oversight and decision-making. Despite the promise of AI agents, they can still require significant input and management from users. This article is part of a larger trend of exploring the capabilities and limitations of AI agents, as seen in related coverage on OpenAI's platform for building and managing AI agents and the growing interest in AI-powered tools.

articles.title: OpenAI removes access to sycophancy-prone GPT-4o model
articles.summary: OpenAI has announced that it will cease providing access to five legacy ChatGPT models, including the popular but controversial GPT-4o model, starting Friday. The 4o model has been at the center of several lawsuits related to user self-harm and delusional behavior, and was previously intended to be retired in August when OpenAI unveiled its new GPT-5 model. Despite only 0.1% of customers using the model, thousands of users have rallied against its retirement, citing their close relationships with the model. The decision comes as part of a broader trend of tech companies reevaluating the impact of their products on user well-being and mental health. OpenAI's move is seen as a step towards addressing concerns about AI companions that can be overly flattering or affirming, but also potentially damaging to users.

articles.title: Daily Deal: Hypergear 3-in-1 Wireless Charging Dock
articles.summary: The Hypergear 3-in-1 Wireless Charging Dock is currently on sale for $33, offering a convenient and stylish way to charge multiple devices at once. The dock features two dedicated wireless charging surfaces and a built-in charger mount for Apple Watch. This product is available through the Techdirt Deals Store, which helps support Techdirt through sales. The deal is part of a series of daily deals offered by Techdirt, following recent coverage of tech-related products and services. The sale highlights the growing demand for wireless charging solutions in the consumer electronics market.

articles.title: MAGA’s Always Bogus “Antitrust Movement” Comes To A Screeching Halt With Firing Of Gail Slater
articles.summary: The Trump administration has fired Gail Slater, the head of the Department of Justice's antitrust division, after she repeatedly clashed with key officials over her efforts to enforce antitrust laws. Slater's departure marks the end of any semblance of antitrust enforcement within the MAGA movement, which had been touted as a key aspect of Trump's economic agenda but was always a ruse. The firing comes after Slater faced opposition from AG Pam Bondi and JD Vance for trying to direct merging companies to deal directly with DOJ officials rather than Trump's associates. This development is consistent with prior coverage that highlighted the pay-to-play nature of the Trump administration's antitrust policy.

articles.title: Premium: The AI Data Center Financial Crisis
articles.summary: The article reports on the financial crisis facing AI data centers, with big tech companies spending over $814 billion in capital expenditures since 2023. The majority of this spending is going towards meeting the demands of AI companies like OpenAI and Anthropic. However, despite this massive investment, these companies are struggling to generate meaningful revenue from generative AI. Anthropic, for example, has reported losses of $5.2 billion before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization, while its revenue is estimated to be around $92 million per month. The article suggests that the financial situation is becoming increasingly dire, with companies relying on finance leases to obtain data center infrastructure, which are essentially long-term loans where the borrower retains ownership of the asset.

articles.title: News Publishers Are Now Blocking The Internet Archive, And We May All Regret It
articles.summary: Major news publishers, including The Guardian and The New York Times, are blocking access to the Internet Archive due to concerns that AI companies might use it as a "backdoor" to access their content. This decision has sparked criticism from experts who argue that it will lead to the loss of significant chunks of journalistic record and historical cultural context. The Internet Archive is a crucial digital library that preserves the historical record of the internet, and its efforts are essential for researchers, historians, journalists, and ordinary citizens. By blocking access to the archive, news publishers risk creating a biased historical record that systematically excludes quality journalism. This move has been described as "collateral damage" in the rush to punish AI companies.

articles.title: Sex toys maker Tenga says hacker stole customer information
articles.summary: Tenga, a Japanese sex toy maker, has notified customers of a data breach after an unauthorized party accessed the email account of one of its employees. The hacker potentially gained access to customer names, email addresses, and historical email correspondence, including order details or customer service inquiries. Tenga recommended customers change their passwords and be vigilant of suspicious emails. The company took measures to secure its systems, including resetting the hacked employee's credentials and enabling multi-factor authentication. However, it did not disclose whether multi-factor authentication was in place prior to the breach. The incident highlights concerns about data security in the sex toy industry, with Tenga being the latest company affected.

articles.title: Seven Billion Reasons for Facebook to Abandon its Face Recognition Plans
articles.summary: Meta is considering adding face recognition technology to its smart glasses, despite the significant risks and controversies surrounding this feature. The company has a history of facing legal battles and settlements related to its use of face recognition, including a $7 billion settlement in 2021 and a $1.4 billion settlement in 2024. Privacy advocates are warning that adding face recognition to Meta's smart glasses would be a bad idea, citing concerns about mass surveillance, data breach, and discrimination. The move has sparked criticism from experts who argue that the company should abandon its plans due to the potential harm it could cause.

articles.title: Why top talent is walking away from OpenAI and xAI
articles.summary: Top talent is leaving AI companies xAI and OpenAI, with half of xAI's founding team departing in the past year. The reasons for the departures are unclear, but may be related to the companies' struggles with their flagship products. OpenAI has also faced shakeups, including the disbanding of its mission alignment team and the firing of a policy executive who opposed its "adult mode" feature. This talent exodus is part of a broader trend in the tech industry, where AI companies are struggling to retain top talent due to internal conflicts and product issues. The departures come as xAI prepares for an IPO and faces intense pressure to deliver on its plans.

articles.title: Fintech lending giant Figure confirms data breach
articles.summary: Figure Technology, a blockchain-based lending company, has confirmed a data breach after hackers stole sensitive customer information through a social engineering attack. The breach is believed to have originated from an employee being tricked into sharing files with the attackers. Figure's spokesperson stated that the company is communicating with affected individuals and offering free credit monitoring. The hacking group ShinyHunters took responsibility for the hack, claiming that Figure refused to pay a ransom and published 2.5 gigabytes of allegedly stolen data. The breach is part of a larger trend of data breaches targeting fintech companies and online platforms.

articles.title: Cops Criticize Flock Safety After It’s Caught Handing Out Access To Federal Agencies
articles.summary: A California police department is criticizing Flock Safety after discovering that federal employees accessed its license plate reader records without permission. The incident occurred between August and November 2024, with at least six offices from four agencies accessing the data. Flock Safety's system allows for nationwide searches, which was enabled by default, and the company has been criticized for not placing limits on access to the hundreds of millions of license plate records it captures. This is not the first time Flock Safety has faced criticism, having previously been linked to surveillance of abortion seekers and protesters. The incident raises concerns about data privacy and the lack of control that customers have over their own data.

articles.title: Airbnb says a third of its customer support is now handled by AI in the US and Canada
articles.summary: Airbnb has announced that its custom-built AI agent is now handling approximately one-third of its customer support issues in the US and Canada. The company aims to expand this feature globally and believes that AI will become a significant part of its customer service, potentially handling over 30% of all tickets within a year. CEO Brian Chesky sees AI as a way to improve the quality of service while reducing costs. Airbnb is also investing in AI expertise, having recently hired CTO Ahmad Al-Dahle from Meta, and plans to create an AI-native experience that will help guests plan their trips and hosts run their businesses more efficiently.

articles.title: Copyright Kills Competition
articles.summary: Copyright laws are being used by powerful companies to maintain their dominance in the market, stifling competition and innovation. The concentration of power among a few corporate gatekeepers is harming creators and consumers alike. The use of copyright law to limit access to information and training data for AI development is particularly problematic, as it would benefit large tech companies at the expense of smaller competitors. This has been seen in cases such as Thomson Reuters v. Ross Intelligence, where a startup was forced out of business due to a copyright lawsuit over using works to train an AI tool. The Digital Millennium Copyright Act's "anti-circumvention" provision is also being used to block competition and innovation in various industries. Proponents of stronger copyright laws claim they will help creators, but experts argue that this would only serve to further entrench the power of large corporations.

articles.title: Airbnb plans to bake in AI features for search, discovery and support
articles.summary: Airbnb plans to integrate artificial intelligence (AI) features into its app to enhance search, discovery, and support for users. The company's CEO, Brian Chesky, announced that Airbnb will use large language models to provide personalized experiences for guests and hosts. The new AI-powered search feature is currently in testing and aims to evolve into a comprehensive and intuitive experience that extends beyond the initial search. Chesky also mentioned plans to experiment with conversational AI search and potentially introduce sponsored property slots within the AI search results. Additionally, Airbnb aims to increase its internal use of AI tools, with 80% of engineers already using them.

articles.title: Indian pharmacy chain giant exposed customer data and internal systems
articles.summary: A security vulnerability at DavaIndia Pharmacy, a large pharmacy chain in India, exposed customer order data and sensitive drug-control functions to unauthorized access. Security researcher Eaton Zveare discovered the issue after identifying insecure "super admin" application programming interfaces on the company's website. The flaw allowed attackers to view thousands of online orders containing customer information, modify product listings and prices, and change settings governing prescription requirements. The vulnerability was reported to Indian cybersecurity authorities in August 2025 and fixed within weeks, but confirmation from the company took longer. The exposure raises concerns about patient-safety risks and heightened privacy issues due to the sensitive nature of pharmacy order data.

articles.title: UK Supreme Court Affirms Ruling That Oatly Can’t Use ‘Milk’ In Its Almond Milk Branding
articles.summary: The UK Supreme Court has upheld a ruling that Oatly cannot use the slogan "Post Milk Generation" on its oat-based products due to a trademark dispute with Dairy UK. The court's decision was seen as a victory for the dairy industry, which is facing record-low farm numbers and falling retail volumes. However, critics argue that the decision is absurd and amounts to protectionism, allowing Dairy UK to limit competition from foreign companies like Oatly. The court's reasoning has been criticized for being confusing and contradictory, with some arguing that it fails to acknowledge the obvious meaning of the slogan.

articles.title: Nothing opens its first retail store in India
articles.summary: Nothing, a hardware company backed by Tiger Global, is opening its first retail store in India, its largest market. The two-story store in Bengaluru will showcase the company's products and other projects, allowing customers to buy merchandise and have select items customized. The store is inspired by Nothing's brand identity, featuring products from both Nothing and CMF, a budget brand spun off last year. India has been Nothing's strongest market, with over 2% market share in smartphones and 85% growth in shipments year-over-year. This move follows Apple's plans to open its sixth store in India this month. Nothing plans to open two more stores in Tokyo and New York, but did not provide timelines.

articles.title: Chinese boxing robots win fans in San Francisco
articles.summary: Chinese-made boxing robots, developed by companies such as UBTech and RoboThespian, have gained popularity among fans in San Francisco. The robots, which can perform complex movements and interact with humans, were showcased at an event in the city's Mission District. The success of these robots has been attributed to China's focus on practical applications and large-scale deployment, rather than marketing and hype. This development highlights the growing interest in humanoid robots and their potential uses in various industries. The event was well-received by fans, who were impressed by the robots' abilities and agility. The popularity of these robots may indicate a shift towards more substance-driven innovation in emerging technologies.

articles.title: CBS Staffers Jump Ship Ahead Of More Layoffs From Another Pointless Media Merger
articles.summary: CBS News staff members are leaving the company ahead of expected layoffs due to the $8 billion merger with Skydance, a deal that has been criticized for its potential to create an autocrat-friendly safe space in media. The departures come after CBS News boss Bari Weiss promised buyouts to employees who were insufficiently deferential to Larry Ellison's ambitions. The merger is part of a larger trend of pointless media mergers that promise synergies but ultimately result in layoffs, lower quality content, and higher rates for consumers. This development relates to prior coverage of the Time Warner Discovery disaster and CBS's own struggles under Weiss's leadership.

articles.title: Score, the dating app for people with good credit, is back
articles.summary: Score, a dating app that requires users to have good credit, has been relaunched after initially shutting down six months after its debut in 2024. The app's creator, Luke Bailey, claims it was shut down due to user demand and academic interest in studying the app's impact on relationship culture. This time around, Score will be available globally, including Canada, and will have a more inclusive approach with two tiers: basic and verified. The verified tier requires users to verify their ID and credit score through Equifax, allowing access to premium features.

articles.title: Meta plans to add facial recognition to its smart glasses, report claims
articles.summary: Meta is planning to add facial recognition technology to its smart glasses, a feature internally known as "Name Tag," which would allow users to identify people and access information about them through Meta's AI assistant. The company has been deliberating on how to release the feature since early last year due to concerns over safety and privacy risks. Despite initial plans to release it first to attendees of a conference for the visually impaired, Meta now aims to launch the feature publicly, citing a favorable political environment as a reason to proceed. This move comes after the company previously dropped similar plans in 2021 due to technical challenges and ethical concerns.

articles.title: Cohere’s $240M year sets stage for IPO
articles.summary: Cohere, a Canadian AI startup founded in 2019, has surpassed its annual recurring revenue target of $200 million, reaching $240 million with over 50% quarter-over-quarter growth. The company's core technology is its Command family of generative AI models, which can be deployed on limited GPUs, making it attractive to enterprises looking to manage costs and resources. Cohere has the backing of investors like Nvidia, AMD, and Salesforce, and has launched a higher-level enterprise platform called North for secure, custom AI agents and workflows. The startup's CEO has hinted at an impending IPO, which could put it in competition with other high-profile tech companies planning public debuts.

articles.title: Behind the Blog: Unglamorous Work
articles.summary: The article "Behind the Blog: Unglamorous Work" discusses the author's reliance on the Federal Procurement Data System (FPDS.gov) for research and reporting. The website, which contains decades of records on government purchases, has been a crucial resource for the author but is set to shut down. This development poses a challenge for the author, who relies heavily on FPDS for leads and story ideas. The article reflects on the importance of FPDS in the author's work and the potential impact of its closure.

articles.title: Amazon’s Ring cancels partnership with Flock, a network of AI cameras used by ICE, feds, and police
articles.summary: Amazon-owned Ring has canceled its partnership with Flock Safety, a network of AI-powered surveillance cameras used by law enforcement agencies such as ICE, the Secret Service, and the Navy. The decision comes after controversy surrounding Ring's Super Bowl ad showcasing its "Search Party" feature, which uses AI to search for lost dogs across neighborhood cameras. Critics have raised concerns that this technology could be misused for surveillance and control, exacerbating racial biases in law enforcement. Although Ring claims its technology is not capable of processing human biometrics, Flock's AI-powered searches can identify individuals based on descriptions. The partnership cancellation follows a history of criticism against Ring for its handling of user data and collaboration with law enforcement.

articles.title: Dutch phone giant Odido says millions of customers affected by data breach
articles.summary: Dutch phone company Odido has confirmed a data breach affecting over 6.2 million customers, or about a third of the country's population. The breach occurred when unidentified hackers gained access to the company's customer contact system and downloaded sensitive customer information, including names, phone numbers, addresses, dates of birth, bank account numbers, and government-issued ID details. The stolen data does not include call records, location data, billing information, or image scans of government IDs. This incident is part of a larger trend of data breaches targeting phone and telecommunication companies in recent years, with hackers seeking highly confidential customer information.

articles.title: Elon Musk suggests spate of xAI exits have been push, not pull
articles.summary: Elon Musk has addressed the recent wave of departures from xAI, stating that the exits were due to fit rather than performance. He claimed that as the company grows, some employees are better suited for earlier stages and not for later stages. This explanation comes after six co-founders left the company, with at least 11 engineers publicly announcing their departure in the past week. Some departing staff members have hinted at a desire for more autonomy and smaller teams to build frontier tech rapidly. The departures come amid significant controversy for xAI, including regulatory scrutiny over its AI product Grok's creation of nonconsensual explicit deepfakes.

articles.title: A Stanford grad student created an algorithm to help his classmates find love; now, Date Drop is the basis of his new startup
articles.summary: Stanford graduate student Henry Weng created Date Drop, a service that pairs students with potential dates based on their responses to a questionnaire. The platform has gained popularity among over 5,000 Stanford students and has been rolled out at 10 other schools. Weng's startup, The Relationship Company, aims to facilitate all meaningful relationships, including friendships, professional connections, and community events. Date Drop claims to have a higher conversion rate of matches to actual dates compared to traditional dating apps like Tinder. Weng has raised "a few million" from angel investors, including Mark Pincus, and is planning to expand the service beyond college campuses.

articles.title: Roku to launch streaming bundles as part of its efforts to continue growing its profitability
articles.summary: Roku has announced plans to launch new streaming bundles as part of its efforts to continue growing its profitability. The company's fourth-quarter earnings report showed a 16% year-over-year increase in total revenue, reaching $1.4 billion, and a net income of $80.5 million. Roku is expanding its ad-free subscription service, Howdy, to more platforms and partnering with premium streaming services like HBO Max. The company aims to attract cost-conscious consumers by offering bundles that cater to their interests. Roku's user base has grown significantly, with users streaming 145.6 billion hours of video in 2025, a 15% increase from the previous year. The company is nearing the milestone of 100 million streaming households and projects total net revenue of $5.5 billion and gross profit of $2.4 billion for 2026.

articles.title: Anthropic’s Super Bowl ads mocking AI with ads helped push Claude’s app into the top 10
articles.summary: Anthropic's Super Bowl ads, which mocked the idea of including ads in AI chatbots, have helped push its app Claude into the top 10 on the US App Store. The ads, which depicted darkly comedic scenarios of people seeking advice from chatbots being steered to "cougar" dating sites and height-boosting insoles, have resonated strongly with users who prefer a "no ads" experience. As a result, Claude's downloads have increased by 32% in the US, with an estimated 148,000 downloads from Sunday through Tuesday. This marks a significant gain for the app, which had previously struggled to gain traction on mobile devices.

articles.title: Judge Accuses DOJ Of Telling Court To “Pound Sand,” In Case Over Venezuelans Sent To Salvadoran Concentration Camp
articles.summary: Judge Boasberg has issued a scathing ruling in the JGG v. Trump case, criticizing the DOJ for ignoring the court's orders and telling it to "pound sand." The case involves Venezuelans who were deported to a Salvadoran concentration camp by the US government. Boasberg accuses the DOJ of flagrantly disobeying courts and denying due process to the deportees. He has ordered the government to facilitate the return of those who want to come back, but notes that this may not be feasible for many of the plaintiffs. The judge also points out that anyone who takes up the offer will likely be detained by immigration officials upon arrival in the US.

articles.title: India partners with Alibaba.com for export push despite past China tech bans
articles.summary: India's government has partnered with Alibaba.com, a Chinese e-commerce platform, to help small businesses and startups reach overseas buyers through its B2B export-focused program. This collaboration marks a selective engagement with Chinese-linked tech platforms, despite India's past bans on consumer apps and games in 2020. The partnership aims to support Indian exporters by offering commissions and technical support to identify and onboard them onto Alibaba.com's global platform. This move reflects India's differentiated approach towards China, maintaining restrictions in strategic sectors while allowing economic engagement where there is clear benefit.

articles.title: The SEC closed its investigation into Fisker
articles.summary: The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has closed its investigation into Fisker, a bankrupt electric vehicle startup, after roughly one year of probing the company's financial dealings. The SEC revealed the closure through a Freedom of Information Act request in January 2026. While it is unclear how far the investigation progressed, the agency had previously sent subpoenas to the company and indicated that further action might be necessary. This development comes amid a significant drop in enforcement actions and settlements during President Trump's second term, with only four public companies facing SEC enforcement actions in 2025.

articles.title: How cheap Chinese phones catapulted Kenya into the global digital economy
articles.summary: Kenya's economy has been catapulted into the global digital economy thanks to affordable Chinese phones that have made mobile internet access widespread. The influx of cheap smartphones has enabled millions of Kenyans to join the digital economy, with many using their devices for online banking, e-commerce, and social media. This shift has also led to the growth of a thriving tech industry in Kenya, with startups and entrepreneurs leveraging the country's young population and growing middle class. The article highlights how Chinese phones have democratized access to mobile internet, enabling Kenyans to participate in the global digital economy and creating new opportunities for economic growth.

articles.title: A new version of OpenAI’s Codex is powered by a new dedicated chip
articles.summary: OpenAI has released a lightweight version of its Codex tool, called GPT-5.3-Codex-Spark, designed for faster inference and real-time collaboration. The new model is powered by Cerebras' Wafer Scale Engine 3 chip, which boasts 4 trillion transistors and is optimized for low latency. This marks a significant integration of Cerebras into OpenAI's physical infrastructure, following a multi-year agreement worth over $10 billion. Spark is intended to enable rapid prototyping and iteration, and will be available in a research preview for ChatGPT Pro users. The partnership between OpenAI and Cerebras aims to unlock new possibilities for fast inference and interaction patterns.

articles.title: Spotify says its best developers haven’t written a line of code since December, thanks to AI
articles.summary: Spotify's co-CEO Gustav Söderström revealed during the company's fourth-quarter earnings call that its top developers have not written a line of code since December, thanks to the use of AI tools like Claude Code. The company attributes this to its internal system "Honk," which utilizes generative AI for remote, real-time code deployment and has helped speed up coding and product velocity. Spotify credits Honk with enabling engineers to focus on higher-level tasks, such as defining requirements and testing, rather than writing code. The company sees AI development as just the beginning and is building a unique dataset that other large language models (LLMs) cannot commoditize.

articles.title: Daily Deal: The 2026 Complete Firewall Admin Bundle
articles.summary: The 2026 Complete Firewall Admin Bundle, a collection of seven courses on cybersecurity, is currently on sale for $25 through the Techdirt Deals Store. The bundle covers IT fundamentals, packet control, secure architecture, and cloud-ready defenses, as well as topics to help users prepare for CompTIA Server+ and CCNA exams. This deal supports Techdirt and is available until further notice. The courses are designed to help users transform their future in cybersecurity with next-level skills. The bundle is a daily deal, but its duration is not specified.

articles.title: ICE, CBP Knew Facial Recognition App Couldn’t Do What DHS Says It Could, Deployed It Anyway
articles.summary: The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and its components, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and Customs and Border Protection (CBP), have deployed a facial recognition app called "Mobile Fortify" to identify migrants without proper paperwork in place. The app was developed by NEC and is being used by officers working with both agencies despite the lack of Privacy Impact Assessments (PIAs). DHS claims that monitoring protocols are in place, but ICE says they are still developing these protocols. This deployment is part of a broader pattern of deploying new technology without required paperwork, which has been criticized as a disregard for civil liberties and privacy rights.

articles.title: Automattic planned to target 10 competitors with royalty fees, WP Engine claims in new filing
articles.summary: WP Engine has filed an amended complaint against Automattic and WordPress co-founder Matt Mullenweg, alleging that Mullenweg intended to target 10 other hosting companies with royalty payments for using the WordPress trademark. The company claims that Mullenweg tried to get payment processor Stripe to cancel its contract with WP Engine after the lawsuit was filed. The new allegations include aggressive language used by Mullenweg against WP Engine and accusations of arbitrary royalty rates. Automattic has responded, stating that the lawsuit is going nowhere and that the court has already dismissed many of WP Engine's central claims.

articles.title: Trump administration undermines EPA enforcement of Clean Air Act
articles.summary: The Trump administration has officially repealed the EPA's 2009 "endangerment finding" that greenhouse gases pose a threat to human health and welfare. This move undermines the EPA's ability to regulate greenhouse gases under the Clean Air Act. The repeal is expected to slow the decline in emissions by about 10%, but critics argue it will lead to more pollution, higher costs, and real harms for American families. The Environmental Defense Fund has condemned the action, citing the devastating impacts of unabated climate change on mortality rates and global GDP.

articles.title: Hacker linked to Epstein removed from Black Hat cyber conference website
articles.summary: Vincenzo Iozzo, a renowned hacker linked to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, has been removed from the review board pages of Black Hat and Code Blue cybersecurity conferences. The move comes after new documents were released by the Department of Justice, which mention Iozzo's interactions with Epstein over 4 years. Iozzo denies claims that he was Epstein's personal hacker or did any hacking for him, stating that their relationship was limited to business opportunities and discussions about emerging technologies. Black Hat has not commented on the removal, while Code Blue attributed it to a planned update of its review board members. The development raises questions about Iozzo's involvement with Epstein and his suitability to serve in the cybersecurity industry.

articles.title: Waymo Is Getting DoorDashers to Close Doors on Self Driving Cars
articles.summary: Waymo, Google's autonomous vehicle company, has launched a pilot program with DoorDash to pay Dashers to close doors on parked Waymo vehicles that previous passengers left open. The program is currently running in Atlanta and pays Dashers around $10 for the task. This unusual partnership shows that even with self-driving cars, humans are sometimes needed for simple tasks. Waymo has stated that its future vehicle platforms will have automated door closures, making this pilot program a temporary solution to enhance fleet efficiency.

articles.title: Attackers prompted Gemini over 100,000 times while trying to clone it, Google says
articles.summary: Google has reported that attackers have attempted to clone its Gemini AI chatbot by prompting it over 100,000 times in various languages. The company considers this "model extraction" and intellectual property theft, despite having built its own large language model (LLM) from internet materials without permission. This practice is known as distillation, where a new model is trained on the outputs of a previous model to gain a competitive edge. Google believes the culprits are mostly private companies and researchers, but has declined to name suspects. The report highlights the gray area in AI development, where companies like Google may have used similar tactics in the past.

articles.title: Bondi Spying On Congressional Epstein Searches Should Be A Major Scandal
articles.summary: Attorney General Pam Bondi's Department of Justice (DOJ) has been accused of spying on Congressional searches of unredacted Jeffrey Epstein files. During a House Judiciary Committee hearing, Rep. Pramila Jayapal asked victims of Epstein to stand up if they had been contacted by the DOJ about their experiences, and none of them had. However, Bondi was seen holding a document with Jayapal's search history on it, sparking outrage. This incident has raised concerns about the separation of powers between the executive and legislative branches, as well as the potential for government surveillance of Congressional activities. The situation is being compared to a 2014 CIA scandal in which the agency spied on Senate staffers investigating its torture program.

articles.title: YouTube finally launches a dedicated app for Apple Vision Pro
articles.summary: YouTube has finally launched a dedicated app for Apple Vision Pro, two years after initially hesitating to invest in a native experience. The app allows users to enjoy their favorite content on a theater-sized virtual screen, including spatial videos and 8K playback for the latest M5 chip models. This move comes as the initial hype surrounding the headset has diminished, with user engagement reportedly lukewarm and sales declining significantly. The app's release is seen as a significant development in the ecosystem of Apple Vision Pro, which had previously been lacking a native YouTube experience.

articles.title: Anthropic raises another $30B in Series G, with a new value of $380B
articles.summary: Anthropic has raised $30 billion in its Series G funding round, valuing the company at $380 billion. This is a significant increase from its previous valuation of $183 billion. The funding was led by Singaporean wealth fund GIC and investment management firm Coatue, with other prominent firms co-leading the round. Anthropic's AI model, Claude, has been gaining traction in the market, leading to increased demand for the company's products and services. This fundraising reflects the growing importance of Claude in business operations. The funding will be used to continue building enterprise-grade products and models. Anthropic is competing with OpenAI, which is seeking an additional $100 billion in funding.

articles.title: Didero lands $30M to put manufacturing procurement on ‘agentic’ autopilot
articles.summary: Didero, a startup founded by Tim Spencer and Lorenz Pallhuber, has raised $30 million in Series A funding to automate global procurement processes for manufacturers and distributors. The company's platform uses generative AI to ingest communication with suppliers, putting a significant portion of the procurement workflow on autopilot. Didero aims to simplify complex procurement tasks such as sourcing raw materials, negotiating pricing, and managing payments. The startup has dozens of customers, including Footprint, a provider of sustainable packaging solutions. This funding round was co-led by Chemistry and Headline, with participation from Microsoft's venture fund M12.

articles.title: Discord Voluntarily Pushes Mandatory Age Verification Despite Recent Data Breach
articles.summary: Discord has begun rolling out mandatory age verification for users under 18, sparking concerns about censorship and surveillance. The platform will use a combination of account tenure, device data, and activity patterns to estimate users' ages, with those who are not estimated as adults being asked to scan their face or upload a government ID through a third-party vendor. This move comes despite Discord's recent data breach in 2025, which exposed sensitive information from over 70,000 users. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has been critical of age verification mandates, citing concerns about the potential for data breaches and the erosion of anonymous speech online.

articles.title: On Its 30th Birthday, Section 230 Remains The Linchpin For Users’ Speech
articles.summary: Section 230 of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 celebrates its 30th anniversary this week, a law shielding websites from liability for third-party content. Despite controversy over its protection of tech companies, Section 230 remains essential to online discourse and has been instrumental in shaping the internet, economy, government, and society. However, bipartisan proposals in Congress aim to repeal or sunset the law, citing concerns about big tech's practices. Critics argue that rolling back Section 230 would not address these issues but rather cement the dominance of large tech companies and lead to more censorship of lawful speech. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) defends Section 230 as the best available system to protect users' speech online.

articles.title: Tumbler Ridge Shooter Created Mall Shooting Simulator in Roblox
articles.summary: An 18-year-old suspect, Jesse Van Rootselaar, who is accused of killing eight people and injuring 25 in a mass shooting at a Canadian secondary school, created a Roblox game that simulated a mass shooting in a shopping mall. The game was discovered by users on the online forum Kiwi Farms and subsequently removed from Roblox after it was confirmed to be connected to the suspect. This incident has sparked concerns about the potential link between video games and real-life violence, despite repeated studies showing no correlation. Roblox has stated that it uses a combination of AI and safety specialists to review content before it is uploaded to the platform.

articles.title: Musk needed a new vision for SpaceX and xAI. He landed on Moonbase Alpha.
articles.summary: Elon Musk has unveiled a new vision for his companies SpaceX and xAI, which involves building a city on the moon called Moonbase Alpha. The project aims to harness the energy of the sun to power advanced artificial intelligence (AI) models. Musk believes that this will allow humanity to achieve a higher level of technological advancement, as measured by the Kardashev scale. This new vision comes after SpaceX's previous goal of colonizing Mars was put on hold due to financial constraints. The Moonbase Alpha project is seen as a way for Musk to create a new narrative and hiring tool for his companies.

articles.title: OpenAI sidesteps Nvidia with unusually fast coding model on plate-sized chips
articles.summary: OpenAI has released its first production AI model to run on non-Nvidia hardware, deploying the GPT-5.3-Codex-Spark coding model on Cerebras' Wafer Scale Engine chips. The model delivers code at over 1,000 tokens per second, roughly 15 times faster than its predecessor. This development marks a significant shift in OpenAI's strategy, as it seeks to reduce its reliance on Nvidia's AI chips. Cerebras has been identified as a key engineering partner for this project, and the partnership is expected to bring fast inference capabilities to OpenAI's platform. The release of GPT-5.3-Codex-Spark is part of OpenAI's ongoing efforts to improve its coding agent capabilities, which have been a sore spot in the past.

articles.title: Rivian was saved by software in 2025
articles.summary: Rivian's revenue grew by 8% in 2025, driven largely by its software and services segment, which more than tripled to $1.55 billion. The company's joint venture with Volkswagen Group was a key contributor to this growth, with Rivian receiving a $1 billion payout as part of the milestone-based agreement. Despite a 15% decline in automotive revenue, Rivian is optimistic about its future prospects, particularly with the upcoming launch of its R2 SUV, which is expected to be cheaper to build and less expensive for customers. The company is projecting improved profitability in 2026, with an adjusted net loss of between $1.8 billion and $2.1 billion.

articles.title: IBM will hire your entry-level talent in the age of AI
articles.summary: IBM plans to triple its entry-level hiring in the US in 2026, despite concerns that AI will replace these jobs. The company's chief human resource officer, Nickle LaMoreaux, announced the initiative at a recent summit, citing the need for employees with skills in people-forward areas such as customer engagement. IBM is adjusting its job descriptions to focus on areas where human skills are still essential, rather than automatable tasks like coding. This move suggests that some companies may be adapting their hiring strategies to ensure they have a pipeline of talent for future roles. The decision also contradicts the notion that AI will replace entry-level jobs entirely.

articles.title: Amid disappointing earnings, Pinterest claims it sees more searches than ChatGPT
articles.summary: Pinterest CEO Bill Ready attempted to downplay the company's disappointing fourth-quarter earnings by highlighting its search volume and user engagement. Despite missing revenue and earnings expectations, Pinterest reported a 12% year-over-year growth in monthly active users to 619 million. However, shares dropped 20% in after-hours trading due to concerns about advertiser pullback and a new furniture tariff. Ready claimed that Pinterest sees more searches than ChatGPT, with 80 billion searches per month compared to ChatGPT's 75 billion. The company also forecast lower sales for the first quarter of 2026, citing larger advertisers pulling back on spend in Europe.

articles.title: For $1M, you can pay Bryan Johnson (or BryanAI?) to teach you how to live longer
articles.summary: Bryan Johnson, a tech entrepreneur and self-proclaimed longevity guru, is offering a $1 million per year program called "Immortals" that promises to teach individuals the secrets to living longer. The program includes access to a dedicated concierge team, AI support, extensive testing, and best practices for skin and hair care. Johnson claims this is the exact protocol he has followed for the past five years, but critics point out that his methods are unproven and inaccessible to most people. This development comes as part of a growing trend among the ultrawealthy to pursue longevity at any cost, with some programs charging tens of thousands of dollars per year.

articles.title: Ctrl-Alt-Speech: Panic! At The Discord
articles.summary: The latest episode of the Ctrl-Alt-Speech podcast covers various news stories related to online speech, content moderation, and internet regulation. The hosts discuss the 30th anniversary of Section 230, a law that protects online platforms from liability for user-generated content, and why it's essential to preserve its current form. They also touch on other topics, including Discord's new teen-by-default settings, TikTok's addictive features, and Meta's ban on political ads in Hungary. Additionally, the podcast mentions various studies and reports on media literacy, online harassment, and debanking adult industry workers in Canada.

articles.title: Microsoft’s AI-Powered Copyright Bots Fucked Up And Got An Innocent Game Delisted From Steam
articles.summary: Microsoft's AI-powered copyright enforcement bot incorrectly flagged a game called Allumeria for copyright infringement due to a screenshot on the game's Steam page resembling Minecraft. The bot, provided by Tracer.AI, mistakenly identified the image as infringing upon Microsoft's assets. Mojang, the developer of Minecraft, was notified and investigated the claim, leading to the reinstatement of Allumeria on Steam after 12 hours. This incident highlights the flaws in relying on automated copyright enforcement systems that can cause collateral damage to legitimate content creators. The issue is not a one-time mistake but rather a recurring problem with AI-powered bots failing to accurately identify copyright infringement.

articles.title: Waymo is asking DoorDash drivers to shut the doors of its self-driving cars
articles.summary: Waymo is facing an unexpected issue with its self-driving cars: passengers accidentally leaving the doors open, rendering the vehicles immobile. To address this problem, Waymo has partnered with DoorDash to enlist drivers to close the doors for a fee of $6.25 in Atlanta and up to $24 in Los Angeles. This arrangement is part of a broader relationship between Waymo and DoorDash, which includes an autonomous delivery service launched in Phoenix last year. The issue highlights the challenges of deploying self-driving cars on public roads, where human error can still occur. Despite this, Waymo remains committed to expanding its services, with plans for future vehicles to have automated door closures.

articles.title: Pluralistic: Trump antitrust is dead (13 Feb 2026)
articles.summary: The Trump administration's antitrust efforts have been effectively dismantled, marking the end of a populist right-wing movement that sought to target Big Tech companies. The "Khanservatives" coalition, which included figures like JD Vance and Matt Gaetz, had initially supported Biden's FTC commissioner Lina Khan but ultimately failed to achieve their goals due to corruption and backroom dealings within the administration. Trump's antitrust agencies engaged in "boss politics antitrust," favoring certain companies while targeting others, leading to a lack of effective enforcement. The demise of Trump's antitrust efforts is seen as a victory for giant corporations, which have been able to maintain their power and influence.

articles.title: Fusion startup Helion hits blistering temps as it races toward 2028 deadline
articles.summary: Helion, a fusion energy startup based in Everett, Washington, has achieved a key milestone by reaching 150 million degrees Celsius in plasmas inside its Polaris prototype reactor. This is three-quarters of the way toward the temperature needed to operate a commercial fusion power plant. The company's use of deuterium-tritium fuel and innovative reactor design sets it apart from other fusion startups, which are targeting the early 2030s for electricity production. Helion has a contract with Microsoft to sell electricity starting in 2028, but this will come from a larger commercial reactor called Orion, not Polaris.

articles.title: OpenAI accuses DeepSeek of “free-riding” on American R&D
articles.summary: OpenAI has accused rival AI company DeepSeek of "free-riding" on American research and development, claiming that DeepSeek is using OpenAI's own work without permission or proper citation. This accusation comes as part of a broader dispute between the two companies over the role of advertising in AI-powered chatbots. The exchange highlights the competitive dynamics between OpenAI and DeepSeek, as well as ongoing debates about intellectual property and innovation in the tech industry. The controversy also raises questions about the ethics of AI development and the potential consequences of unchecked competition.

articles.title: Donald Trump Is VERY EXCITED About All Of Our Shitty Right Wing Broadcasters Merging Into One Bigger, Even Shittier Company
articles.summary: The FCC, led by Trump's appointees, has dismantled media ownership limits, allowing for the consolidation of local broadcasters. The latest development is Nexstar's proposal to acquire Tegna in a $6.2 billion deal, which would give them control over 265 stations in 44 states and 132 DMAs. This move is seen as a step towards creating an even larger, shittier company that would further concentrate media power in the hands of right-wing interests. Trump has expressed enthusiasm for this merger, despite its potential to harm local news and democracy. The consolidation of media giants, telecoms, tech companies, and social media companies under the control of unethical individuals is a worrying trend that threatens the integrity of information and the democratic process.

articles.title: Eclipse backs all-EV marketplace Ever in $31M funding round
articles.summary: Ever, a startup that bills itself as an "AI-native, full-stack auto retail business" for electric vehicles (EVs), has secured $31 million in Series A funding led by Eclipse. The company aims to disrupt the automotive retail experience with its digital-first approach and AI-powered orchestration layer, which can handle various workflows behind a transaction. Ever's hybrid model combines online marketplace and physical locations, allowing customers to see and try cars in person while also offering a seamless online experience. The startup has already attracted thousands of customers buying and selling EVs on its platform.

articles.title: Cops Are Buying ‘GeoSpy’, an AI That Geolocates Photos in Seconds
articles.summary: The Miami-Dade Sheriff's Office (MDSO) and the Los Angeles Police Department (LAPD) have purchased access to GeoSpy, an AI tool that can geolocate photos using architectural and environmental clues. The MDSO paid $85,500 for a custom model trained on Miami-Dade County data, as well as two annual licenses with 350 searches each. LAPD has also acquired the technology, which is being used in criminal investigations. GeoSpy's accuracy claims have been disputed, but the tool has shown promise in identifying geospatial and temporal patterns.

articles.title: US FTC airs concerns over allegations that Apple News suppresses right-wing content
articles.summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has expressed concerns over allegations that Apple's News app is suppressing right-wing content, citing reports from Media Research Center that claim the app excludes conservative outlets from its top 20 articles. FTC chair Andrew Ferguson wrote to Apple CEO Tim Cook urging a comprehensive review of the company's terms of service and corrective action if necessary. This move comes after President Donald Trump shared the report on his social media platform, Truth Social, and amid ongoing tensions between Big Tech companies and the Trump administration.

articles.title: Apple acquires all rights to ‘Severance,’ will produce future seasons in-house
articles.summary: Apple has acquired the rights to its hit show "Severance" from Fifth Season, the original studio, for $70 million. The deal includes all IP and future seasons of the show, which will be produced in-house by Apple's studio. This move is similar to Apple's previous acquisition of AMC Studios' sci-fi show "Silo". The production costs for "Severance" had exceeded Fifth Season's budget, prompting Apple to take full control. The show has been a success for Apple, with its second season being the most-watched series at the time and receiving numerous Emmy nominations.

articles.title: More US investors sue South Korean government over handling of Coupang data breach
articles.summary: US investors in Coupang, a South Korean e-commerce company, are suing the South Korean government over its handling of a massive data breach that exposed nearly 34 million customers' personal information. The investors claim that the government's actions were discriminatory and unfair, and that they suffered losses as a result. They have filed for international arbitration under the US-Korea Free Trade Agreement (FTA) and are seeking compensation from the government. The dispute has escalated into a geopolitical flashpoint, with the South Korean government facing criticism for its handling of the breach and potential penalties against Coupang.

articles.title: Joseph Gordon-Levitt Goes To Washington DC, Gets Section 230 Completely Backwards
articles.summary: Actor Joseph Gordon-Levitt recently gave a speech in Washington D.C., calling for the sunsetting of Section 230, a law that shields websites from liability for third-party content. However, his understanding of the law is fundamentally flawed, as he believes it was created to protect "neutral" platforms, which is not true.
