In reality, Section 230 was designed to allow platforms to make editorial decisions without being held liable as publishers. Gordon-Levitt's speech has been criticized for spreading misinformation about the law and its purpose. This development comes at a time when there are ongoing bipartisan efforts to repeal or reform Section 230, with some arguing it provides too much protection for tech companies.

articles.title: Aurora’s driverless trucks can now travel farther distances faster than human drivers
articles.summary: Aurora's self-driving trucks have achieved a significant milestone by completing a non-stop 1,000-mile journey from Fort Worth to Phoenix in 15 hours. This feat exceeds what human drivers can accomplish due to federal regulations limiting their driving time. The company's driverless trucks are now earning revenue for its customers, including Uber Freight, Werner, FedEx, and Schneider. Aurora plans to expand its operations across the Sun Belt region of the US, with a projected fleet of over 200 trucks by the end of the year. The company has reported $4 million in adjusted revenue for 2025, despite a net income loss of $816 million.

articles.title: Threads’ new ‘Dear Algo’ AI feature lets you personalize your feed
articles.summary: Threads, a social network owned by Meta, has introduced an AI-powered feature called "Dear Algo" that allows users to personalize their feed by temporarily adjusting what they see more or less of. Users can post a public request with the phrase "Dear Algo" followed by their preferences, and their feed will be adjusted for three days. This feature is available in four countries initially and aims to make Threads feel more real-time and community-driven. The launch comes as Threads surpasses X in daily mobile usage, according to market intelligence firm Similarweb. While the feature offers a new level of personalization, it also raises concerns about public visibility of user requests. Meta views this as an opportunity for users to discover new conversations and topics.

articles.title: Google releases the first beta of Android 17, adopts a continuous developer release plan
articles.summary: Google has released the first beta of Android 17, which introduces performance improvements, new camera capabilities, and a continuous developer release plan. The company is adopting a Canary channel for developers, similar to Chrome's development approach, allowing for over-the-air updates and more integrated workflows. This change aims to reduce fragmentation in the Android ecosystem by releasing features and APIs as soon as they are approved internally. Android 17 also includes restrictions on resizing options for large-screen devices, improved Wi-Fi connectivity, and better camera handling capabilities.

articles.title: Government Loses Hard Drives It Was Supposed to Put ICE Detention Center Footage On
articles.summary: The federal government has lost three hard drives containing surveillance footage from an Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) detention center in suburban Chicago. The footage was requested as part of a lawsuit brought by detainees alleging abuse within the facility. Despite providing the government with five large hard drives to facilitate production, the government claims it cannot afford storage space for the footage. This development is the latest in a series of controversies surrounding the handling of surveillance footage from the Broadview detention center.

articles.title: Why the economics of orbital AI are so brutal
articles.summary: Elon Musk's SpaceX is planning to build solar-powered orbital data centers across as many as a million satellites, which could shift up to 100 GW of compute power off the planet. This vision is shared by other tech giants, including Google and Amazon Web Services, but experts say it will require significant technological advancements, massive capital expenditure, and lower launch costs. The current cost of launching a satellite is around $3,600/kg, which needs to be reduced to $200/kg for orbital data centers to become economically viable. SpaceX's next-generation Starship rocket is expected to deliver these improvements, but its success is not guaranteed.

articles.title: 🗣 Homeland Security Wants Names | EFFector 38.3
articles.summary: The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has been using administrative subpoenas to demand that tech companies hand over users' names, locations, and other information. This move has raised concerns about government overreach and the erosion of online privacy. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) is urging tech companies to stand up for their users by resisting these subpoenas and advocating for stronger protections against unlawful surveillance. The EFF is also highlighting its ongoing campaigns to expand end-to-end encryption protections, stop government face scans, and preserve Section 230, a law that protects online speech.

articles.title: DOJ says Trenchant boss sold exploits to Russian broker capable of accessing ‘millions of computers and devices’
articles.summary: The former boss of Trenchant, a US maker of hacking and surveillance tools, has pleaded guilty to selling eight zero-day exploits to a Russian broker. The exploits could have been used to access millions of computers and devices worldwide, including in the US. Peter Williams, 39, made over $1.3 million from the sales between 2022 and 2025. Prosecutors are seeking a nine-year prison sentence, three years of supervised release, and a fine of up to $250,000. Williams' lawyer argues that he did not intend to harm the US or his native Australia.

articles.title: Daily Deal: The Ultimate Microsoft Office Professional 2021 for Windows License + Windows 11 Pro Bundle
articles.summary: The Ultimate Microsoft Office Professional 2021 for Windows + Windows 11 Pro Bundle is on sale for $44.97, offering a lifetime license to the professional version of Microsoft Office and the latest operating system from Microsoft. The bundle includes popular applications such as MS Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Outlook, Teams, OneNote, Publisher, and Access, along with Windows 11 Pro, designed for professionals who need a secure platform. This deal is available through the Techdirt Deals Store, which is powered by StackCommerce, and supports Techdirt. The sale is limited-time only.

articles.title: The System Of Checks And Balances Doesn’t Work When One Branch Refuses To Play By The Rules
articles.summary: The article argues that the system of checks and balances in the US government has broken down due to one branch (the executive) refusing to play by the rules. The judicial branch has become complicit in allowing executive overreach, while the legislative branch is compromised by MAGA bootlickers who refuse to hold the executive accountable. This has led to instances where the executive ignores court orders and disregards individual rights, as seen in a sworn statement from a Guatemalan resident of Minnesota who was detained and mistreated by ICE despite a court-ordered release.

articles.title: Activist investor Ancora publicly opposes the WBD-Netflix deal
articles.summary: Activist investor Ancora Holdings has publicly opposed Netflix's $82.7 billion bid to acquire Warner Bros. Discovery (WBD), instead throwing its support behind a rival bid from Paramount. Ancora claims the Netflix deal is inferior, involves more regulatory risk, and doesn't deliver as much immediate cash to shareholders. The investment group has purchased $200 million in WBD shares and warned that it will vote against the Netflix deal if the WBD board refuses to reconsider Paramount's proposal. This development adds a new layer of complexity to the already tense situation, with Ancora seeking to rally other shareholders to reject the Netflix proposal.

articles.title: The search is on: 2026 Joseph C. Belden Innovation Award nominations are open
articles.summary: Nominations for the 2026 Joseph C. Belden Innovation Award are now open, inviting groundbreaking technologies and solutions to be recognized for driving meaningful impact across connected industries. The award, named after a visionary in early telecommunications and connectivity, celebrates innovations that push boundaries and power the future. This year's award has an expanded focus on IT/OT convergence, recognizing solutions that bridge the gap between information technology and operational systems. Finalists and winners will receive visibility with industry leaders, networking opportunities, and tailored co-marketing support. The nomination deadline is February 13.

articles.title: Amazon’s new eero Signal keeps you connected to the internet when outages occur
articles.summary: Amazon's eero has introduced a new device called eero Signal, which acts as an instant backup internet connection when the main internet goes down. The device plugs into existing eero devices with Wi-Fi 6 or higher and automatically switches to cellular service during outages. This is ideal for remote workers, security systems, and areas prone to outages. The eero Signal comes in two plans: a $99.99 annual subscription with 10 GB of backup data and a $199.99 plan with 100 GB of data. A 5G version will be launched later this year.

articles.title: Cash App adds payment links so you can get paid in a DM
articles.summary: Cash App has introduced payment links, allowing users to send payments via hyperlinks that can be attached to various communications such as texts, emails, or direct messages (DMs). This feature aims to make the process of requesting and sending money more seamless and less awkward, particularly for Gen Z users who often engage in multiple conversations around payments. The links can be used for one-time or recurring payments, including group payments. Cash App's goal is to provide a more human and natural way of requesting money, alleviating social awkwardness associated with traditional payment requests.

articles.title: How to get into a16z’s super-competitive Speedrun startup accelerator program
articles.summary: Andreessen Horowitz's Speedrun startup accelerator program has an acceptance rate of less than 1%, with over 19,000 startups pitching and fewer than 0.4% accepted into the latest cohort. The program, which focuses on early-stage startups, examines the founding team's skills and capabilities, preferring teams with a shared history or complementary skill sets. Speedrun also looks for teams that have already achieved some market validation or traction for their product. Founders should focus on showcasing why their team is well-suited to solve the problem they're tackling, rather than spending too much time on market theory. The program invests up to $1 million in each company and provides access to a16z's advisory and business networks.

articles.title: OpenAI researcher quits over ChatGPT ads, warns of "Facebook" path
articles.summary: Former OpenAI researcher Zoë Hitzig has resigned from the company, citing concerns over its advertising strategy for ChatGPT. She argues that the ads risk repeating Facebook's mistakes by exploiting users' personal data, which they shared with the chatbot under the assumption of confidentiality. Hitzig warns that OpenAI may initially follow principles to protect user data but will eventually be driven by economic incentives to override them. Her resignation adds to a growing debate over advertising in AI chatbots and raises questions about the long-term implications for users' privacy.

articles.title: Microsoft says hackers are exploiting critical zero-day bugs to target Windows and Office users
articles.summary: Microsoft has released patches for critical security vulnerabilities in Windows and Office, which are being actively exploited by hackers to gain access to users' computers. The exploits are one-click attacks that can bypass Microsoft's SmartScreen feature and allow hackers to plant malware or gain high privileges on the victim's computer. Two of the bugs affect all supported versions of Windows, while another affects Microsoft's proprietary browser engine, MSHTML. Google has confirmed that one of the Windows bugs is under "widespread, active exploitation" and poses a high risk of system compromise. The vulnerabilities were discovered by security researchers in Google's Threat Intelligence Group.

articles.title: Who will own your company’s AI layer? Glean’s CEO explains
articles.summary: Glean's CEO, Arvind Jain, discusses the emerging trend of enterprise AI shifting from chatbots to systems that perform actual work across organizations. As this shift occurs, a key question arises: who will own the AI layer powering these systems? Glean aims to be an "AI work assistant" that sits beneath other AI experiences, connecting to internal systems and delivering intelligence wherever employees work. The startup has raised $150 million at a $7.2 billion valuation, indicating investor interest in its vision. Jain addresses how enterprises are thinking about AI architecture, consolidation, and what's real versus hype in the agent space.

articles.title: Free Tool Says it Can Bypass Discord's Age Verification Check With a 3D Model
articles.summary: A free tool has been released that claims to bypass Discord's age verification system by allowing users to control a 3D model of a computer-generated man in their browser, rather than scanning their real face. This comes after Discord announced it was launching teen-by-default settings globally, requiring more users to verify their age through uploading an identity document or taking a selfie. The tool appears to show that age verification checks may be bypassed, echoing previous reports of kids using photos to circumvent the system in popular VR games like Gorilla Tag.

articles.title: Uber Eats launches AI assistant to help with grocery cart creation
articles.summary: Uber Eats has launched a new AI-powered feature called "Cart Assistant" to help customers quickly and easily fill their grocery carts. The beta version of the chatbot is now available in the Uber Eats app, allowing users to search for a store, tap on the Cart Assistant icon, and enter a list or upload an image of one. The chatbot will then automatically add necessary items to the basket, prioritizing familiar items based on previous orders. This move aims to help Uber Eats compete with other food delivery and grocery apps that have already integrated AI chatbots. The company is rapidly investing in AI, including tools for merchants, such as AI-generated menu descriptions and customer review summaries.

articles.title: Apple’s Siri revamp reportedly delayed… again
articles.summary: Apple's highly anticipated revamp of its digital assistant Siri has been delayed yet again, with the new features now expected to roll out over several months instead of being launched with the upcoming iOS 26.4 update in March. According to a report from Bloomberg, Apple encountered issues during internal testing that pushed back the launch date. The changes aim to make Siri more conversational and AI-powered, similar to large language model (LLM) chatbots like ChatGPT or Claude. This marks the latest delay in a series of setbacks for the new Siri, which was first announced over a year and a half ago. Apple's product managers are likely feeling the pressure as they work to bring this ambitious project to fruition.

articles.title: Peter Mandelson Invokes Press Harassment Protections To Dodge Questions About His Support Of Jeffrey Epstein
articles.summary: Peter Mandelson, a former UK cabinet minister and recently sacked ambassador to the US, has invoked press harassment protections to avoid answering questions about his friendship with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. The move comes after emails revealed the depth of their relationship, which led to Mandelson's dismissal from his post. Mandelson's representatives have sent a confidential notice to UK media outlets, asking them not to contact or photograph him and directing requests for comment to a third party. This action has been criticized as an attempt to use press regulation as a shield against accountability journalism. The move is seen as particularly egregious given the public interest in Mandelson's relationship with Epstein, which included expressing support for challenging the pedophile's conviction.

articles.title: OpenAI disbands mission alignment team
articles.summary: OpenAI has disbanded its mission alignment team, which was formed in 2024 to promote the company's stated mission of ensuring artificial general intelligence benefits all humanity. The team's former leader, Josh Achiam, has been given a new role as OpenAI's "chief futurist," where he will study how the world will change in response to AI and AGI. The rest of the team members have been reassigned to different parts of the company, but it is unclear what specific roles they will be taking on. This move comes after OpenAI previously disbanded its superalignment team in 2024, which focused on studying long-term existential threats posed by AI.

articles.title: Once-hobbled Lumma Stealer is back with lures that are hard to resist
articles.summary: The infostealer Lumma Stealer has made a comeback after being hobbled by law enforcement authorities last year. Researchers have found that Lumma is now "back at scale" with new attacks that use social engineering lures to infect Windows computers. The malware, which was previously sold for up to $2,500 on crime forums, uses a cloud-based model and has been rebuilt after the takedown of its command-and-control infrastructure. Lumma Stealer's resurgence is attributed to its ability to adapt and rebuild its infrastructure quickly. This development raises concerns about the effectiveness of law enforcement efforts in combating cybercrime. The malware's use of social engineering lures, such as fake CAPTCHAs, makes it difficult for users to detect and avoid infection.

articles.title: AI inference startup Modal Labs in talks to raise at $2.5B valuation, sources say
articles.summary: Modal Labs, an AI inference infrastructure startup, is in talks with investors to raise funding at a valuation of around $2.5 billion, more than doubling its previous valuation of $1.1 billion announced just five months ago. The company's annualized revenue run rate (ARR) is approximately $50 million. General Catalyst is reportedly leading the round, although terms are still in discussion and could change. Modal Labs focuses on optimizing inference, a critical process for AI models to generate answers from user requests. The startup is one of several inference-focused companies attracting significant investor attention, with competitors like Baseten and Fireworks AI also raising large sums recently.

articles.title: The Policy Risk Of Closing Off New Paths To Value Too Early
articles.summary: The article discusses how technological advancements, particularly AI, are changing the nature of work and creating new challenges for societies to legitimize certain forms of employment. Historically, societies have adapted to technological change by legitimizing new forms of value, such as paid prayer in medieval England or video essays on theme parks today. This process allows economies to absorb technological change without requiring immediate increases in productivity to be translated into conventional employment. The article argues that this mechanism is essential for economic adjustment and that it has been overlooked in discussions about the impact of AI on work.

articles.title: xAI lays out interplanetary ambitions in public all-hands
articles.summary: xAI, a company acquired by Elon Musk's SpaceX, has made its all-hands meeting video public, revealing new details about its plans and product roadmap. The video shows significant departures of employees, which Musk attributed to a changing organizational structure. xAI is now split into four primary teams focused on the Grok chatbot, app coding system, Imagine video generator, and Macrohard project. Executives also shared revenue figures for X, claiming it has reached $1 billion in annual recurring revenue from subscriptions. Additionally, the video showcased xAI's Imagine tool generating 50 million videos a day and over 6 billion images in 30 days, although some of these figures may include deepfake content. Musk emphasized the importance of space-based data centers, envisioning a moon-based factory for AI satellites that could capture significant portions of the sun's energy output or expand to other galaxies.

articles.title: Dr. Oz: Vaccine Mandates Are Bad. I’ll Just Beg People To Get Vaccinated Instead.
articles.summary: Dr. Oz, Administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, has undergone a change of heart regarding vaccine mandates. Initially opposing mandates, including cheering Florida's decision to drop vaccination requirements for public school children, Dr. Oz is now urging people to get vaccinated against measles in response to a growing outbreak. Despite still not advocating for mandates, Dr. Oz's new stance is seen as inconsistent with his previous views and has raised questions about the credibility of government messaging on public health policy. The shift in Dr. Oz's position comes at a time when measles cases are surging in the US, particularly in South Carolina.

articles.title: Pluralistic: Doctors' union may yet save the NHS from Palantir (12 Feb 2026)
articles.summary: The article discusses how the doctors' union may save the NHS from Palantir, a US military contractor accused of being Trumpist war-criminals. The Labour government's decision to hand over NHS patient records to Palantir is seen as indefensible and has sparked outrage. However, it appears that a proven, advanced, open, safe, British alternative, OpenSAFELY, developed by Ben Goldacre and his team at Jesus College Oxford, was passed up in favor of Palantir's solution. The article highlights the potential risks and consequences of using Palantir's services, particularly given their ties to the Trump regime.

articles.title: Okay, now exactly half of xAI’s founding team has left the company
articles.summary: Two co-founders of xAI, Yuhuai (Tony) Wu and Jimmy Ba, have announced their departure from the company. This brings the total number of founding team members who have left to six in just over a year. The reasons for the departures are unclear, but may be related to the company's struggles with its flagship product, Grok, which has faced issues with bizarre behavior and internal tampering. With an IPO pending, xAI faces intense pressure to deliver on its plans, particularly in the development of AI models. Elon Musk is reportedly spinning up plans for orbital data centers, adding to the pressure on the company.

articles.title: Can India be a “third way” AI alternative to the U.S. and China?
articles.summary: The AI Impact Summit in India aims to give a platform to developing countries, particularly the "Global South", to discuss and shape the future of artificial intelligence (AI). The event is seen as an opportunity for India to establish itself as a major player in the global AI landscape, potentially offering an alternative to the dominance of the US and China. This move comes amidst growing concerns about the concentration of power and data in the hands of a few large tech companies. By hosting the summit, India hopes to promote its own AI ecosystem and create opportunities for innovation and collaboration with other developing countries.

articles.title: Trump DOJ Launches Bunk Investigation Of Netflix Merger As a Favor To Larry Ellison
articles.summary: The Trump Department of Justice (DOJ) has launched an investigation into Netflix's business practices and its planned $82.7 billion merger with Warner Brothers. The DOJ claims it is concerned about media consolidation and monopoly power, but experts believe the real motive is to help Larry Ellison acquire Warner Brothers, CNN, and HBO. This move is part of a broader trend by Trumpism to pretend to support antitrust reform while actually engaging in corruption. The investigation comes after Netflix's merger was repeatedly rejected by the Warner board due to concerns about dodgy financing and Saudi money involvement.

articles.title: Complyance raises $20M to help companies manage risk and compliance
articles.summary: Complyance, a company that helps enterprises manage governance, risk, and compliance (GRC) through AI-powered automation, has raised $20 million in Series A funding led by GV. The app integrates with existing tech stacks to perform custom checks on data against specific criteria and risk thresholds, flagging potential risks for review. This process can take weeks or months when done manually, but Complyance's technology enables continuous checks in seconds. The company has already secured a few Fortune 500 clients and plans to expand its product offerings with 30 new purpose-built agents.

articles.title: Humanoid robot startup Apptronik has now raised $935M at a $5B+ valuation
articles.summary: Apptronik, a University of Texas spinout that builds humanoid robots for Google DeepMind and others, has raised an additional $520 million in its Series A funding round, bringing the total to $935 million. The company's post-money valuation is now around $5.3 billion, more than triple its initial Series A valuation of $1.75 billion. Apptronik plans to use the funds for research and development, as well as expansion into new markets. The company has partnered with Google DeepMind, GXO, and Mercedes-Benz to deliver embodied AI robots that can perceive their environment and take physical action based on reasoning.

articles.title: Meridian raises $17 million to remake the agentic spreadsheet
articles.summary: Meridian, a startup based in New York, has emerged from stealth mode with $17 million in seed funding at a $100 million post-money valuation. The company aims to revolutionize financial modeling and spreadsheets using AI, making them more predictable and auditable. Meridian operates as a standalone workspace, integrating data sources and other references, unlike previous Excel agents that built agents into the spreadsheet software. The company's biggest challenge is meeting the strict requirements of financial clients while navigating the non-deterministic nature of AI models. Meridian's approach combines agentic AI with conventional tooling to minimize hallucinations and provide transparent logic flows.

articles.title: Podcast: Ring Is Back and Scarier Than Ever
articles.summary: The 404 Media podcast discusses the recent launch of Ring's Search Party feature, which allows users to search for specific individuals within their neighborhood. The hosts remind listeners that Ring is a surveillance company that has been criticized for its role in building a "surveillance dragnet" in American communities. They also discuss how the FBI was unable to access a Washington Post reporter's iPhone due to Lockdown Mode being enabled, highlighting the growing concern over personal data security. Additionally, the podcast touches on 404 Media's recent Super Bowl ad purchase and the company's efforts to power independent journalism.

articles.title: Integrate raises $17M to move defense project management into the 21st century
articles.summary: Integrate, a Seattle-based startup founded by John Conafay, has raised $17 million in Series A funding led by FPV Ventures. The company's collaboration platform is designed specifically for classified, multi-entity projects involving government agencies and private companies. Integrate solves the problem of secure project management for government contracts, which was a major hurdle for Conafay during his time at Spire, Astranis, and ABL Space Systems. The startup has already won a $25 million contract from the U.S. Space Force and plans to expand its customer base to other branches of the military and private companies that serve them. Integrate's platform allows different organizations to collaborate securely on massive project schedules while keeping sensitive details hidden from other participants.

articles.title: TikTok launches an opt-in Local Feed in the US leveraging users’ precise location
articles.summary: TikTok has launched an opt-in Local Feed in the US, which displays content related to travel, news, events, shopping, and dining near the user's current location. The feature uses precise location information collected from users, but allows them to control whether or not they share this data. The Local Feed is part of TikTok's push to attract small businesses to its app as advertisers and content producers, which could help insulate it against further regulation. The company claims that the feature will generate real-world traffic and sales for brick-and-mortar stores across the US. However, some users may be concerned about the privacy risks associated with sharing precise location data.

articles.title: Build a pipeline and close deals with an exhibit table at TechCrunch Disrupt 2026
articles.summary: TechCrunch Disrupt 2026 is an upcoming event that will bring together over 10,000 founders, investors, and decision-makers in San Francisco from October 13-15. The event offers a unique opportunity for startups to showcase their innovations and connect with potential customers, investors, and partners through exhibit tables. Exhibiting at Disrupt can drive real growth by providing direct access to buyers and decision-makers, investor proximity, brand credibility, and multi-channel ROI. The event package includes 6' x 30" exhibit table, 10 passes for team members, lead generation via the TechCrunch Disrupt app, and more. Limited exhibit table spaces are available on a first-come, first-served basis.

articles.title: 'The Most Dejected I’ve Ever Felt:' Harassers Made Nude AI Images of Her, Then Started an OnlyFans
articles.summary: Kylie Brewer, a content creator focused on feminism and history, discovered that someone had created an OnlyFans page in her name using AI-generated nude images. The images were created using the Grok image generator, which has been linked to the creation of millions of sexualized images, including 23,000 depicting children. Brewer's case is one of many reported instances of harassment and abuse online, with the perpetrator using AI to create explicit content without her consent. This incident highlights concerns about the regulation of AI and its potential for harm, particularly in cases of non-consensual sexual imagery.

articles.title: Amazon Pharmacy to expand same-day delivery to nearly 4,500 US cities
articles.summary: Amazon Pharmacy is expanding its same-day prescription delivery service to nearly 4,500 US cities and towns by the end of this year, adding over 2,000 new communities to its network. This expansion will cover customers in newly served states such as Idaho and Massachusetts. The move aims to provide faster access to medication for patients across the country, regardless of their location. Amazon Pharmacy launched in 2020 after the acquisition of PillPack, and has since introduced services like RxPass, which offers Prime members generic medications for a $5 monthly fee. With this expansion, Amazon is setting a new standard for accessible and digital-forward pharmacy care.

articles.title: Former Founders Fund VC Sam Blond launches AI sales startup to upend Salesforce
articles.summary: Sam Blond, former VC at Founders Fund, has launched his new startup, Monaco, which offers an AI sales platform that combines artificial intelligence with human expertise. The platform aims to automate sales grunt work for young startups and is currently in public beta after raising $35 million from investors including Founders Fund and Human Capital. Unlike other AI sales startups, Monaco uses experienced human salespeople to monitor and guide the AI's work, ensuring accuracy and effectiveness. The startup is targeting seed and Series A-level companies with its product suite, which includes an AI-native CRM system and a database for finding prospects.

articles.title: Upside Robotics is reducing fertilizer use and waste in corn crops
articles.summary: Upside Robotics, a startup founded in 2024 by Jana Tian and Sam Dugan, has developed lightweight solar-powered autonomous robots that deliver right-sized amounts of fertilizer and nutrients to crops when they need it. The company's software uses proprietary algorithms to decipher when and how much fertilizer the plants need using weather and soil data. Upside Robotics has successfully reduced fertilizer use by 70% in corn crops, resulting in around $150 in savings per acre per season for its customers. With a growing customer base and over 200 farms on their waitlist, the company aims to expand out of Canada and into the US corn belt.

articles.title: Twilio co-founder’s fusion power startup raises $450M from Bessemer and Alphabet’s GV
articles.summary: Inertia Enterprises, a fusion power startup co-founded by Jeff Lawson (Twilio) and Annie Kircher (Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory), has raised $450 million in Series A funding from Bessemer Venture Partners and GV (Alphabet's venture arm). The company aims to build one of the world's most powerful lasers for its grid-scale fusion power plant, which it plans to start constructing in 2030. Inertia's technology is based on the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory's National Ignition Facility, where scientists have achieved controlled fusion reactions that release more energy than they consume. The startup believes its commercial approach can bring down costs and make fusion power a viable source of electricity.

articles.title: Senior engineers, including co-founders, exit xAI amid controversy
articles.summary: At least nine senior engineers, including two co-founders of xAI, have publicly announced their departure from the company in recent weeks. The departures come amid controversy surrounding xAI's flagship product, Grok, which has faced issues with bizarre behavior and internal tampering. Co-founder Yuhai (Tony) Wu and Jimmy Ba are among those who have left, citing a desire for new opportunities and autonomy to build frontier tech more rapidly. The rapid pace of departures has sparked online jokes about a "mass exodus" from xAI, but the exits raise concerns about governance and long-term stability at the company, particularly as it prepares for an IPO.

articles.title: A Mystery Inside Earth’s Core Has Finally Been Solved With a Mind-Boggling Discovery
articles.summary: Scientists have finally solved a decades-long mystery surrounding the density deficit in Earth's core, an unexplained discrepancy between expected and observed densities. A new study published in Nature Communications reveals that vast oceans of hydrogen locked within the core significantly lower its overall density. The research also provides insights into the origins of Earth's liquid water, suggesting that it was largely sourced from the planet's building blocks rather than extraterrestrial sources like comets and asteroids. The study used high-pressure experiments to simulate the extreme environment in the core during Earth's formation billions of years ago. While the estimate has large uncertainties, the findings support a new understanding of Earth's composition and its potential implications for life on our planet.

articles.title: An 18-Million-Subscriber YouTuber Just Explained Section 230 Better Than Every Politician In Washington
articles.summary: A YouTuber with nearly 18 million subscribers, Cr1TiKaL, has created a video explaining Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act better than many politicians and experts. In his 13-minute video, he clarifies that Section 230 shields platforms from liability for user-generated content, placing responsibility on the individual creator. This principle is essential to online discourse and would be catastrophically altered if the law were repealed or gutted. Cr1TiKaL's explanation highlights how Section 230 protects not just tech giants but also smaller platforms, comment sections, and social media posts. His video counters the misconceptions spread by politicians from both parties who aim to control online speech.

articles.title: UpScrolled’s social network is struggling to moderate hate speech after fast growth
articles.summary: UpScrolled, a social network that has gained 2.5 million users since its launch six months ago, is struggling to moderate hate speech on its platform. Despite claims of being inclusive of all voices, the app has been found to host explicit content, including racial slurs and antisemitic posts. The company's founder, Issam Hijazi, acknowledged that users have been uploading "harmful content" and promised to expand the moderation team and upgrade their policies. However, TechCrunch found that some of the reported accounts with hate speech remained online even after reporting them to UpScrolled. The issue highlights the challenges social networks face in balancing free speech with content moderation.

articles.title: How AI changes the math for startups, according to a Microsoft VP
articles.summary: Microsoft's Amanda Silver believes AI is having a profound impact on startups, comparable to the shift to public cloud computing. She notes that agentic AI can reduce software operations costs by automating tasks such as support and legal investigations, leading to more ventures and higher-valuation startups with fewer people at the helm. Silver highlights examples of multi-step agents being used in coding tasks and live site operations, but acknowledges that deployments haven't happened as fast as expected due to a lack of clear business use cases and data for these systems.

articles.title: “Free” Surveillance Tech Still Comes at a High and Dangerous Cost
articles.summary: The article highlights the dangers of "free" surveillance technology provided to local law enforcement by vendors, federal agencies, and private donors. This equipment often bypasses local oversight and can be used for mass surveillance, tracking individuals, and exposing them to harm. The cost of this technology is not measured in tax dollars but rather in the erosion of civil liberties. Cities are advised to reject federal grants, vendor trials, and donations that facilitate surveillance and experimentation with spy tech, and to implement clear policies and oversight mechanisms before using any surveillance tools.

articles.title: Speaking Freely: Yazan Badran
articles.summary: Yazan Badran, an assistant professor at Vrije Universiteit Brussel, discusses his views on free speech and expression in a conversation with Jillian York of EFF. He emphasizes that free speech is not just the absence of constraints but also requires frameworks that enable people to express themselves and be listened to by others. Badran draws from his experiences in the Arab uprisings, research on exiled journalists, and academic work to highlight the importance of mutual responsibility and recognition in fostering a culture of free expression. He argues that platforms, journalism, and education should prioritize both enabling expression and fostering listening.

articles.title: Sen. Blackburn Gets Shitty Because Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson Attended An Awards Show Where ICE Was Criticized
articles.summary: Sen. Marsha Blackburn (R-Tenn) has called for an investigation into Supreme Court Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson's attendance at the Grammy Awards, where artists criticized Trump's anti-migrant actions and ICE. However, Jackson was a nominee in the Best Audio Book category and attended the event solely to support her own work, not to participate in the criticism of ICE. Despite this, Blackburn claims that Jackson's presence raises ethical questions about her impartiality as a Supreme Court justice.

articles.title: Marc Benioff 'Jokes' ICE Is Watching Salesforce Employees Who Traveled to the U.S.
articles.summary: Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff made a joke during an all-hands meeting in Las Vegas, stating that Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents were present to keep tabs on international employees who had traveled to the US for the event. The comment sparked outrage among employees, with many expressing shock and disappointment on internal Slack channels. This incident comes amidst controversy over Salesforce's contracts with ICE, which have been criticized within the company. Employees are calling out Benioff's lack of understanding of why his joke was problematic, citing the harm caused by ICE's actions against immigrant communities. The incident has sparked a wider discussion about accountability and empathy among tech leaders.

articles.title: Facebook adds new AI features, animated profile photos, and backgrounds for text posts
articles.summary: Facebook has introduced several AI-powered features aimed at enhancing user expression and personalization across its platform. The updates include animated profile pictures, photo-restyling tools for Stories and Memories, and the ability to add animated backgrounds to text posts. These features are part of Facebook's efforts to maintain relevance among younger users on its flagship app, particularly Gen Z. With around 2.1 billion daily active users, Facebook is attempting to revamp its platform with new technology, including AI, and introduce a more youthful redesign. The company plans to add more animation options throughout the year and will also roll out seasonal backgrounds for text posts.

articles.title: Here’s how Rivian changed the rear door manual release on the R2
articles.summary: Rivian has made changes to the rear door manual release on its upcoming R2 SUV, moving it from a hidden location behind a panel to a more accessible spot near the front of the interior handle. This change is part of a broader trend among carmakers to address concerns about electronic door handles and their potential safety risks. Rivian's design still requires passengers to remove a piece of plastic to access the manual release, but it is now in a more logical location than before. The move comes as other companies, including Tesla, have faced criticism for making manual releases too difficult to find and access during emergencies.

articles.title: Daily Deal: Nix Mini 3 Color Sensor
articles.summary: The Nix Mini 3 Color Sensor, a portable device for color matching and management, is currently on sale for $69.97 through the Techdirt Deals Store. This device allows users to access over 200,000 brand-name paint colors and essential color codes like RGB, HEX, and CMYK. The Mini 3 features Bluetooth connectivity, debris resistance, and improved accuracy with 3x enhanced resolution compared to its predecessor. It also offers free access to the Nix Toolkit app for precise and convenient color matching. This deal is part of the Techdirt Deals Store, which helps support Techdirt through sales.

articles.title: How To Think About AI: Is It The Tool, Or Are You?
articles.summary: The article discusses the author's perspective on Artificial Intelligence (AI) and its potential impact on society. The author argues that AI can be a powerful tool when used thoughtfully by humans to enhance their knowledge and creativity, but it tends to fail when used as a replacement for human input and thinking. This is illustrated through an analogy of "centaurs" and "reverse centaurs," where the former refers to humans assisted by machines, while the latter refers to machines controlling humans. The author believes that most attempts to build AI-powered systems that replace human workers will fail due to the lack of human knowledge and creativity in these systems.

articles.title: Google sent personal and financial information of student journalist to ICE
articles.summary: Google provided U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) with the personal data of Amandla Thomas-Johnson, a British student and journalist, in response to an administrative subpoena that had not been approved by a judge. The data included usernames, physical addresses, IP addresses, phone numbers, credit card and bank account information, and more. This is part of a larger trend where the U.S. government uses administrative subpoenas to demand personal data from tech companies without judicial oversight. Tech companies are under no obligation to comply with these requests, but many do so anyway. The Electronic Frontier Foundation has called on companies to resist such demands and protect user privacy.

articles.title: VC Masha Bucher, Epstein associate and Day One founder, explains herself
articles.summary: Masha Bucher, a prominent Silicon Valley venture capitalist and founder of Day One Ventures, has addressed recent reports detailing her close relationship with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. According to the documents, Bucher worked as Epstein's publicist in 2017, helping him rehabilitate his reputation after his conviction. The files also show that Epstein supported and encouraged Bucher in the early days of her venture capital firm, which has since grown substantially. Bucher apologized for her involvement with Epstein, citing naivety and a desire to feel safe from threats associated with her home country, Russia. She has since denounced Putin and met with some of Epstein's victims.

articles.title: No One, Including Our Furry Friends, Will Be Safer in Ring's Surveillance Nightmare
articles.summary: Amazon Ring's Super Bowl ad showcased a vision of widespread surveillance, where its doorbell cameras could identify and track individuals, pets, and objects using AI analysis. The "Search Party" feature allows users to scan footage across multiple devices in a neighborhood, raising concerns about biometric identification and data collection. This is not the first time Ring has faced criticism for its handling of user data and collaboration with law enforcement. The company has a history of privacy violations, enabling surveillance of innocents and protesters, and has made law enforcement access a regular part of its business. Users can disable the "Search Party" feature by following specific steps in the app.

articles.title: Boston Dynamics CEO Robert Playter steps down after 30 years at the company
articles.summary: Boston Dynamics CEO Robert Playter is stepping down after 30 years with the company, where he held various roles including vice president of engineering and chief operating officer. Playter took over as CEO in 2020 and led the company's transformation into a successful business under its current owner Hyundai. Amanda McMaster, the CFO, will serve as interim CEO while the company searches for a replacement. Boston Dynamics is known for its quadruped robot Spot and humanoid robot Atlas. The leadership change comes after Playter's significant contributions to the robotics industry, including pioneering innovation in mobile robotics.

articles.title: Techdirt Podcast Episode 443: The Supreme Court’s Internet Cases
articles.summary: The Supreme Court has been increasingly involved in internet-related cases, which are having a significant impact on how the internet functions. This week's episode of the Techdirt Podcast explores this trend with guest Cathy Gellis discussing the past, present, and future of SCOTUS and the internet. The discussion covers various aspects of online speech, content moderation, and user agency, highlighting the complexities and implications of these cases. As the Supreme Court continues to address internet-related issues, it's likely that its decisions will shape the future of online interactions. The podcast provides a comprehensive analysis of these developments, encouraging listeners to think critically about their impact.

articles.title: RFK Jr's Nutrition Chatbot Recommends Best Foods to Insert Into Your Rectum
articles.summary: The Department of Health and Human Services has launched an AI nutrition chatbot, "Grok," which provides recommendations for foods to insert into one's rectum. The chatbot suggests foods such as bananas, cucumbers, and zucchinis, with detailed instructions on how to prepare them for insertion. This advice is not only absurd but also potentially hazardous. The chatbot was created by Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who has been criticized for his anti-science stance on food policy. The launch of this chatbot raises concerns about the federal government's priorities and its willingness to promote misinformation.

articles.title: An ice dance duo skated to AI music at the Olympics
articles.summary: Czech ice dancers Kateřina Mrázková and Daniel Mrázek made their Olympic debut using AI-generated music in their rhythm dance program. The music choice has sparked controversy, with some accusing the duo of plagiarism for incorporating copyrighted lyrics into their routine. This is not the first time the siblings have faced backlash for using AI-generated music, having previously used a song that included lyrics from New Radicals' "You Get What You Give." The International Skating Union and Olympic officials have confirmed that the use of AI-generated music does not break any official rules.

articles.title: Border Patrol Thug Greg Bovino Bitched About Being Asked To Be A Bit More Lawful Before Being Turfed To California
articles.summary: Border Patrol commander Greg Bovino has been sent back to his patrol area near the US-Mexico border after being removed from high-profile surges in Chicago and Minneapolis due to his insubordination and brutal tactics. Bovino had become a public face of the Trump administration's efforts to purge non-white people from the country, but his actions have sparked widespread criticism and court orders restraining his activities. The decision to send him back to the border is seen as a move by the Trump administration to distance itself from Bovino's behavior, which has lost the "hearts and minds" battle with most US citizens and residents.

articles.title: Amazon may launch a marketplace where media sites can sell their content to AI companies
articles.summary: Amazon is reportedly considering launching a marketplace where media sites can license their content to AI companies, addressing the issue of copyrighted material in AI training data. This move follows Microsoft's launch of its Publisher Content Marketplace (PCM) and OpenAI's partnerships with major news outlets. The AI industry has faced lawsuits over copyright infringement, and regulatory strategies are being proposed to deal with the issue. Media publishers have also expressed concerns about AI summaries depressing traffic to their sites. Amazon's potential marketplace could provide a more sustainable business model for publishers as AI usage continues to escalate.

articles.title: Okay, now exactly half of xAI’s founding team has left the company
articles.summary: xAI, a company founded by Elon Musk to develop artificial intelligence (AI) technologies, has seen six members of its 12-person founding team leave the company in the past year. The latest departures include co-founders Yuhuai (Tony) Wu and Jimmy Ba, who announced their exits on social media platforms X. This follows previous departures of key researchers, including Kyle Kosic, Christian Szegedy, Igor Babuschkin, and Greg Yang. The reasons for the departures are unclear, but may be related to the company's struggles with its flagship product, Grok, which has faced issues with bizarre behavior and internal tampering. With an IPO pending, xAI faces intense pressure to deliver on its plans, particularly in the development of AI models.

articles.title: OpenAI policy exec who opposed chatbot’s “adult mode” reportedly fired on discrimination claim
articles.summary: Ryan Beiermeister, OpenAI's former vice president of product policy, has been fired after a male colleague accused her of sex discrimination. The alleged incident occurred in January, shortly before she expressed criticism of the company's planned "adult mode" feature, which would introduce erotica into the ChatGPT user experience. Beiermeister denies the allegations and claims they are false. OpenAI maintains that her departure was not related to any issue she raised while working at the company. The incident highlights concerns about the impact of AI-powered chatbots on users, particularly in relation to sensitive topics like adult content.

articles.title: So, You’ve Hit An Age Gate. What Now?
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) is against age gating and verification mandates, citing concerns about sensitive data leakage and privacy risks. Despite existing mandates, many people are still being asked to verify their age online, with some platforms using facial age estimation solutions that can be inaccurate for marginalized users. The EFF provides a guide on how to navigate age verification options, recommending the least amount of data submission possible and considering questions such as data access, retention, audits, visibility, and tools used by each platform.

articles.title: With co-founders leaving and an IPO looming, Elon Musk turns talk to the moon
articles.summary: Elon Musk held an all-hands meeting with xAI employees on Tuesday night, where he discussed the company's future and its need for a lunar manufacturing facility. Musk believes that building AI satellites in space will give xAI a significant advantage over competitors. However, the plan raises questions about how to build such a facility and how it fits into the company's merger with SpaceX, which is reportedly targeting a $1.5 trillion valuation through an IPO this summer. The meeting comes as two co-founders of xAI have recently left the company, bringing the total number of departed founding members to six.

articles.title: Samsung to hold its Galaxy S26 event on February 25
articles.summary: Samsung has announced its Galaxy Unpacked event for February 25 in San Francisco, where it will unveil its Galaxy S26 series of smartphones. The new phones are expected to feature AI-powered capabilities and a privacy display that can hide sensitive information from onlookers. Other rumored features include a 5,100mAh battery, 60W wired charging, and 25W wireless charging. Samsung is also likely to release updated Galaxy Buds 4 wireless earbuds with a new design. The event will be streamed live on Samsung's website and YouTube channel.

articles.title: Google backs African push to reclaim AI language data
articles.summary: Google has partnered with the African Union and other organizations to launch a project aimed at collecting and preserving African languages' data for AI models. The initiative seeks to address the lack of representation of African languages in AI systems, which often rely on Western language datasets. Google will provide technical support and resources to help collect and annotate African language data, while the African Union will coordinate efforts across the continent. This project has significant implications for promoting digital inclusion and linguistic diversity in Africa.

articles.title: Pluralistic: Europe takes a big step towards a post-dollar world (11 Feb 2026)
articles.summary: Europe has taken a significant step towards creating a post-dollar world by launching a digital euro and establishing a European Payments Initiative (EPI). This move aims to reduce reliance on the US dollar for international transactions and promote financial sovereignty. The EPI will allow Europeans to make payments without using Visa or Mastercard, recapturing $24 trillion worth of transactions from these companies. This development is seen as a response to the dangers of enshittification, where powerful platforms like America's fiber networks or the US dollar are used for surveillance and disruption.

articles.title: Immigrant women founders face double hurdle in Silicon Valley
articles.summary: Sri Ramaswamy, an immigrant woman founder of an AI-powered insurance claims startup, faced a double hurdle in Silicon Valley - being a woman and an immigrant. She encountered biases and stereotypes during pitches to venture capitalists, who often focused on her background rather than the product itself. This experience is not unique to Ramaswamy; many immigrant women founders face similar challenges in the tech industry. The article highlights the need for greater diversity and inclusion in Silicon Valley's startup ecosystem.

articles.title: YouTube rolls out an AI playlist generator for Premium users
articles.summary: YouTube has rolled out an AI-powered playlist generator for Premium users, allowing them to create playlists using text prompts. This feature is available on both iOS and Android devices and can be accessed by tapping the "New" button in the Library tab of YouTube Music. Users can enter a prompt, such as a genre or mood, and receive a personalized playlist. This move follows similar developments from rival streaming services like Spotify, Amazon Music, and Deezer, which have also introduced AI-powered playlist creation features. The feature is part of YouTube's efforts to make its Premium plan more attractive to users, following the company's recent restriction on free users viewing song lyrics.

articles.title: Brendan Carr Launches Fake Investigation Of ABC’s ‘The View’ Because They Haven’t Adequately Coddled Trumpism
articles.summary: FCC boss Brendan Carr has launched a fake investigation into ABC's "The View" for allegedly violating equal time rules by not adequately coddling right-wing ideology. The rule in question is a dated relic that would be difficult to enforce, and Carr's office is likely the source of the Reuters report announcing the investigation. This move is seen as an attempt to intimidate media companies into providing more favorable coverage to Republicans. Anna Gomez, the FCC's lone Democrat Commissioner, has criticized the move as "government intimidation" rather than a legitimate investigation.

articles.title: Primary Ventures raises healthy $625M Fund V to focus on seed investing
articles.summary: Primary Ventures has closed a $625 million Fund V focused on seed investing nationwide, with an average check size of $7.5 million. The fund will invest in 40-50 companies over three years and will go as early as pre-seed. This is the firm's largest fund to date, reflecting the increasing size of early-stage rounds in the age of AI. Primary Ventures aims to compete with other firms for top deals by bringing more resources to the table. The firm has already invested in three companies from Fund V and has $1.65 billion in assets under management.

articles.title: Proptech startup Smart Bricks raises $5 million pre-seed led by a16z
articles.summary: Smart Bricks, an AI-powered proptech startup, has raised $5 million in pre-seed funding led by Andreessen Horowitz. The company's platform analyzes millions of data points to help investors find high-quality real estate investments and automate the transaction workflow. Founded by Mohamed Mohamed, a former executive at BlackRock and Goldman Sachs, Smart Bricks aims to bring modern intelligence stacks to the real estate industry, making it more efficient and transparent. The funding will be used to expand the product's infrastructure into additional markets and advance its technology. This development comes as part of the growing trend in AI-powered proptech, with other companies like reAlpha and RoofStock also operating in this space.

articles.title: AI video startup Runway raises $315M at $5.3B valuation, eyes more capable world models
articles.summary: Runway, an AI video generation startup, has raised $315 million in a Series E funding round, nearly doubling its valuation to $5.3 billion. The company plans to use the funds to pre-train the next generation of world models, which are AI systems that construct internal representations of an environment for future planning. Runway's shift towards world models comes amid increasing competition from other labs pursuing similar technology. The startup has seen significant adoption in media, entertainment, and advertising, but is now expanding into gaming and robotics. Its latest video generation model, Gen 4.5, has earned the company credibility within the AI industry.

articles.title: Spotify hits a record 751M monthly users thanks to Wrapped, new free features
articles.summary: Spotify has reached a record 751 million monthly active users, driven by its "Wrapped" campaign and new features on its free tier. The company saw a 38 million increase in new users in the fourth quarter, with paying subscribers increasing by 10% to 290 million. Revenue came in at €4.53 billion ($5.39 billion), a 7% increase from last year, thanks to an 8% rise in subscription revenue. Spotify's gross margin improved by 83 basis points to a record high of 33.1%. The company has expanded its offerings beyond music streaming to include podcasts, audiobooks, and physical bookstores.

articles.title: Former GitHub CEO raises record $60M dev tool seed round at $300M valuation
articles.summary: Former GitHub CEO Thomas Dohmke has raised $60 million for his new startup Entire at a valuation of $300 million, the largest-ever seed round for a dev tool startup. Entire offers an open-source tool to help developers manage code written by AI agents, addressing the issue of large volumes of software created by AI coding agents that may be poorly designed or unusable. The company's technology has three components: a git-compatible database, a universal semantic reasoning layer, and an AI-native user interface. Entire's first product is Checkpoints, which automatically pairs AI-generated code with context. This development highlights the growing need for tools to manage the output of AI coding agents.

articles.title: India orders social media platforms to take down deepfakes faster
articles.summary: India has introduced new regulations requiring social media platforms to step up policing of deepfakes and other AI-generated impersonations. The rules, which were published as amendments to the 2021 IT Rules, mandate the labelling and traceability of synthetic audio and visual content, while also slashing compliance timelines for platforms. Platforms are now required to remove content within three hours of receiving a takedown order or two hours for urgent user complaints. The regulations aim to curb the spread of child sexual abuse material and deceptive content, but critics argue that they risk accelerating censorship by compressing takedown timelines.

articles.title: Hauler Hero collects $16M for its AI waste management software
articles.summary: Hauler Hero, a New York-based startup, has raised $16 million in a Series A funding round led by Frontier Growth, with participation from K5 Global and Somersault Ventures. The company's AI-powered waste management software aims to bring modernity to the industry, which was previously plagued by outdated systems. Hauler Hero has facilitated 35 million trash pickups since its inception in 2020 and continues to grow, doubling its headcount, revenue, and customer base since its seed round. The company is now developing three AI agents to enhance its platform's capabilities, including automatically identifying service issues and revenue opportunities.

articles.title: With Ring, American Consumers Built a Surveillance Dragnet
articles.summary: Ring's Super Bowl ad promoted its "Search Party" feature, which uses AI to search for lost dogs across neighborhood cameras. This raises concerns about the potential misuse of this technology for surveillance and control. The company has a history of partnering with law enforcement and creating a culture of fear among users through its "Neighbors" app. Despite scaling back police partnerships in recent years, Ring remains a critical part of the expanding surveillance state. Experts warn that features like Search Party can be easily repurposed for more sinister uses, such as tracking suspected criminals or undocumented immigrants.

articles.title: YouTubers aren’t relying on ad revenue anymore — here’s how some are diversifying
articles.summary: YouTubers are diversifying their income streams beyond ad revenue, driven by its unpredictability. Many creators have turned to building parallel businesses, such as product lines, brick-and-mortar ventures, and consumer brands that can outlast algorithm changes and policy shifts. Notable examples include MrBeast's theme park, telecommunications venture, and banking app acquisition, as well as Emma Chamberlain's coffee brand. These side businesses are growing faster and more sustainably than their YouTube channels in some cases.

articles.title: Trump EPA reportedly seeks to revoke landmark air pollution rule
articles.summary: The Trump EPA is reportedly seeking to revoke a landmark air pollution rule, known as the "endangerment finding," which was established in 2009 and found that greenhouse gases pose a threat to human health and welfare. The move would effectively repeal federal regulations on six greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide and methane, and could be implemented as early as this week. The decision is likely to attract lawsuits and may take years to resolve. Automakers, particularly those relying on fossil fuel-powered trucks, are facing significant challenges due to the potential regulatory whiplash in the US. Climate change experts warn that the move would put the US out of step with other advanced economies and could have devastating consequences for the environment.

articles.title: Google expands tools to let users remove sensitive data about themselves from Search
articles.summary: Google has announced updates to its "Results about you" tool and non-consensual explicit image removal tools as part of Safer Internet Day. The updated tool now allows users to remove Search results containing personal contact information, such as driver's licenses, passports, or Social Security numbers. Users can access the tool in the Google app by tapping their account photo and selecting "Results about you." Additionally, Google has made it easier for users to request the removal of non-consensual explicit images on Search, allowing them to select and submit requests for multiple images at once.

articles.title: What to know about Netflix’s landmark acquisition of Warner Bros.
articles.summary: Netflix has acquired Warner Bros. in a historic deal valued at $82.7 billion, bringing together iconic franchises such as Game of Thrones and Harry Potter under one roof. The acquisition marks a significant shift in the streaming landscape, with industry observers predicting it will disrupt Hollywood as we know it. Despite Paramount's initial bid and subsequent attempts to acquire Warner Bros., Netflix emerged as the preferred buyer after revising its offer to an all-cash deal. Regulatory scrutiny remains a challenge for the transaction, with Netflix co-CEO Ted Sarandos set to testify in a Senate hearing on the matter.

articles.title: Vega raises $120M Series B to rethink how enterprises detect cyber threats
articles.summary: Vega Security, a two-year-old AI cybersecurity startup, has raised $120 million in Series B funding to scale its vision of running security operations where data already lives, rather than storing it all in one place. This approach aims to address the limitations of legacy tools like Splunk, which require companies to store and process vast amounts of security data before detecting threats. Vega's AI-native security operations suite is designed to be cost-effective, scalable, and easy to adopt for large enterprises. The funding round nearly doubles Vega's valuation to $700 million and brings its total funding to $185 million.

articles.title: Singapore says China-backed hackers targeted its four largest phone companies
articles.summary: The Singapore government has accused a Chinese cyber-espionage group, known as UNC3886, of targeting four of its top telecommunication companies, including Singtel, StarHub, M1, and Simba Telecom, over several months. The hackers were able to breach some systems but did not disrupt services or access personal information. Google-owned cybersecurity unit Mandiant has previously linked UNC3886 to China, which is known for conducting regular cyber-espionage operations. The attack follows similar incidents on hundreds of telecoms companies worldwide, including those attributed to a China-backed group called Salt Typhoon. Singapore's government has launched a multi-agency operation to counter the threat posed by UNC3886.

articles.title: Former Tesla product manager wants to make luxury goods impossible to fake, starting with a chip
articles.summary: Luci Holland, a former Tesla product manager and founder of Veritas, aims to combat luxury goods counterfeiting with a "hack-proof" chip that combines custom hardware and software. The chip, linked with digital certificates, verifies the authenticity of products and can't be bypassed by hacking tools like Flipper Zero. Veritas has partnered with designers to create a minimally disruptive chip that can be inserted into products without compromising their integrity. The startup plans to educate the market about the need for robust tech solutions to combat counterfeiting.

articles.title: Hey Rep. Gonzales, Finish The Thought: What About That Five-Year-Old US Citizen?
articles.summary: Republican Rep. Tony Gonzales of Texas made a statement on Face the Nation, defending the deportation of Liam Ramos, a 5-year-old US citizen who was detained at a family facility in his district. Gonzales stated that he understands why people are concerned about Ramos' situation, but then mentioned a hypothetical 5-year-old US citizen, asking "what about that five-year-old U.S. citizen?" without completing the thought. The statement has sparked confusion and criticism, with many questioning what scenario or process could harm a US citizen child in relation to Liam Ramos' asylum case. Gonzales' comment has been widely criticized as insensitive and nonsensical.

articles.title: Coalition Urges California to Revoke Permits for Federal License Plate Reader Surveillance
articles.summary: A coalition of organizations, led by the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) and Imperial Valley Equity & Justice, has urged California Governor Gavin Newsom to revoke permits allowing federal agencies such as Customs and Border Patrol (CBP) and the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) to install automated license plate readers (ALPRs) along border highways. The coalition argues that this invasive mass surveillance puts residents and migrants at risk of harassment, abuse, detention, and deportation. The letter to Governor Newsom and Caltrans Director Dina El-Tawansy notes the urgent need for action, citing the return of U.S. Border Patrol Chief Greg Bovino to the El Centro sector, which has been associated with a brutal campaign against immigrants and U.S. citizens. The coalition includes various organizations, including the California Nurses Association, ACLU California Action, and Project on Government Oversight.

articles.title: Open Letter to Tech Companies: Protect Your Users From Lawless DHS Subpoenas
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) and the ACLU of Northern California have sent an open letter to tech companies, urging them to resist the Department of Homeland Security's (DHS) lawless administrative subpoenas for user data. The DHS has issued subpoenas to target individuals engaged in First Amendment activity, including those who have documented ICE's activities or criticized the government. These subpoenas are unlawful and the government knows it, as evidenced by DHS withdrawing some subpoenas when challenged in court. Tech companies can protect their users by insisting on court intervention before complying with a subpoena, giving users notice of a subpoena, and resisting gag orders that prevent notification.

articles.title: Hacked, leaked, exposed: Why you should never use stalkerware apps
articles.summary: The article highlights the growing problem of stalkerware companies being hacked or leaking customer data, exposing sensitive information about millions of people. At least 27 stalkerware companies have been affected since 2017, with some experiencing multiple breaches. The latest incident involves uMobix and associated apps, which had over 500,000 customers' payment records leaked online. Hacktivists have targeted these companies in recent years to expose their activities and raise awareness about the dangers of stalkerware. Experts warn that using such apps is not only irresponsible but also potentially illegal, as they often encourage abusive behavior.

articles.title: Lyft opens its ride-hailing app to teens
articles.summary: Lyft has launched a new feature allowing minors as young as 13 to hail rides without an adult in over 200 US cities. The service, called Lyft Teen, requires parents or guardians to create the account and comes with guardrails such as PIN verification, audio recording, and real-time tracking. This move follows Uber's introduction of similar teen accounts in 2024 and Waymo's robotaxi service for teens in Phoenix. Lyft is playing catch-up in this space but has also made significant expansions in autonomous vehicle partnerships and European market entry.

articles.title: Workday CEO Eschenbach departs, with co-founder Aneel Bhusri returning as CEO
articles.summary: Workday CEO Carl Eschenbach has stepped down from his position, effective immediately, and will leave the company's board. Co-founder Aneel Bhusri is returning as CEO, marking a permanent return to the role after serving as executive chairman since 2024. The leadership change comes as Workday focuses on its next chapter, which is centered around artificial intelligence (AI). Bhusri expressed enthusiasm for the opportunity ahead, citing AI's potential to define the next generation of market leaders. This move follows a significant layoff in February 2025, where Workday cut nearly 2,000 employees, or 8.5% of its headcount, as Eschenbach emphasized the need for a new approach to labor in the age of AI.

articles.title: Harvey reportedly raising at $11B valuation just months after it hit $8B
articles.summary: Harvey, a legal AI startup, is reportedly in talks to raise an additional $200 million at a valuation of $11 billion, led by Sequoia and Singapore's GIC. This would be a significant increase from its previous valuation of $8 billion just months ago, when it raised $160 million in December 2025. The company has seen rapid growth, with annual recurring revenue reaching $190 million by the end of 2025, nearly double its contracted revenue in less than six months. Harvey's success is attributed to its LLM AI for law firms and its ability to attract top venture capital investors. This latest development suggests that Harvey is becoming one of the breakout winners in the AI enterprise applications space.

articles.title: Daily Deal: AdGuard Personal or Family Plan
articles.summary: The article promotes a deal on AdGuard Personal or Family plans, an ad blocker software that offers advanced features such as ad-blocking, privacy protection, and parental control. The software is available for Windows, Android, macOS, and iOS devices. A personal plan is on sale for $11, while a family plan is on sale for $15.97 (available only to new users). This deal is part of the Techdirt Deals Store, which helps support the website through sales.

articles.title: So, what’s going on with Musicboard?
articles.summary: Musicboard, a music discovery and recommendation app, has been experiencing technical issues, including outages, website downtime, and removal from the Play Store. Despite having a small but devoted user base, the company has not provided any official communication or explanation for the problems. Users have taken matters into their own hands by organizing an unofficial "Help Save Musicboard" initiative to raise awareness about the issue. The app's founders, Johannes Vermandois and Erik Heimer, are also involved with other projects, including an AI app called Frank AI. TechCrunch reached out to Musicboard for comment but was provided a brief statement that dismissed the issues as temporary downtime.

articles.title: RIP Dave Farber, EFF Board Member and Friend
articles.summary: Dave Farber, a 91-year-old longtime Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) Board member, has passed away. Known as the "Grandfather of the Internet," Farber made significant contributions to the internet's development and was a steadfast advocate for protecting users' rights and liberties online. He joined the EFF board in the early 1990s, before the widespread adoption of the internet, and remained a consistent presence throughout the organization's growth. Farber's expertise on internet technologies and his commitment to promoting civil liberties will be deeply missed by the EFF community.

articles.title: Section 230 Turns 30; Both Parties Want It Gone—For Contradictory Reasons
articles.summary: The 30th anniversary of Section 230, a law that shields websites from liability for third-party content, has sparked a bipartisan effort to repeal or reform it. Critics on both sides argue that the law allows tech companies to censor conservative speech (Republicans) or host disinformation (Democrats). However, this criticism is contradictory and misses the law's actual purpose: to protect online platforms from liability for user-generated content. Without Section 230, smaller platforms would be disproportionately affected by lawsuits, leading to their demise and further consolidating market power among tech giants. The real goal of critics is not responsibility or safety but control over online speech.

articles.title: On Its 30th Birthday, Section 230 Remains The Lynchpin For Users’ Speech
articles.summary: Section 230 of the Telecommunications Act of 1996, a law shielding websites from liability for third-party content, celebrates its 30th anniversary this week. Despite controversy over its protection of tech companies, Section 230 remains essential to online discourse and has been instrumental in shaping the internet, economy, government, and society. However, bipartisan proposals in Congress aim to repeal or sunset the law, citing concerns about big tech's practices. Critics argue that rolling back Section 230 would not address these issues but rather cement the dominance of large tech companies and lead to more censorship of lawful speech. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) defends Section 230 as the best available system to protect users' speech online.

articles.title: The Screen Time Panic Sets Parents Up to Fail
articles.summary: The article discusses how parents are often left feeling unprepared to manage their children's screen time, despite a wealth of information available on the topic. The author reflects on their own experience as a parent and notes that there is a lack of practical advice for applying research on screen time in real-world parenting situations. To address this gap, the podcast features an interview with Patrick Klepek, a writer and parent who has reported on video games and parenting issues.

articles.title: On Section 230’s 30th Birthday, A Look Back At Why It’s Such A Good Law And Why Messing With It Would Be Bad
articles.summary: Section 230, a law that shields websites from liability for third-party content, is celebrating its 30th anniversary. Despite being misunderstood and criticized in recent years, the law has enabled online discourse and reshaped the internet, economy, government, and society.
