While the effectiveness of this supervisory model remains uncertain, both companies are betting on its potential, with Anthropic's Claude Opus 4.6 and OpenAI's Frontier being the latest examples. These products aim to enable developers to spin up multiple AI agents that can work together on tasks, but their reliability and performance in practice have yet to be confirmed.

articles.title: AWS revenue continues to soar as cloud demand remains high
articles.summary: Amazon Web Services (AWS) reported its strongest quarterly growth rate in over three years, with a 24% year-on-year increase in revenue to $35.6 billion in the fourth quarter of 2025. This growth was driven by new agreements with major companies and government entities, as well as increased demand for cloud services from enterprises and startups. AWS's success is attributed to its top-to-bottom AI stack functionality and its ability to provide easy-to-core computing capacity. The company's annual revenue run rate is now $142 billion, making it a significant contributor to Amazon's overall revenue. Despite this growth, Amazon shares fell 10% in after-hours trading due to concerns about increased capital expenditures and missed earnings per share expectations.

articles.title: Reddit looks to AI search as its next big opportunity
articles.summary: Reddit is exploring the potential of AI-powered search as a key growth area, with CEO Steve Huffman highlighting its ability to provide multiple perspectives on complex queries. The company has seen significant growth in weekly active users for its AI-powered Reddit Answers feature, which now reaches 15 million users. Reddit plans to integrate its traditional and AI search engines, making it more relevant to logged-out users and personalizing the experience with AI and machine learning. The company's content licensing business, which allows other companies to train their AI models on Reddit's data, is also growing rapidly.

articles.title: Sapiom raises $15M to help AI agents buy their own tech tools
articles.summary: Sapiom, a San Francisco-based startup, has raised $15 million in seed funding to develop a payment system that allows AI agents to securely purchase and access software, APIs, data, and compute services without human intervention. The company's goal is to make it seamless for AI agents to buy the services they need, eliminating the need for manual authentication and micro-payments. Sapiom's technology has the potential to be adopted by vibe-coding companies and other businesses creating AI agents that will perform various tasks independently. Accel led the funding round with participation from several prominent venture capital firms. The startup is currently focused on B2B solutions, but its technology could eventually empower personal AI agents to handle consumer transactions.

articles.title: Ctrl-Alt-Speech: C’est La Vile Content
articles.summary: The latest episode of the Ctrl-Alt-Speech podcast covers various news stories related to online speech, content moderation, and internet regulation. The hosts discuss a report from the House Judiciary Committee exposing the European Commission's decade-long campaign to censor American speech on social media platforms. Other topics include the raiding of X offices in France, a potential ban on social media for children under 16 in Spain, and a shift towards taking comments seriously again in newsrooms. The hosts also touch on the moderation practices of TikTok and the consequences of killing comment sections on websites.

articles.title: NIH Boss Jay Bhattacharya Breaks With RFK Jr. On Vaccines
articles.summary: Jay Bhattacharya, the director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH), has publicly broken with Robert F. Kennedy Jr. on vaccines, stating that he believes in their safety and effectiveness. This stance contradicts Kennedy's views, which have led him to fire several people who disagreed with his claims about vaccines causing autism and other harm. Bhattacharya's comments were made during a Senate Committee hearing, where he was asked directly if vaccines cause autism and replied "no." His statements are seen as a departure from the views of Kennedy, who has been critical of vaccine policies and schedules.

articles.title: Pluralistic: Luxury Kafka (06 Feb 2026)
articles.summary: The article "Luxury Kafka" by Cory Doctorow critiques the US immigration system, highlighting its complexity and inaccessibility to most people. The author, who has gone through the process himself, notes that Americans often have no idea how their own immigration system works, leading to frustration and xenophobia. He argues that the current system is designed to favor those with resources and connections, making it difficult for ordinary people to navigate. Doctorow emphasizes that even he, as a relatively affluent individual, found the process daunting and stressful.

articles.title: China is running the EV playbook on humanoid robots — and it’s working
articles.summary: China has been quietly making significant strides in developing and deploying humanoid robots, with nearly 90% of global sales in 2025 attributed to Chinese companies. This contrasts with Silicon Valley's focus on marketing and hype surrounding the technology. China's approach has allowed it to gain a substantial lead in the field, with many of its robots being used in various industries such as manufacturing, healthcare, and logistics. The country's emphasis on practical applications and large-scale deployment is paying off, with Chinese companies now dominating the global market for humanoid robots. This development highlights the importance of focusing on substance over marketing and hype when it comes to emerging technologies.

articles.title: China prioritizes investments outside the U.S.
articles.summary: China's foreign direct investment strategy has shifted, with only 2.6% of its investments going to North America in 2025. This marks a significant decline from previous years and reflects China's growing distrust of the West. The country is instead prioritizing investments outside of the US, focusing on regions such as Europe, Africa, and Southeast Asia. This shift is driven by concerns over trade tensions, intellectual property theft, and other issues that have strained relations between China and the US. As a result, Chinese companies are increasingly looking to invest in emerging markets with more favorable business environments. The implications of this trend are significant, potentially leading to increased economic influence for China in regions where it has historically been less prominent.

articles.title: The volunteer Wikipedia army protecting against AI slop
articles.summary: Wikipedia's volunteer editors are stepping up to protect against AI-generated "slop" submissions that have been flooding the platform with low-quality content. The influx has put a strain on the moderators' mental health and sparked concerns about the accuracy of AI-powered tools relying on Wikipedia data. In response, Wikimedia Foundation is implementing new measures to detect and reject AI-generated content. This development comes as AI's increasing presence in various industries raises questions about accountability and the role of human editors in ensuring quality control.

articles.title: $50 on war in Iran: How geopolitical bets have surged on Polymarket, in five charts
articles.summary: A growing number of individuals are using online prediction markets like Polymarket to wager on the likelihood of a US-Iran conflict, with some placing bets as high as $50. The surge in betting activity follows recent tensions between the two countries, including the US's withdrawal from the Iran nuclear deal and ongoing protests in Iran. The article highlights five charts illustrating the trend, showing that betting volumes have increased significantly since November 2025. Experts warn that these markets can be volatile and may not accurately reflect real-world events. Meanwhile, other news outlets are reporting on related developments, such as Uber's investment in a self-driving truck startup and Amazon's potential $50 billion investment in OpenAI.

articles.title: Spotify ventures into physical book sales, adds new audiobook features
articles.summary: Spotify has announced a significant expansion into physical book sales, allowing users in the US and UK to purchase physical copies of their favorite audiobooks directly through the app. The company has partnered with Bookshop.org, an online marketplace that supports local independent bookstores, to offer this new feature. Additionally, Spotify is introducing two new features: "Page Match," which allows users to scan a page from a physical or e-book and directs them to the exact spot in the audiobook, and "Audiobook Recaps," a previously iOS-only feature now coming to Android devices. These developments position Spotify as a competitor to major booksellers like Amazon and Barnes & Noble.

articles.title: Google’s subscriptions rise in Q4 as YouTube pulls $60B in yearly revenue
articles.summary: YouTube's subscription and ad revenue have seen significant growth, with the platform now having 325 million paying users across Google One and YouTube Premium. The company reported $60 billion in overall revenue for the full financial year, a 17% increase from last year. YouTube's premium tier is seeing strong traction, but specific numbers were not disclosed. Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai announced plans to expand subscription offerings, including new YouTube TV plans with genre-specific packages. The platform's AI features are also gaining popularity, with over 1 million channels using its AI creation tools and 20 million consumers using the Gemini-powered content discovery tool.

articles.title: Pluralistic: All laws are local (05 Feb 2026)
articles.summary: The article discusses the idea that societal conditions can become "eternal" in the popular consciousness, but are often fleeting and context-dependent. The author cites Thomas Piketty's book "Capital in the 21st Century" as an example of how primogeniture, a practice of passing down wealth to the eldest son, was once considered essential but became obsolete with colonization. This idea is related to the concept that "all laws are local," meaning that what seems universal and natural can actually be a product of specific historical and cultural contexts. The author argues that humans tend to forget how much things have changed over time, and that what is taken for granted today may seem unimaginable tomorrow.

articles.title: Josh Hawley Trots Out Trans Panic Attacks On Netflix To Help Larry Ellison Buy CNN, HBO
articles.summary: Josh Hawley, a Republican senator, has used Senate hearings to attack Netflix's proposed merger with Warner Brothers by leveraging anti-trans hysteria and fear-mongering. His claims that half of Netflix's children's programming promotes a "transgender ideology" are based on a flawed study from the Heritage Foundation, which is designed to demonize Netflix. This move is part of a larger effort by the Trump GOP to help Larry Ellison buy Warner Brothers, CNN, and HBO, allowing him to dominate U.S. media and turn it into a pro-Trump propaganda machine. The attack on Netflix serves two functions: scuttling the deal or forcing Netflix to debase itself to please Trump for merger approval.

articles.title: Increase of AI bots on the Internet sparks arms race
articles.summary: A new report from TollBit and data from Akamai reveal that AI bots are increasingly dominating web traffic, with some predicting that "the majority of the Internet will be bot traffic in the future." This development is part of a broader arms race between websites and AI companies as they try to outsmart each other's defenses. While many big websites attempt to limit what content bots can scrape for training purposes, others are now using real-time information from the web to augment their outputs. The rise of AI-related website scraping has sparked concerns about copyright infringement and the future of the Internet.

articles.title: ElevenLabs CEO: Voice is the next interface for AI
articles.summary: ElevenLabs CEO Mati Staniszewski predicts that voice will become the next major interface for AI, allowing people to interact with machines more naturally and effortlessly. This shift is driven by advancements in voice models that can mimic human speech and work in tandem with large language models. As a result, users may soon be able to control technology with their voices, making screens less relevant. Staniszewski's vision has been fueled by ElevenLabs' recent $500 million raise at an $11 billion valuation, and is shared across the AI industry, with companies like OpenAI and Google also focusing on voice-based interfaces. However, this trend raises concerns about privacy, surveillance, and data storage as voice-based systems become more pervasive.

articles.title: Substack confirms data breach affects users’ email addresses and phone numbers
articles.summary: Substack, a popular newsletter platform, has confirmed a data breach that exposed users' email addresses and phone numbers. The incident occurred in October 2025 when an unauthorized third party accessed the company's systems, but it was not detected until February 2026. Substack has fixed the issue and is investigating the matter, but it did not disclose how many users are affected or if any sensitive data was compromised. The breach highlights concerns about data security in online platforms, particularly those handling large amounts of user information.

articles.title: Fundamental raises $255 million Series A with a new take on big data analysis
articles.summary: Fundamental, an AI lab, emerged from stealth mode with $255 million in funding and a valuation of $1.2 billion. The company offers a new foundation model called Nexus, which combines predictive AI with contemporary tools to analyze large quantities of structured data produced by enterprises. Unlike Large Language Models (LLMs), Nexus is a deterministic model that doesn't rely on the transformer architecture, making it better suited for handling extremely large datasets common in big businesses. Fundamental's technology aims to bring contemporary techniques to Big Data analysis, offering more powerful and flexible solutions than existing algorithms.

articles.title: The Washington Post Is No Longer Useful to Jeff Bezos
articles.summary: The author reflects on their personal connection to The Washington Post, which was once a thriving institution under publisher Donald Graham's leadership. However, after Jeff Bezos acquired the paper in 2013, it has undergone significant changes, including layoffs and the gutting of its foreign bureau coverage. The latest round of layoffs, announced on Wednesday, has destroyed entire sections of the newspaper and left many journalists without jobs. The author, who had a personal connection to the paper through their father's work there and their own journalism education, laments the loss of an institution that was once a critical part of their life.

articles.title: Data breach at govtech giant Conduent balloons, affecting millions more Americans
articles.summary: A massive data breach at government technology giant Conduent has affected tens of millions of people across the United States, with at least 15.4 million individuals in Texas and 10.5 million in Oregon impacted. The stolen data includes sensitive information such as Social Security numbers, medical records, and health insurance details. Conduent, which handles personal and sensitive information for large corporations, government departments, and several US states, disclosed the breach in April but has provided limited details about the incident. The company is continuing to notify individuals whose data was stolen, with plans to conclude alerts by early 2026. The Safeway ransomware gang took credit for the breach, claiming to have stolen over 8 terabytes of data.

articles.title: This Tool Searches the Epstein Files For Your LinkedIn Contacts
articles.summary: A new tool, EpsteIn, allows users to search their LinkedIn connections for mentions in the Epstein files. The tool, created by Christopher Finke, uses an API developed by Patrick Duggan to easily search the publicly released court documents. Users can input their LinkedIn connections and receive a report showing each result's name, company, position, and excerpts from matching documents. The tool has been tested and found to work, but may produce false positives due to common names. The Epstein files contain 3.5 million pages of documents related to the investigations of Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, including videos, images, and audio recordings.

articles.title: Trump’s critical mineral reserve is an admission that the future is electric
articles.summary: The Trump administration has announced a $11.7 billion initiative to build a stockpile of critical minerals, dubbed Project Vault, in an effort to secure supplies for U.S. manufacturers and ensure national security. This move is seen as an admission that the future relies on electric technologies, including electric vehicles and wind turbines, which require significant amounts of critical minerals such as gallium, cobalt, and lithium. The initiative follows recent investments by the administration into rare earth producers and marks a shift in focus from fossil fuels to clean energy. Experts predict that demand for critical minerals will grow significantly in the coming years, driven by the increasing adoption of clean energy technologies.

articles.title: This SpaceX Situation: Not Good!
articles.summary: The author reflects on a 2015 article about Elon Musk and SpaceX's plans for a constellation of low-earth orbit satellites, which they called Starlink. The author predicted that SpaceX would become a powerful company due to its ability to launch rockets inexpensively and easily access space. Today, SpaceX has over 9,000 satellites in orbit, making it the largest satellite operator in the world. The company's dominance in space is raising concerns about its geopolitical implications and Musk's power. The author notes that SpaceX has been a political project for Musk, aiming to colonize space and expand his influence. Recent developments, including Musk's acquisition of xAI, are seen as alarming and highlight the need for greater scrutiny of SpaceX's activities.

articles.title: Vibe Coding Is Killing Open Source Software, Researchers Argue
articles.summary: A new study by European researchers argues that "vibe coding" is killing open-source software (OSS) due to its reliance on vast amounts of OSS libraries, databases, and user knowledge. Vibe coding involves quickly writing code with the assistance of a large language model (LLM), but it leads to users not contributing back to the community, which is essential for OSS survival. The study suggests that vibe coding reduces OSS provision and lowers welfare, leading to a rapid decline in shared packages and revenue. This phenomenon has already been observed in popular open-source projects like Tailwinds, which laid off three of its four engineers due to plummeting revenue despite increased popularity.

articles.title: Pacific Fusion finds a cheaper way to make its fusion reactor work
articles.summary: Pacific Fusion has made a breakthrough in its fusion reactor design by eliminating the need for lasers and magnets to preheat the fuel pellet before compression. The company used experiments at Sandia National Laboratory to tweak the design of the cylinder encasing the fuel pellet, allowing a magnetic field to leak through and warm the fuel before compression. This simplifies the system and reduces costs, with the elimination of the laser potentially saving over $100 million. Pacific Fusion's pulser-driven inertial confinement fusion (ICF) approach is one of several methods being explored by startups aiming to make fusion power commercially viable.

articles.title: Meta tests a standalone app for its AI-generated ‘Vibes’ videos
articles.summary: Meta is testing a standalone app for its AI-generated "Vibes" videos, allowing users to create and share short-form AI-generated content outside of the Meta AI app. The move positions Vibes as a direct competitor to OpenAI's Sora app, which has struggled since its launch. Vibes has seen strong early traction within Meta AI, with users increasingly leaning into the format for creation, discovery, and sharing. A standalone app provides a dedicated home for this experience, offering a more focused and immersive environment. Meta plans to expand the app further based on community feedback and will offer freemium access to Vibes video creation, with optional subscriptions to unlock additional features.

articles.title: Secondary sales shift from founder windfalls to employee-retention tools
articles.summary: Several fast-growing AI startups have recently allowed their employees to sell some of their shares at increasingly higher valuations through secondary sales, also known as tender offers. This trend is seen as a departure from the 2021 bubble, where founder windfalls were common, and instead focuses on providing liquidity to employees. Companies like Clay, Linear, and ElevenLabs have offered their staff the opportunity to cash in on their stock at valuations of $5 billion, $1.25 billion, and $6.6 billion respectively. This shift is viewed favorably by investors as it promotes employee retention and morale, but some experts warn that relying on tender offers could create a vicious cycle for the venture ecosystem by reducing liquidity for venture investors.

articles.title: The Wyden Siren: Senator’s Cryptic CIA Letter Follows A Pattern That’s Never Been Wrong
articles.summary: Senator Ron Wyden has sent a cryptic letter to CIA Director John Ratcliffe, expressing "deep concerns" about CIA activities. This is a pattern that Wyden has followed in the past, where he raises alarms about classified issues without revealing details, only to be proven right later on. Historically, when Wyden sounds the "Wyden Siren," it indicates that something serious and potentially problematic is happening within the government. The letter comes as part of ongoing surveillance and civil liberties issues, with Wyden having previously exposed programs such as bulk metadata collection, ICE's financial data collection, and the government's gathering of push notification data from tech companies.

articles.title: Anthropic releases Opus 4.6 with new ‘agent teams’
articles.summary: Anthropic has released Opus 4.6, an updated version of its advanced model that includes new features such as "agent teams" and a longer context window. Agent teams allow multiple agents to work together on tasks in parallel, increasing efficiency and speed. The update also integrates Claude directly into PowerPoint, enabling users to create presentations with direct help from the chatbot. Opus 4.6 aims to make the model more versatile and useful for a broader range of knowledge workers beyond software developers. The new features are currently available in research preview for API users and subscribers.

articles.title: Why Nvidia builds open models with Bryan Catanzaro
articles.summary: Nvidia's open model program has seen significant growth in 2025, with the release of high-quality models and datasets. In an interview, Bryan Catanzaro, VP Applied Deep Learning Research at Nvidia, discusses the company's approach to building open models, including their Nemotron series. He explains how Nvidia benefits from releasing open models, which creates a sustainable advantage for the company. The Nemotron 3 Nano model, released in December 2025, is a notable example of this effort, and larger Super and Ultra variants are expected soon. Catanzaro also touches on the importance of Megatron-LM and the current state of open-source training software.

articles.title: Tinder looks to AI to help fight ‘swipe fatigue’ and dating app burnout
articles.summary: Tinder is introducing an AI-powered feature called Chemistry to combat "swipe fatigue" among its users. The feature uses questions and access to the user's Camera Roll to get to know them better, providing a more personalized experience. Match CEO Spencer Rascoff announced that Chemistry is still in testing in Australia but aims to reduce the need for swiping through many profiles. The company also reported a decline in new registrations and monthly active users, citing AI-driven recommendations as a partial solution. To address common Gen Z pain points, Tinder plans to redesign discovery and use facial recognition verification to cut down on bad actors.

articles.title: Daily Deal: SunFounder GalaxyRVR Mars Rover Kit for Arduino
articles.summary: The article promotes a SunFounder GalaxyRVR Mars Rover Kit for Arduino, a robotics kit that allows users to learn coding and electronics through hands-on experience. The kit is compatible with the Arduino UNO R3, runs on solar power, and features real-time FPV with app-based control. It's on sale for $110 and comes with beginner-friendly tutorials and active support. This article appears to be a standalone product promotion and does not relate to any ongoing story or prior coverage.

articles.title: Federal Judges Are Done With The Deference: Courts Call Out Admin’s Immigration ‘Bullshit’ In Increasingly Pointed Terms
articles.summary: Two federal judges have issued scathing rulings on immigration cases, marking a significant shift in the judiciary's approach to executive branch actions. Judge Fred Biery's ruling granted habeas corpus to a five-year-old child and his father, criticizing the government's pursuit of daily deportation quotas and ignoring constitutional protections. Biery's opinion included a civics lesson, referencing the Declaration of Independence and the Fourth Amendment, and concluded with a quote from Ben Franklin about keeping the republic. Judge Ana Reyes' 83-page ruling in the Haitian TPS case is even more critical, laying bare the government's disregard for immigration laws and constitutional protections. Both judges have abandoned traditional judicial deference to the executive branch, instead calling out the administration's actions as "bullshit" and emphasizing their commitment to upholding the Constitution.

articles.title: Jeff Bezos Is Destroying What’s Left Of The Washington Post To Please Our Dim, Unpopular Autocrats
articles.summary: Jeff Bezos has continued to dismantle the Washington Post through massive layoffs, eliminating its sports desk, scaling back international and local news, firing journalists, and ending book sections. This is part of a broader trend of corporate media outlets shifting their tone to be more right-wing and autocrat-friendly. The Washington Post's leadership claims these cuts are necessary to remain competitive, but critics argue that billionaires like Bezos want a press that caters to their ideology and protects their interests. Former editor Marty Baron called the situation "one of the darkest days in the history of one of the world's greatest news organizations." Bezos' actions are seen as part of a global project to defang accountability for the planet's richest individuals and corporations.

articles.title: A16z just raised $1.7B for AI infrastructure. Here’s where it’s going.
articles.summary: Andreessen Horowitz (a16z) has raised $1.7 billion for its infrastructure team, which focuses on AI investments. The team's general partner, Jennifer Li, discussed the firm's plans with TechCrunch's Julie Bort on the Equity podcast. Li highlighted the importance of search infrastructure and the talent crunch facing AI-native startups. a16z is looking to invest in companies that can address these challenges, such as those developing AI chips or infrastructure for large-scale AI deployments.

articles.title: Should AI chatbots have ads? Anthropic says no.
articles.summary: Anthropic's AI chatbot Claude will remain ad-free, differentiating itself from rival OpenAI's ChatGPT, which began testing ads in a low-cost tier last month. Anthropic argues that including ads would be incompatible with its vision for Claude as a helpful assistant for work and deep thinking. The company has launched a Super Bowl ad campaign mocking AI assistants that interrupt conversations with product pitches, taking a dig at OpenAI's approach to advertising. This move comes amidst intense competition between the two companies in the AI coding agent market.

articles.title: Amazon to begin testing AI tools for film and TV production next month
articles.summary: Amazon is set to begin testing its AI tools for film and TV production in a closed beta program starting next month. The company's AI Studio, launched last summer, has developed proprietary tools aimed at streamlining production, improving character consistency, and supporting pre- and post-production. Industry partners will be invited to participate in the beta program, with initial outcomes expected by May. Amazon emphasizes that its goal is to support creative teams, not replace them, while addressing concerns about job security, creativity, and intellectual property protection.

articles.title: OpenAI’s New Scientific Writing And Collaboration Workspace ‘Prism’ Raises Fears Of Vibe-Coded Academic AI Slop
articles.summary: OpenAI has launched a new scientific writing and collaboration workspace called Prism, which integrates its advanced language model GPT-5.2 into the workflow to assist with drafting, revision, and publication preparation. While Prism aims to make scientific writing easier and more efficient, researchers are concerned that it will exacerbate the problem of "AI slop" in academic publishing, where low-quality papers generated by AI models flood scientific journals. The launch of Prism coincides with growing alarm among publishers about the issue, and some conferences have taken punitive measures against authors who fail to disclose their use of LLMs.

articles.title: AI SRE Resolve AI confirms $125M raise, unicorn valuation
articles.summary: Resolve AI, a startup co-founded by two former Splunk executives, has announced a $125 million Series A funding round at a valuation of $1 billion. The round was led by Lightspeed Venture Partners with participation from existing investors. This confirms TechCrunch's previous report in December 2025 that the startup was raising funds at a billion-dollar valuation. Resolve AI uses AI to automate system reliability engineering (SRE), also known as troubleshooting system failures. The company is part of the emerging category of AI SRE, which includes other startups like Traversal backed by Sequoia Capital.

articles.title: Meet Gizmo: A TikTok for interactive, vibe-coded mini apps
articles.summary: Gizmo is a new mobile app that allows users to create interactive, vibe-coded mini apps using natural language prompts. The app uses AI coding technology to turn user ideas into functional experiences, which can be shared on the app's feed or social media. Gizmo's founders aim to make creativity and app development accessible to non-technical users, with a focus on fun and playful interactions. The app has gained around 600,000 installs since its introduction, with half coming from the US. Gizmo is seen as a unique approach to vibe-coding, blending elements of TikTok and interactive design tools like Rooms.

articles.title: Elon Musk’s SpaceX company town is getting a police department
articles.summary: Starbase, the company town created by Elon Musk's SpaceX in South Texas, is establishing its own police department after struggling with a contract-based law enforcement system. The city commission approved an ordinance to create a municipal police department, which will be run by a chief of police elected by the commission and hire eight officers. This move comes as Starbase has grown in size and complexity, requiring more robust security measures to protect its assets and residents. The new police department is expected to be operational within a few months.

articles.title: The Wayback Machine debuts a new plug-in designed to fix the internet’s broken links problem
articles.summary: The Internet Archive's Wayback Machine has launched a new WordPress plug-in called Link Fixer to combat "link rot," a phenomenon where online articles become populated with broken links. The plug-in, developed in partnership with Automattic, scans WordPress posts for outbound links and cross-references the Wayback Machine for archived versions of those links. If no archived version exists, it takes new snapshots and redirects readers to the archived versions. This tool aims to keep a site's visitors reading the best available version of a web page and ensures the longevity of user-generated content.

articles.title: Smart AI Policy Means Examing Its Real Harms and Benefits
articles.summary: The article discusses the need for a nuanced approach to artificial intelligence (AI) policy, recognizing both its potential benefits and harms. While AI has been touted as a solution to various problems, it can also perpetuate biases and exacerbate existing issues. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) argues that regulators should focus on the specific context and impact of each use or tool, rather than making blanket decisions about AI technologies. The article highlights examples of AI's potential harms, such as price collusion, mass surveillance, and biased decision-making in areas like law enforcement and medical care.

articles.title: Google’s Gemini app has surpassed 750M monthly active users
articles.summary: Google's AI chatbot Gemini has surpassed 750 million monthly active users (MAUs), marking significant growth from its previous quarter's 650 million MAUs. This achievement comes after the launch of Gemini 3, which showcases Google's most advanced model yet. The company attributes this success to continued investment and iteration in its AI division, which has seen increased demand. Alphabet's overall financial performance has also surpassed $400 billion in annual revenue for the first time, driven by the expansion of its AI division. Google is focused on a free tier and subscriptions, with its recent roll-out of the Google AI Plus plan expected to drive further growth.

articles.title: Microsoft releases urgent Office patch. Russian-state hackers pounce.
articles.summary: Russian-state hackers have exploited a critical Microsoft Office vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2026-21509, to compromise devices in over a dozen countries. The threat group, known as APT28, pounced on the vulnerability just 48 hours after Microsoft released an urgent security update. The campaign involved spear phishing emails with at least 29 distinct lures, targeting defense ministries, transportation/logistics operators, and diplomatic entities. The hackers used advanced exploits and payloads that were encrypted and ran in memory to make their malice hard to spot. This incident highlights the speed and precision of state-aligned actors in weaponizing new vulnerabilities.

articles.title: Alphabet won’t talk about the Google-Apple AI deal, even to investors
articles.summary: Alphabet declined to discuss its AI partnership with Apple during a recent earnings call, sparking speculation about the impact of this deal on Alphabet's core business. The partnership is reportedly worth around $1 billion per year for Apple, but its effects on Google's search and advertising revenue are less clear. This decision not to disclose information suggests that Alphabet may be hesitant to discuss how this partnership will affect its AI-focused business. Meanwhile, rival Anthropic is taking aim at ad-supported AI with a forthcoming Super Bowl ad, challenging the business model adopted by OpenAI and Google.

articles.title: Baton Rouge Acquires A Straight-Up Military Surveillance Drone
articles.summary: The Baton Rouge Police Department has acquired a military-grade drone called the Stalker VXE30, designed by Lockheed Martin and Edge Autonomy, for use in surveillance operations. This is one of the first local police departments to deploy an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) with extensive surveillance capabilities, raising concerns about the militarization of law enforcement. The drone can fly for dozens of miles, access private spaces, and be equipped with additional camera-based surveillance technology, including automated license plate readers and face recognition software. The acquisition has sparked worries about the potential for mass surveillance and the need for communities to establish policies and oversight mechanisms to restrict its use.

articles.title: Stripe alumni raise €30M Series A for Duna, backed by Stripe and Adyen execs
articles.summary: Duna, a business identity verification startup co-founded by Stripe alumni Duco van Lanschot and David Schreiber, has raised €30 million in Series A funding led by Alphabet's growth fund CapitalG. The company aims to build a global trust infrastructure where businesses can reuse their verified identity information across multiple platforms. Duna's technology helps fintech companies onboard business customers more efficiently, reducing churn associated with corporate ID checks and fraud prevention measures. The startup has already secured customers including Plaid and Moss, and is looking to expand its network effects by identifying small clusters of overlapping companies that can benefit from reused verification.

articles.title: Mundi Ventures closes on €750M for Kembara, its largest deep tech and climate fund
articles.summary: Mundi Ventures has closed its largest deep tech and climate fund, Kembara, with a first close of €750 million. The fund is focused on Series B and C rounds, with plans to invest between €15-40 million in 20 companies, and potentially up to €100 million per company for follow-on investments. Kembara's co-founder Yann de Vries emphasizes the need for non-dilutive financing options for deep tech founders, citing his experience with Lilium's bankruptcy as a lesson learned. The fund aims to productize non-dilutive financing solutions and attract limited partners who are willing to coinvest in winners.

articles.title: As it preps Specs for the masses, Snap’s Q4 shows revenue growth but fewer daily users
articles.summary: Snap's Q4 earnings report shows revenue growth, with $1.7 billion in revenue and a 10% year-over-year increase. The company's average revenue per user also rose slightly, while its net income jumped from $9 million to $45 million. However, Snap's daily active users declined by 3 million, falling from 477 million to 474 million, primarily due to losses in North America and Europe. Despite this, the company's paid subscription service, Snap+, saw a 71% year-over-year growth in subscribers, reaching 24 million. Snap is also preparing for the launch of its augmented reality glasses, Specs, which will be developed by a new subsidiary, Specs Inc.

articles.title: Sam Altman got exceptionally testy over Claude Super Bowl ads
articles.summary: Anthropic's Super Bowl ads, which mocked OpenAI's plan to introduce ads in its ChatGPT chatbot, have sparked a heated response from Sam Altman, the CEO of OpenAI. The ads depicted ChatGPT inserting ads into conversations, which Altman claims is dishonest and misleading. In a lengthy social media post, Altman accused Anthropic of being "dishonest" and "authoritarian," and defended his company's approach to advertising in ChatGPT. He also took aim at Anthropic's business model, suggesting that it serves only wealthy customers with its expensive product. The exchange highlights the competitive dynamics between OpenAI and Anthropic, as well as the ongoing debate about the role of ads in AI-powered chatbots.

articles.title: Protecting Our Right to Sue Federal Agents Who Violate the Constitution
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) is advocating for new statutes to allow individuals to sue federal agents who violate their constitutional rights. This comes after a series of incidents involving Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and Customs and Border Protection (CBP) agents in Minnesota, where they have been accused of violence and violating digital rights. The EFF argues that the current system lacks accountability for federal officials, citing the Supreme Court's narrowing of the Bivens v. Six Unknown FBI Agents case, which allowed individuals to sue federal officials for constitutional violations. The organization supports California S.B. 747, a bill aimed at filling this gap in the rule of law.

articles.title: Measles Has Now Begun To Infect Immigrant Detention Camps
articles.summary: Measles has begun to infect immigrant detention camps in the US, with confirmed cases reported at facilities in Texas and Arizona. The Dilley detention center in Texas was placed on a soft lockdown due to measles outbreaks among detainees, while the Florence Detention Center in Arizona reported one ICE detainee testing positive for measles. This development is seen as ironic given the Trump administration's claims that immigrants bring disease into the country. Lawyers and advocates are concerned about the spread of disease in detention camps and the potential use of the outbreak as an excuse to limit access to these facilities. The situation highlights the poor conditions and lack of medical care in immigrant detention centers.

articles.title: Why won’t people buy these tiny electric cars?
articles.summary: The article discusses the lack of interest in micro electric vehicles (EVs), which are small, compact cars designed for urban driving. Despite their potential benefits, such as lower production costs and reduced environmental impact, these EVs have failed to gain traction with consumers. The article suggests that this is due to various factors, including limited range, high prices, and a lack of awareness about the benefits of micro EVs. Experts are quoted as saying that the industry needs to rethink its approach to marketing and selling these vehicles in order to make them more appealing to customers.

articles.title: To understand China, we need to understand the Chinese internet
articles.summary: Understanding China's current situation and future trajectory requires analyzing its unique online landscape. The Chinese internet is a distinct entity that reflects the country's values, politics, and societal norms. What becomes popular on the Chinese internet can reveal insights into the nation's priorities, while what disappears quickly can indicate areas of censorship or suppression. This phenomenon has significant implications for understanding China's economic, social, and cultural dynamics. By studying the Chinese internet, researchers and observers can gain a deeper understanding of the country's complexities and nuances. The article suggests that this is crucial for predicting China's future development and its potential impact on the global stage.

articles.title: So yeah, I vibe-coded a log colorizer—and I feel good about it
articles.summary: The author, who claims they can't code, uses AI-powered Claude Code to create a log colorizer. They share their experience and provide access to the project's GitHub repository. The article highlights the potential of AI in making coding more accessible, even for those without extensive technical knowledge. This development is part of an ongoing trend where AI tools are being used to simplify complex tasks and make them more user-friendly.

articles.title: Accel doubles down on Fibr AI as agents turn static websites into one-to-one experiences
articles.summary: Accel has led a $5.7 million seed round for Fibr AI, a startup that uses AI agents to turn generic webpages into one-to-one experiences tailored to each visitor. The funding brings the company's total investment to $7.5 million, with Accel doubling down on its thesis that Fibr AI can bridge the gap between personalized advertising and static website experiences. Fibr AI operates by connecting to a company's data systems and using autonomous AI agents to assemble and adjust page content in real-time, running thousands of micro-experiments in parallel. The platform has gained traction among large enterprises, including banks and healthcare providers, which are evaluating its cost-effectiveness and conversion impact. Accel sees Fibr AI as a key player in the agentic-commerce era, where AI agents mediate online interactions.

articles.title: Spotify upgrades its lyrics feature with offline access, more translations
articles.summary: Spotify has upgraded its lyrics feature, making it available offline for Premium subscribers and expanding translations to 25 new markets. The update also relocates the lyrics section to a more prominent position beneath album artwork or short videos. This move is part of Spotify's efforts to encourage free users to upgrade to Premium subscriptions by offering exclusive features. The company has been refining its lyrics feature over the years, initially introducing real-time lyrics in 2021 and later loosening restrictions on free users' access to lyrics.

articles.title: Trumpland Ramps Up Attacks On Netflix Warner Brothers Merger To Help Larry Ellison
articles.summary: The Trump administration has escalated its attacks on Netflix's proposed merger with Warner Brothers, allegedly to help Larry Ellison dominate the US media landscape. The administration claims that Netflix is attempting a "cultural takeover" through its content, which they say promotes left-wing ideology. However, this narrative is disputed by critics who argue that Netflix prioritizes profits over ideological consistency and will adapt its content to appeal to a broad audience. The Trump administration's efforts are seen as an attempt to create a safe space for right-wing ideology and propaganda, with Larry Ellison's media acquisitions being a key part of this strategy.

articles.title: SNAK Venture Partners raises $50M fund to back vertical marketplaces
articles.summary: SNAK Venture Partners has closed its debut $50 million fund, backed by Pritzker Group and other investors. The firm, founded by Sonia Nagar and Adam Koopersmith, aims to invest in digital marketplaces, particularly those serving business-to-business (B2B) markets that have yet to be digitized. They plan to write seed checks into at least 20 companies over the next 3-4 years, focusing on areas such as supply chain and construction. Nagar believes there is significant white space for B2B marketplaces, citing examples like Uber, Instacart, and Airbnb, which have achieved massive success in consumer markets. The firm has already invested in six companies, including Big Rentals and Repackify.

articles.title: Alexa+, Amazon’s AI assistant, is now available to everyone in the US
articles.summary: Amazon has made its upgraded AI-powered assistant, Alexa+, available to all US customers as of Wednesday. The feature was previously in beta testing and is now free for Prime members across devices. Non-Prime customers can also use Alexa+ for free via the website or mobile app, with some limitations. Alexa+ allows for natural language conversations, follow-up questions, and back-and-forth chat, and can perform tasks such as scheduling appointments, making reservations, and more. The assistant is model agnostic, using a combination of Amazon's own foundation models and those from other companies to provide a more comprehensive experience.

articles.title: Apeiron Labs gets $9.5M to flood the oceans with autonomous underwater robots
articles.summary: Apeiron Labs, a startup founded by Ravi Pappu, has secured $9.5 million in funding for its autonomous underwater robots (AUVs) designed to collect data from the ocean's subsurface. The AUVs can travel 400 meters up and down the water column, sampling temperature, salinity, and acoustics once or twice a day. This technology aims to fill the gaps in ocean data collection, which is currently limited by expensive and slow ship-based methods. Pappu hopes to bring the cost of ocean data down by a factor of 1,000 next year, making it more accessible for various customers, including the Pentagon and fisheries.

articles.title: Podcast: The Latest Epstein Dump is a Disaster
articles.summary: The latest Epstein dump has revealed unredacted nude images, exposing sensitive data. This development is part of a series of security flaws and data breaches in the tech industry, including Moltbot's terrible security and an exposed database that allowed anyone to take control of AI agents on the site. These incidents raise concerns about the handling of sensitive information and the security measures in place to protect it.

articles.title: FBI Couldn’t Get into WaPo Reporter’s iPhone Because It Had Lockdown Mode Enabled
articles.summary: The FBI was unable to access the iPhone of Washington Post reporter Hannah Natanson due to Lockdown Mode being enabled on her device, according to court records. The FBI had raided Natanson's home in January as part of an investigation into leaks of classified information. Despite attempting to access the device, the FBI was only able to retrieve data from other devices and not the iPhone itself. This incident highlights the effectiveness of Lockdown Mode, a feature that makes iPhones more secure by limiting their functionality when enabled. The court records provide rare insight into how law enforcement agencies attempt to access seized devices and the limitations they face when encountering advanced security features.

articles.title: Uber appoints new CFO as its AV plans accelerate
articles.summary: Uber has appointed Balaji Krishnamurthy, its VP of strategic finance and investor relations, as its new CFO, replacing Prashanth Mahendra-Rajah. Krishnamurthy has been with Uber for over six years and has a background in autonomous vehicle (AV) investments, suggesting that the company's plans to expand its driverless operations are accelerating. The appointment comes as Uber reported strong Q4 earnings, driven by demand for its food delivery services. CEO Dara Khosrowshahi emphasized the potential of AVs to unlock a multitrillion-dollar opportunity for the company, with plans to facilitate AV trips in 15 cities globally by 2026 and become the largest facilitator of AV trips worldwide by 2029.

articles.title: After backlash, Adobe cancels Adobe Animate shutdown and puts app on ‘maintenance mode’
articles.summary: Adobe has put its plan to discontinue Adobe Animate on hold after facing intense backlash from customers. The company had announced the shutdown of the 2D animation software due to its age and the evolution of technologies that better serve users' needs. However, in response to customer concerns and criticism, Adobe has decided to place Animate in "maintenance mode," where it will continue to be available for both current and new customers, with ongoing security and bug fixes, but without adding new features. This decision comes as a surprise, given the company's previous statement that Animate no longer represents its current direction, which is focused on AI-powered products.

articles.title: ElevenLabs raises $500M from Sequoia at an $11 billion valuation
articles.summary: ElevenLabs, a voice AI startup, has raised $500 million in funding from Sequoia Capital at an $11 billion valuation. This is more than three times the company's valuation in its last round in January 2025. The funding will be used for research and product development, as well as expansion into international markets such as India, Japan, Singapore, Brazil, and Mexico. ElevenLabs plans to use this new capital to develop agents beyond voice and incorporate video capabilities. This investment is part of a larger trend of big tech companies and investors targeting voice AI model providers.

articles.title: Pluralistic: Justin Key's "The Hospital at the End Of the World" (04 Feb 2026)
articles.summary: Justin C. Key's debut novel "The Hospital at the End of the World" has been published by Harpercollins. The book is a biopunk medical thriller set in a future where an AI-driven health monopolist controls much of American life. Key, a practicing psychiatrist and MD, combines his insights into human relations with a wild imagination to create a compelling story about Pok, a young New Yorker who dreams of becoming a doctor. The novel explores themes of personal identity, human connection, and the role of technology in medicine.

articles.title: Scientists Keep Discovering Mysterious Ancient Tunnels Across Europe
articles.summary: Scientists in Germany have discovered a mysterious ancient tunnel, known as an erdstall, within a prehistoric burial ground. The tunnel measures about two feet wide and four feet high and was likely constructed between 800 to 1,100 years ago. Archeologists found pottery dating back to the 13th or 14th century in the chamber, along with a horseshoe, a fox skeleton, and small mammal bones. This discovery is one of hundreds of similar structures found across Europe, but their purpose remains unknown. Researchers speculate that the tunnel may have been used as a hiding place or cultic site, but further investigation is needed to determine its function.

articles.title: Roblox’s 4D creation feature is now available in open beta
articles.summary: Roblox has launched an open beta for its 4D creation feature, allowing users to create fully functional and interactive objects within the platform. The technology enables creators to design items that can move and react to players in the game, breaking down complex objects into individual parts with assigned behaviors. Two initial object templates are available for testing, including a car schema that generates spinning wheels and a single-piece object schema. Roblox plans to expand user freedom by allowing creators to make their own schemas and is developing new technologies, such as reference image-based 3D modeling. The company's AI-powered creation tools have generated over 1.8 million 3D objects since its open-source model was released last year.

articles.title: DOJ Prosecutors Directly Contradict The DHS’s Oregon Shooting Narrative
articles.summary: DOJ prosecutors have directly contradicted a narrative presented by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) regarding an Oregon shooting incident. The DHS initially claimed that two suspected gang associates, who were allegedly "let loose on American streets" by President Joe Biden, had attempted to arrest Border Patrol agents in Portland and were subsequently shot. However, DOJ prosecutors have disputed this account, suggesting that the individuals involved were not as threatening as portrayed. This development highlights ongoing concerns about government narratives and the use of violent rhetoric to justify actions against minority groups.

articles.title: Hackers publish personal information stolen during Harvard, UPenn data breaches
articles.summary: Notorious hacking group ShinyHunters has published over 2 million records stolen from Harvard University and the University of Pennsylvania (UPenn) in last year's data breaches. The hackers claimed responsibility for the breach, which was initially reported by both universities in November 2025. The leaked data includes sensitive information such as email addresses, phone numbers, home and business addresses, event attendance, and donation details. ShinyHunters published the stolen data after claiming that the universities refused to pay a ransom to stop them from doing so. The incident highlights concerns about data security in educational institutions and the tactics used by hackers to extort their victims.

articles.title: Lunar Energy raises $232M to deploy home batteries that prop up the grid
articles.summary: Lunar Energy, a six-year-old startup that builds battery packs for homeowners, has raised $232 million through two funding rounds, a Series C of $130 million and a Series D of $102 million. The company plans to use the funds to scale its manufacturing capacity from 20,000 units by the end of this year to 100,000 units by the end of 2028. Lunar Energy's technology allows homeowners to deploy batteries that can prop up the grid when needed, and its virtual power plant (VPP) software can control EV chargers and appliances to supply electrons while reducing demand. The company is one of several startups in the stationary storage space, which has become a bright spot for battery manufacturers after policy changes affected the industry.

articles.title: Xcode moves into agentic coding with deeper OpenAI and Anthropic integrations
articles.summary: Apple has released Xcode 26.3, which integrates agentic coding tools from OpenAI and Anthropic into its app development suite. This allows developers to use AI models like Codex and Claude Agent directly within Xcode to automate tasks, explore project structure, build projects, and run tests. The integration enables AI models to tap into Xcode's features for more complex automation and access to Apple's developer documentation. Developers can choose which version of the model to use and direct the agent with natural language commands. The feature aims to help new developers learn coding and provides transparency through visual changes in code and a project transcript.

articles.title: Skyryse lands another $300M to make flying, even helicopters, simple and safe
articles.summary: Skyryse, an aviation automation startup, has secured $300 million in Series C funding, bringing its valuation to $1.15 billion. The investment will support the company's efforts to integrate its operating system, SkyOS, across various aircraft, including U.S. military Black Hawk helicopters. Skyryse aims to simplify and automate flight operations, while enhancing pilot skills and improving safety. The startup has already made inroads with investors and operators, such as United Rotorcraft and Mitsubishi Corporation, which have contracts to integrate SkyOS on their aircraft. Skyryse's system automates takeoff and landing, hover, and engine-out emergency landings, but still requires a pilot for operation.

articles.title: Homeland Security is trying to force tech companies to hand over data about Trump critics
articles.summary: The Department of Homeland Security has been using administrative subpoenas to demand user information from tech companies about critics of the Trump administration. The subpoenas have targeted individuals who run anonymous Instagram accounts sharing posts about ICE immigration raids and those who have criticized Trump officials or protested government policies. Tech companies are not required to comply with these subpoenas, but they often do so voluntarily. The American Civil Liberties Union has expressed concern that this is part of a broader strategy to intimidate people who document immigration activity or criticize government actions. At least four cases have been reported where Homeland Security withdrew its subpoena after the account owners sued to block the attempt. The use of administrative subpoenas raises concerns about the lack of judicial oversight and the potential for abuse of power.

articles.title: Daily Deal: The Complete Raspberry Pi And Alexa A-Z Bundle
articles.summary: The Complete Raspberry Pi and Alexa A-Z Bundle is on sale for $30, offering project-based courses to learn Raspberry Pi and build Amazon Alexa projects. The bundle caters to all levels, starting with the basics of Pi before moving on to full projects such as building a gaming system and personal digital assistant using the Google Assistant API. Additionally, users will learn how to build Alexa Skills that can run on any Amazon Echo device and create their own Echo clone. This deal is part of the Techdirt Deals Store, which helps support Techdirt through sales. The bundle includes courses and resources to get started with Raspberry Pi and Alexa development.

articles.title: Turns Out They Didn’t Really Want You To Bring Your Whole Self To Work
articles.summary: Silicon Valley executives have been accused of hypocrisy for their sudden shift towards conservative values, but a former tech communications executive argues that this is not about ideology, but rather leverage. The real reason companies promoted "bringing your whole self to work" was to attract and retain top talent in a competitive labor market, where engineers had infinite options. As the job market tightened, companies dropped these values as quickly as they adopted them. This shift was driven by economics, not politics.

articles.title: 2026 plans: What’s next for Startup Battlefield 200
articles.summary: TechCrunch Startup Battlefield 200 is a highly selective startup launch program that selects 200 early-stage companies to participate in the TechCrunch Disrupt event. The program provides visibility, credibility, and opportunities for growth through free exhibit space, masterclasses, networking, direct exposure to top-tier press and investors, and a chance to pitch live at Disrupt. Alumni of the program have collectively raised over $32 billion and include well-known companies such as Dropbox, Discord, Cloudflare, and Trello. Applications for the 2026 cohort will open in mid-month and close in mid-June, with selected startups notified around September 1.

articles.title: YC startups can now receive investment in stablecoin
articles.summary: YC startups will now have the option to receive their seed checks in stablecoins, a move that reflects YC's growing interest in blockchain technology. This change is part of YC's partnership with Base and Coinbase Ventures, aimed at encouraging founders to build more blockchain-related companies. Stablecoin transfers are seen as a more effective option for founders working in emerging markets. The decision comes as the US takes steps towards more formal regulation of the crypto industry, sparking renewed interest in blockchain tech in Silicon Valley. YC's standard deal will remain unchanged, with $500,000 invested in exchange for 7% equity. This move is seen as a vote of confidence in the potential of blockchain technology. The upcoming spring batch of startups will be the first to receive stablecoin seed checks.

articles.title: ICE Director Says Officers Are Now Allowed To Make Arrests Without Warrants
articles.summary: The Director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), Todd Lyons, has issued an internal memo allowing lower-level ICE agents to make arrests without warrants. This change expands their ability to carry out sweeps and round up people suspected of being undocumented immigrants. The memo redefines the term "flight risk" to allow for warrantless arrests, citing a new standard of "likely to escape." Critics argue that this move undermines the Fourth Amendment's protection against unreasonable searches and seizures.

articles.title: Intel will start making GPUs, a market dominated by Nvidia
articles.summary: Intel's CEO Lip-Bu Tan announced that the company will start producing graphics processing units (GPUs), a move to expand into a market dominated by Nvidia. The project will be overseen by Kevork Kechichian and Eric Demers, who were recently hired for their expertise in data center and engineering. Intel plans to develop its strategy around customer demands and needs, indicating that the initiative is still in its early stages. This move marks a notable expansion for Intel, which has been consolidating and focusing on its core businesses under Tan's leadership. The GPU market is highly competitive, with Nvidia holding a commanding lead, but Intel hopes to gain traction with its entry into this space.

articles.title: Techdirt Podcast Episode 442: Does AI Remove Or Provide User Agency?
articles.summary: The Techdirt Podcast explores the question of whether AI tools enhance or diminish user agency. In a previous episode, Mike and guest host Konstantinos Komaitis discussed online speech and touched on this topic briefly. This week's episode delves deeper into the issue, with Mike and Konstantinos presenting different perspectives on how AI affects user control and autonomy. They discuss various scenarios where AI might either empower or restrict users' choices, from content moderation to personalized recommendations. The conversation highlights the complexities of AI's impact on user agency and encourages listeners to think critically about these issues.

articles.title: The Minneapolis tech community holds strong during ‘tense and difficult time’
articles.summary: The Minneapolis tech community is facing a challenging time due to increased immigration raids and enforcement operations by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) in the city. The raids have resulted in several deaths, including at least two U.S. citizens, and have caused widespread fear and disruption among residents. Tech entrepreneurs and investors are putting their work on hold to focus on supporting their communities, volunteering, and helping those affected by the raids. Despite the challenges, the community is coming together in a grassroots effort to provide emotional support and resources to one another.

articles.title: Nvidia's $100 billion OpenAI deal has seemingly vanished
articles.summary: Nvidia and OpenAI announced a letter of intent for Nvidia to invest up to $100 billion in OpenAI's AI infrastructure in September 2025. However, five months later, the deal has not been finalized, and Nvidia's CEO has downplayed the commitment, stating that the $100 billion figure was "never a commitment." OpenAI is reportedly dissatisfied with the speed of some Nvidia chips for inference tasks, leading them to seek alternatives. The two companies have attempted to smooth over their public image, but the situation remains unclear.

articles.title: India’s Varaha bags $20M to scale carbon removal from the Global South
articles.summary: Varaha, an India-based climate tech startup, has raised $20 million in funding to scale its carbon removal projects from the Global South. The company aims to position itself as a lower-cost supplier for verified emissions reductions, leveraging its execution-focused model and partnerships with smallholder farmers and industrial operators. Varaha develops carbon removal projects across four main pathways: regenerative agriculture, agroforestry, biochar, and enhanced rock weathering. With over 2 million tons of CO2 removed to date, the startup expects revenue to rise from $4.76 million last year to nearly $11.06 million this year while remaining profitable after tax.

articles.title: ICE Is A Paramilitary Force, And Those Don’t End Well
articles.summary: The article argues that Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) has become a paramilitary force, similar to those found in other countries, due to its militarized structure and tactics. The author defines paramilitaries as highly centralized forces with access to military-grade equipment and hierarchical command structures, often used for domestic policing. ICE's operations have been criticized for being overly aggressive and targeting vulnerable populations, leading some politicians and journalists to compare it to a "personal paramilitary unit" of the president. The article explores two definitions of paramilitaries: formal police forces with military characteristics and informal, partisan groups that operate outside the state's regular security sector. While ICE meets some but not all criteria for a paramilitary force, its use of tactics such as raids and surveillance raises concerns about its legitimacy and accountability.

articles.title: Epstein-linked longevity guru Peter Attia leaves David Protein, and his own startup ‘won’t comment’
articles.summary: Dr. Peter Attia, a prominent longevity guru and physician, has stepped down as Chief Science Officer at David Protein, a high-protein nutrition bar company, following his name's appearance in over 1,700 documents related to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. The documents were released as part of a massive file dump by The New York Times. Attia had also been an early investor and executive team member at David Protein, which raised $75 million in funding last year. His departure from the company has sparked concerns about his involvement with Epstein and potential fallout for other companies he is associated with, including Biograph, a healthcare testing and longevity startup co-founded by Attia.

articles.title: Kash Patel Creating Tension With Mexico Because He Can’t Shut The Fuck Up On Social Media
articles.summary: FBI Director Kash Patel has sparked tension with Mexico after publicly announcing a joint operation to apprehend Ryan Wedding, a suspected drug kingpin. However, Mexican law prohibits foreign law enforcement from operating on its soil, making the FBI's involvement potentially illegal. The situation has created problems for both the US and Mexican governments, with Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum scrambling to perform damage control. Patel's decision to post about the operation on social media has further exacerbated the issue, opening up Sheinbaum to political attacks in Mexico and straining US-Mexico relations. This incident is just one of many examples of Patel's perceived incompetence and recklessness as FBI Director.

articles.title: Exclusive: Positron raises $230M Series B to take on Nvidia’s AI chips
articles.summary: Positron, a semiconductor startup based in Reno, has secured $230 million in Series B funding from investors including Qatar Investment Authority (QIA). The company plans to use the capital to accelerate deployment of its high-speed memory chips, which are critical components for AI workloads. This investment comes as hyperscalers and AI firms seek to reduce their reliance on Nvidia's AI chips, with some companies like OpenAI reportedly dissatisfied with Nvidia's latest offerings. Positron's technology is positioned to compete with Nvidia's H100 GPUs, offering similar performance at a lower power consumption. The startup has raised over $300 million in total capital and plans to focus on inference computing for real-world applications.

articles.title: Peak XV says internal disagreement led to partner exits as it doubles down on AI
articles.summary: Peak XV Partners, a leading venture capital firm in India and Southeast Asia, has experienced another round of senior departures due to internal disagreements. The latest exits include Ashish Agrawal, Ishaan Mittal, and Tejeshwi Sharma, who have been with the firm for over 13, 9, and 7 years respectively. Despite these losses, Peak XV is doubling down on its focus on AI investing and expanding its global footprint, including opening a US office within the next 90 days. The firm has seen significant portfolio exits in recent months, generating billions of dollars in unrealized gains.

articles.title: PayPal hires HP’s Enrique Lores as its new CEO
articles.summary: PayPal has appointed Enrique Lores, former CEO of HP, as its new CEO and president, replacing Alex Chriss. The move comes after PayPal reported lower-than-expected revenue and profit in the fourth quarter due to a cost-of-living crisis and softening labor market. Lores will take over from Jamie Miller, who will serve as interim CEO until he joins the company. The appointment is seen as a response to PayPal's pace of change and execution not meeting the board's expectations. Lores has promised to accelerate product innovation and deliver quarterly accounts. His appointment comes as PayPal's shares fell 17.9% in premarket trading.

articles.title: Pluralistic: Michael Swanwick's "The Universe Box" (03 Feb 2026)
articles.summary: Michael Swanwick's new short story collection "The Universe Box" is a masterclass in science fiction writing. The book showcases Swanwick's unique ability to craft engaging and thought-provoking stories that explore the boundaries of human knowledge and imagination. As a five-time Hugo-winning author, Swanwick is part of an elite group of writers who have dedicated themselves to the short story form, which has historically been a staple of science fiction. The article highlights the importance of exposition in science fiction writing and how it can be used to create immersive and engaging stories.

articles.title: Hackers and Trolls Target Wave of ICE Spotting Apps
articles.summary: Hackers and trolls have targeted several ICE spotting apps, sending threatening text messages and push notifications to users. The attacks appear to be an attempt to intimidate and stop users from reporting sightings of ICE officials. Apps such as StopICE, Eyes Up, and DEICER have been affected, with some developers claiming that hackers gained access to their systems or used automated tools to send malicious messages. While there is no evidence that user data has been compromised, the attacks highlight the vulnerability of these apps and their users. The incidents also raise concerns about government pressure on tech companies to remove these apps from their stores.

articles.title: Fitbit founders launch AI platform to help families monitor their health
articles.summary: Fitbit founders James Park and Eric Friedman have launched a new AI startup called Luffu, which aims to help families monitor their health and well-being. The platform uses AI to gather and organize family information, learn day-to-day patterns, and flag notable changes. This comes as 63 million US adults are family caregivers, up 45% from 10 years ago, highlighting the need for a comprehensive solution. Luffu will start with an app experience and expand into hardware devices, allowing users to track health stats, diet, medications, symptoms, and more. The platform is designed to reduce the mental burden of caregiving by providing insights and alerts when needed.

articles.title: TikTok recovers from dip in usage that benefited rival apps following US ownership change
articles.summary: TikTok has largely recovered from a brief dip in active users following its ownership change in the US. The decline, which benefited rival apps like UpScrolled and Skylight Social, was driven by user concerns over TikTok's updated privacy policy and a multi-day data center outage that caused glitches and disruptions to the app. However, as users became more comfortable with the new terms and conditions and the outage was resolved, they returned to the platform. According to estimates from digital market intelligence firm Similarweb, TikTok has bounced back to over 90 million daily active users in the US. Despite this recovery, rival apps have still seen significant growth, with UpScrolled topping 138,500 daily active users at its peak and Skylight Social hitting 81,200 daily active users.

articles.title: What tech CEOs and executives have said about ICE’s actions in Minnesota
articles.summary: Tech industry leaders are speaking out against the Trump administration's immigration policies and actions by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) after a series of deaths in Minnesota. The tech industry has been criticized for its ties to ICE, with companies like Palantir and Clearview AI providing services to the agency. Some CEOs, such as Reid Hoffman of LinkedIn, have called on their peers to take a stronger stance against ICE's actions, while others, like Sam Altman of OpenAI, have walked back previous criticisms of Trump's policies in favor of more conciliatory language. The tech industry has been accused of being too quiet on the issue, and some are calling for greater action from its leaders.

articles.title: French police search X office in Paris, summon Elon Musk for questioning
articles.summary: French police and Europol searched the Paris office of X, a social media platform owned by Elon Musk, as part of an ongoing investigation into allegations of "fraudulent extraction of data" and other crimes. The investigation has been expanded to cover complicity in child sexual abuse material, privacy violations, and Holocaust denial. Musk and former CEO Linda Yaccarino have been summoned for questioning, along with unnamed X staffers. The raid is part of a wider effort by French authorities to ensure X's compliance with French law. The investigation follows widespread criticism of X's AI-powered feature, Grok, which was used to generate nonconsensual imagery, including child abuse material.

articles.title: Lotus Health nabs $35M for AI doctor that sees patients for free
articles.summary: Lotus Health AI, a primary care provider, has raised $35 million in a Series A round to develop an AI-powered doctor that offers free medical care 24/7 in 50 languages. The platform uses AI to diagnose and prescribe treatments, but human doctors review the final diagnoses to ensure accuracy. Lotus claims it can see 10 times as many patients as traditional practices, addressing the shortage of primary care doctors. The company is differentiating itself by offering free services, although eventual business models may include sponsored content or subscriptions.

articles.title: MN Police Chief Intervenes To Free A US Citizen Arrested By Federal Officers
articles.summary: The police chief in St. Peter, Minnesota intervened on Thursday to prevent federal immigration agents from detaining a local resident who was being arrested by federal officers. The resident had been observing the officers' actions and recording them with her dash cam and cellphone. Despite not committing any crime, she was treated as if she were a violent criminal and was threatened at gunpoint before being taken into custody. However, thanks to her husband's quick thinking in calling an attorney, who then contacted the police chief, she was released from federal custody and driven home by the police chief. This incident is believed to be the first time a local police department in Minnesota has intervened in a federal law enforcement action since the surge in immigration enforcement began two months ago.

articles.title: Watch Club is producing short video dramas and building a social network around them
articles.summary: Henry Soong, the founder of Watch Club, aims to create a vertical microdrama series that surpasses the quality of existing apps. Unlike competitors like ReelShort and DramaBox, which rely on formulaic content and aggressive monetization tactics, Watch Club will feature stories made by SAG and WGA actors and writers. Soong seeks to differentiate his app by embedding a social network within it, allowing users to engage with each other around the shows they watch. The app has secured seed funding from investors, including GV and Patreon founder Jack Conte, and plans to release its first show, "Return Offer," soon.

articles.title: Gradient’s heat pumps get new smarts to enable old building retrofits
articles.summary: Gradient, a company that makes horseshoe-shaped heat pumps, has developed new software called Nexus that allows building managers to control and optimize energy usage in multifamily buildings. The system can link multiple units together, enabling more efficient heating and cooling while preventing overuse by residents. This technology aims to improve comfort and reduce energy consumption in old buildings, particularly those with boilers nearing the end of their lifespan. Gradient has already partnered with the New York City Housing Authority and is exploring opportunities with colleges and universities.

articles.title: Agentic coding comes to Apple’s Xcode with agents from Anthropic and OpenAI
articles.summary: Apple has released Xcode 26.3, which includes agentic coding tools from Anthropic and OpenAI.
