This update allows developers to use AI models like Claude Agent and Codex directly within Apple's official app development suite. The integration enables AI models to tap into Xcode's features for more complex automation and access to developer documentation. Developers can now use natural language commands to direct the agents, which will break down tasks into smaller steps and provide transparency on code changes. This feature is expected to help new developers learn coding by providing a visual representation of the coding process.

articles.title: Notepad++ users take note: It's time to check if you're hacked
articles.summary: The Notepad++ text editor's infrastructure was compromised by suspected China-state hackers for six months, allowing them to deliver backdoored updates to select targets. The attackers used their access to install a sophisticated backdoor tool called Chrysalis, which has been described as a permanent and feature-rich malware. The hack began in June 2022 and wasn't discovered until December, when Notepad++ regained control of its infrastructure. The hackers specifically targeted the Notepad++ domain with the goal of exploiting insufficient update verification controls in older versions of the software. Security firm Rapid 7 has described Chrysalis as a custom backdoor tool that indicates a sophisticated and permanent threat. The incident highlights the importance of keeping software up to date, especially when it comes to security updates. Notepad++ users are advised to check if they have been affected by the hack.

articles.title: Adobe Animate is shutting down as company focuses on AI
articles.summary: Adobe is discontinuing its 2D animation software, Adobe Animate, citing the product's age and the evolution of technologies that better serve users' needs. The decision comes as the company focuses on AI-powered products, such as Firefly and Photoshop Express with AI assistants. Enterprise customers will receive technical support until March 1, 2029, while other customers will have support through next year. Users are expressing disappointment and frustration on social media, with some calling for Adobe to open-source the software instead of abandoning it. Adobe suggests that users can replace Animate's functionality with other Adobe apps, but does not recommend a direct replacement.

articles.title: ICE, CBP Brag About Stealing A Legally-Impossible $14,000 From US Citizens At The Minneapolis Airport
articles.summary: ICE and CBP have publicly bragged about seizing $14,000 from two US citizens of Somali descent at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport. The individuals were departing on international flights when their undeclared cash was confiscated by HSI St. Paul and CBP. This incident has sparked controversy, with some accusing the agencies of targeting specific communities due to their ethnicity or national origin. The seizure is being framed as a measure to prevent the illegal movement of funds across borders and protect national security. However, critics argue that the amount seized is unusually large for undeclared cash and raises questions about the legitimacy of the confiscation. The incident has also been linked to recent deportation efforts by ICE in Minneapolis, which have been criticized as being driven by anti-immigrant sentiment.

articles.title: China is leading the fight against hidden car door handles
articles.summary: China has become the first country to ban hidden car door handles in new vehicles sold within its borders, effective January 1, 2027. The rule is part of a broader safety policy aimed at preventing occupants from becoming trapped in their cars after accidents. The decision was prompted by numerous fatal incidents involving electric vehicles with concealed door handles, including a crash involving a Xiaomi SU7 sedan. China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology has published the new safety rules, which require mechanical releases on both exterior and interior door handles. This move is seen as a world-first in safety regulations, and other countries may follow suit. Tesla, which popularized the design feature, was not involved in drafting the new standard.

articles.title: Elon Musk’s SpaceX officially acquires Elon Musk’s xAI, with plan to build data centers in space
articles.summary: SpaceX has acquired Elon Musk's artificial intelligence startup, xAI, creating the world's most valuable private company with a combined valuation of $1.25 trillion. The merger aims to build space-based data centers, which Musk believes are necessary for the growth of AI due to the limitations of terrestrial solutions. SpaceX will use satellites to create these data centers, generating a constant stream of revenue for the foreseeable future. The acquisition brings together two companies with financial challenges, with xAI burning $1 billion per month and SpaceX generating 80% of its revenue from launching Starlink satellites. Musk's vision for space-based data centers has sparked controversy over the environmental impact of his existing data centers on Earth.

articles.title: Waymo raises $16B to scale robotaxi fleet internationally
articles.summary: Waymo, the autonomous vehicle company owned by Alphabet, has raised $16 billion in funding to scale its robotaxi fleet internationally. The investment values Waymo at $126 billion and will be used to fuel growth, which has accelerated over the past year. The company plans to expand its service to more than a dozen new cities globally, including London and Tokyo. With 400,000 rides provided every week across six major US metropolitan areas, Waymo is rapidly scaling its commercial reality, despite facing increased scrutiny and criticism due to missteps and safety concerns.

articles.title: Beware: Government Using Image Manipulation For Propaganda
articles.summary: The US government, specifically the White House and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem, has been accused of using image manipulation for propaganda purposes. A photo of Nekima Levy Armstrong's arrest was digitally altered to darken her skin tone and rearrange her facial features, making it appear as if she was distraught. The National Press Photographers Association condemned the alteration, stating that it undermines public trust and is incompatible with professional practice. This incident raises concerns about the government's use of technology to lie to the public and perpetuate racial biases. The manipulation of images has a long history in propaganda, from Nazi Germany's anti-Semitic cartoons to US cartoons depicting Japanese people during World War II. In today's digital age, the danger of abuse by government is greater due to the ease with which photos can be altered.

articles.title: Fintech CEO and Forbes 30 Under 30 alum has been charged for alleged fraud
articles.summary: Gökçe Güven, the 26-year-old founder and CEO of fintech startup Kalder, has been charged with alleged securities fraud, wire fraud, visa fraud, and aggravated identity theft by the US Department of Justice. The charges stem from a $7 million seed round in April 2024, during which Güven allegedly presented a pitch deck containing false information to investors. The government claims that Kalder's financial books were also falsified, with two separate sets of numbers being kept, one of which was presented to investors to hide the company's true financial condition. Güven had previously been featured on Forbes' 30 Under 30 list and claimed to have worked with major clients such as Godiva and the International Air Transport Association. The indictment marks another high-profile case of alleged fraud among Forbes 30 Under 30 alumni, following similar cases involving FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried and others.

articles.title: The CDC Has Mysteriously Frozen Vaccine Databases Without Explanation
articles.summary: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has mysteriously frozen nearly half of its databases without explanation, affecting vaccination data and other critical health information. A study published in the Annals of Internal Medicine found that 38 out of 82 CDC databases were no longer being updated as of October 2025, with 33 of those databases containing vaccination-related data. This has raised concerns among medical professionals and experts, who argue that this lack of data will hinder outbreak response efforts and put Americans at risk of preventable infections. The study's authors suggest that the freeze may be linked to the Secretary of Health and Human Services' vaccine skepticism. The implications are dire, with experts warning that the consequences of this data freeze will be severe.

articles.title: Temu’s global rise runs into a regulatory wall
articles.summary: Temu, a Chinese e-commerce app known for its low prices, has experienced rapid global growth, reaching the top of download charts in 2023 and 2024. However, its success is now being hindered by regulatory issues that have raised concerns about the company's business practices. Temu's model relies on selling products at significantly lower prices than competitors, often through questionable means such as mislabeling or misrepresenting products. This has led to scrutiny from regulators in various countries, who are investigating potential violations of consumer protection laws and intellectual property rights. The regulatory challenges facing Temu threaten to undermine its global expansion plans and may force the company to adapt its business model.

articles.title: Is India softening its stance toward Chinese tech?
articles.summary: The Indian government's stance towards Chinese technology has undergone a significant shift in recent years. In June 2020, India banned 59 Chinese apps citing concerns over national sovereignty and integrity. However, by the end of that year, the ban was relaxed to allow some of these apps back into the market. This change in policy suggests that India may be softening its stance towards Chinese tech. The decision is seen as a significant shift in the country's approach to dealing with China, which has implications for trade and economic ties between the two nations. Experts believe that this move could lead to increased investment from Chinese companies in India. However, some critics argue that allowing Chinese apps back into the market may compromise national security.

articles.title: Avalanche thinks the fusion power industry should think smaller
articles.summary: Avalanche, a nuclear fusion startup, is taking an unconventional approach by developing a "desktop" version of the technology. The company's CEO, Robin Langtry, believes that smaller reactors can be more efficient and allow for faster experimentation and iteration. Avalanche uses electric current to contain plasma particles in an orbit around an electrode, rather than large magnets or lasers used by other companies. The startup has raised $80 million from investors and is testing its devices at a commercial facility called FusionWERX. Langtry thinks that smaller reactors can help the industry overcome challenges and achieve breakeven point faster.

articles.title: The rise of Moltbook suggests viral AI prompts may be the next big security threat
articles.summary: A recent concept, dubbed "prompt worms," has been identified by security researchers as a potential new threat to AI networks. These self-replicating instructions can spread through networks of communicating AI agents, exploiting their core function of following instructions. Unlike traditional malware, prompt worms do not rely on operating system vulnerabilities but rather manipulate the AI's behavior through adversarial prompts. This phenomenon has been predicted by researchers and is reminiscent of the 1988 Morris worm, which caused widespread damage to computer systems. The rise of Moltbook, a platform that enables networks of AI agents to share instructions, may be contributing to this new threat.

articles.title: Vema predicts cheap hydrogen could change where data centers are built
articles.summary: Vema Hydrogen has successfully completed a pilot project in Quebec, Canada, using a novel method to produce hydrogen from iron-rich rock deep underground. The startup's technology, known as stimulated geologic hydrogen or "engineered mineral hydrogen," promises to be one of the cleanest and cheapest sources of hydrogen on the market. Vema plans to drill its first commercial well next year, which will reach 800 meters into the Earth, and expects to produce hydrogen for less than $1 per kilogram. This price is significantly lower than other methods of producing hydrogen, such as steam reformation of methane (SMR), which can cost between 70 cents and $1.60 per kilogram. If Vema's forecasts are correct, its hydrogen could become the cheapest source on the market, potentially changing where data centers are built in regions with suitable geology.

articles.title: India’s Supreme Court to WhatsApp: ‘You cannot play with the right to privacy’
articles.summary: India's Supreme Court delivered a stern warning to Meta, stating that it would not allow the company to "play with the right to privacy" of Indian users. The court expressed concerns over WhatsApp's data-sharing practices and monetization of user metadata, questioning how users can provide meaningful consent in a market where the app is the default communications platform. The judges also pressed Meta on how user data is analyzed beyond message content and its commercial value for targeted advertising. The case stems from a 2021 update to WhatsApp's privacy policy that required Indian users to accept broader data-sharing terms with Meta or stop using the service, leading to a ₹2.13 billion penalty imposed by India's competition regulator. The Supreme Court has adjourned the matter until February 9, allowing Meta and WhatsApp to explain their data practices in greater detail.

articles.title: Whoops, Websites Realize That Killing Their Comment Sections Was A Mistake
articles.summary: News websites are reversing their decision to eliminate comment sections, recognizing the value they bring to public discourse and community engagement. Many editors have had second thoughts about outsourcing comments to Facebook, which has led to homogenized and often toxic discussions. Restoring on-site comment sections with automation-assisted moderation is seen as a way to rekindle functional online conversations and rebuild relationships with readers. This shift acknowledges that participation in journalism can be a key aspect of a news outlet's value proposition. The trend is seen as a step towards reviving local community engagement and improving public discourse.

articles.title: Wedding Photo Booth Company Exposes Customers’ Drunken Photos
articles.summary: A photo booth company, Curator Live, has exposed customers' photos and personal data, including phone numbers, after a security researcher discovered the issue. The company's website allows users to download digital copies of their photos, but it also stores them insecurely, making them accessible to anyone. This is not an isolated incident, as another photo booth company was reported to have had a similar flaw in December. The exposed data includes photos from weddings, lobbying events, and engagement parties, with some showing people drinking and others including children. The researcher who discovered the issue has called it a violation of reasonable expectation of privacy.

articles.title: The State of Open Models
articles.summary: The article discusses a talk about the state of open models, covering key events in 2025 such as DeepSeek kickstarting Chinese open model norms, Llama's decline, and Qwen's dominance. The speaker shares their research on the topic, highlighting the importance of understanding the current landscape to steer it in a better direction. The article recommends watching or listening to the talk for those impacted by discussions around open models or Chinese AI. The speaker also provides links to related content, including slides and podcast episodes.

articles.title: OpenAI Needs $400 Billion In The Next 12 Months
articles.summary: OpenAI is expected to require $400 billion in funding over the next 12 months, according to an analysis by a blogger who has been critical of OpenAI's ambitious plans for data center capacity. The blogger argues that building a gigawatt of data center capacity costs at least $50 billion and takes two and a half years, citing estimates from various sources including Jensen Huang and Barclays Bank. OpenAI has promised 33GW of capacity across multiple partnerships with companies like AMD, NVIDIA, Broadcom, and Stargate, which the blogger claims is an unrealistic goal given the costs involved. The blogger suggests that OpenAI's plans are reckless and involve naked market manipulation.

articles.title: Latest open artifacts (#15): It’s Qwen's world and we get to live in it, on CAISI's report, & GPT-OSS update
articles.summary: The Center for AI Standards and Innovation (CAISI) has released a report evaluating the DeepSeek 3.1 model against leading closed models, highlighting discrepancies in evaluation scores. The CAISI report found that MMLU-Pro, GPQA, and HLE scores were close to self-reported results from DeepSeek, but SWE-bench Verified scores were off by a wide margin due to a weak harness for the benchmark. This discrepancy has implications for the marketing of Claude, an AI model developed by Anthropic, which relies heavily on SWE-bench Verified as a benchmark. The report also highlights the importance of considering the software framework used in agentic benchmarks, known as the "harness," when evaluating model performance.

articles.title: This Is How Much Anthropic and Cursor Spend On Amazon Web Services
articles.summary: The article reveals that Anthropic and AI coding company Cursor are spending massive amounts on Amazon Web Services (AWS). According to exclusive information from sources with direct knowledge of their AWS billing, Anthropic spent over $2.66 billion on compute in 2024 alone, exceeding its estimated revenue of $2.55 billion. This means that Anthropic's spend on AWS accounted for more than 100% of its revenue. Additionally, Cursor's AWS bills have more than doubled from $6.2 million to $12.6 million between May and June 2025. The article suggests that these costs are indicative of a larger trend in the AI industry, where compute costs continue to rise exponentially.

articles.title: How to scale RL
articles.summary: A recent paper, "The Art of Scaling Reinforcement Learning Compute for LLMs," proposes a method to extrapolate RL learning curves over compute scales and sets a baseline for the order of compute required for top-end performance. This breakthrough has significant implications for scaling reinforcement learning (RL) and improving frontier models. The paper, referred to as ScaleRL, is a must-read for anyone interested in understanding cutting-edge RL algorithms and infrastructure. The authors address two major challenges: stable RL training setups and lack of compute for experimentation. Their work provides a clear path forward for academics and practitioners alike.

articles.title: Burning out
articles.summary: The article discusses the intense work culture in the AI industry, particularly in the Large Language Model (LLM) space, where researchers are working long hours to stay ahead of the curve. The author acknowledges that this culture is not unique to AI and has been seen in other industries before, but notes that it's being amplified by the rapid pace of innovation in LLMs. The article highlights the physical and mental toll of this work culture, with some researchers comparing it to war or elite athletics. The author suggests that a more balanced approach to work, including rest and creativity, is necessary to avoid burnout and maintain intellectual acuity.

articles.title: Big Tech Needs $2 Trillion In AI Revenue By 2030 or They Wasted Their Capex
articles.summary: Big Tech companies, including Microsoft, Amazon, Google, and Meta, have spent over $400 billion in capital expenditures on AI infrastructure. This massive investment is expected to reach a total of around $776 billion in three years. However, the industry has been given "incredible" grace by the markets, allowing them to avoid scrutiny of their actual return on investment or demands for disclosure of resulting revenue. As a result, these companies are using their existing growth and successful products to pretend that AI is driving their success, despite evidence suggesting otherwise. The article argues that Big Tech needs $2 trillion in AI revenue by 2030 or they will have "wasted" their capital expenditures.

articles.title: 5 Thoughts on Kimi K2 Thinking
articles.summary: The Moonshot AI team has released Kimi K2 Thinking, a reasoning model with impressive benchmark scores and writing quality. The model is an extension of their original Kimi K2 Instruct model, which was trained using extended thinking RL training. Kimi K2 Thinking has 1T total parameters, 32B active parameters, and a context length of 256K. It has been praised for its ability to reason and generate human-like text. The release has generated excitement in the industry, with rumors of Gemini 3's upcoming launch. However, it still lags behind other models like GPT-5 and Claude Sonnet 4.5 on certain benchmarks.

articles.title: Premium: OpenAI Burned $4.1 Billion More Than We Knew - Where Is Its Money Going?
articles.summary: OpenAI, a leading AI research company backed by Microsoft, has reportedly burned through an additional $4.1 billion in cash beyond what was previously disclosed. This revelation comes after Sam Altman stated that OpenAI's revenues exceeded $13 billion in 2025, which some question based on other outlets' reporting. The company's actual revenue for the first half of 2025 is estimated to be around $8 billion. Meanwhile, Microsoft has funding commitments to OpenAI totaling $13 billion, with $11.6 billion already funded by September 30, 2025. OpenAI's losses have been substantial, with a reported $12 billion loss in the last quarter alone. The company's expenses include significant spending on staff, sales and marketing, real estate, lobbying, data, and inference costs. Despite these high expenses, OpenAI's operations cost over $15 billion in three months, leaving many questions about where this money is going.

articles.title: Opening the black box of character training
articles.summary: Researchers have made progress in character training for AI models, a crucial area of study for creating more human-like and engaging interactions. Character training involves shaping the personality and behavior of AI assistants to make them more relatable and effective. A new paper, "Open Character Training: Shaping the Persona of AI Assistants through Constitutional AI," presents a method for instilling model personalities using data and evaluation work. The authors have released their code and artifacts, making it possible for others to build on this research. This breakthrough has significant implications for the development of more advanced and user-friendly AI systems.

articles.title: Interview: Ant Group's open model ambitions
articles.summary: Ant Group's AI lab, InclusionAI, is making significant strides in open language models. The lab has released several exceptional models, including Ling 1T, which was highlighted in a recent open model roundup. In an interview with Interconnects, Richard Bian, Product & Growth Lead at Ant Ling & InclusionAI, discusses the company's ambitions to catch up to the frontier of AI and its decision-making process for modeling strategies. The Chinese AI ecosystem is prioritizing different directions than the West, focusing on rapid progress in open language models. The interview covers various topics, including what it takes to rapidly gain the ability to train excellent models and how the Chinese ecosystem differs from the Western one.

articles.title: Exclusive: Here's How Much OpenAI Spends On Inference and Its Revenue Share With Microsoft
articles.summary: OpenAI's inference spend on Microsoft Azure has reached $8.67 billion by the end of September 2025, up from $3.76 billion in the same period last year, indicating a significant increase in costs. The company's inference costs have consistently risen over the past 18 months, with $5.02 billion spent in the first half of 2025 alone. OpenAI's revenues, however, remain unclear, but it is reported that Microsoft receives 20% of its revenue as part of their partnership agreement. This has led to concerns that OpenAI's inference costs may be exceeding its revenues.

articles.title: Premium: The Hater's Guide To The AI Bubble Vol. 2
articles.summary: The article critiques the AI industry's inflated revenue projections, citing discrepancies between reported figures and internal documents. OpenAI's spending on inference is reportedly higher than its revenue, with a $5.022 billion expenditure in the first half of 2025 against a minimum revenue of $2.2735 billion. The article questions CEO Sam Altman's claims that OpenAI was profitable on inference and will reach $20 billion in annualized revenue by the end of 2025. Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella is also criticized for downplaying the issue, suggesting that companies make projections to raise money, rather than adhering to reality. The article raises questions about Anthropic's financial health and its ability to achieve profitability.

articles.title: Why AI writing is mid
articles.summary: The author reflects on the limitations of AI writing, citing its inability to produce sustained high-quality text despite advances in other areas like image generation. They argue that this is due to structural issues with current training processes and market pressures that prioritize predictability over style and quality. The author identifies several problems, including a lack of focus on style as a leading objective, the suppression of quirks by aggregate preferences, and financial biases against complex writing. They propose that creating a language model capable of great writing would require giving it a strong personality and sense of self.

articles.title: Olmo 3: America’s truly open reasoning models
articles.summary: The AI2 team has released Olmo 3, a family of fully open language models that includes the best 32B base model and the first 32B or larger fully open reasoning model. The models are available with full training data, code, intermediate checkpoints, training logs, and a detailed technical report. This release is considered a milestone for the viability of fully open-source models, as they are competitive on performance rather than just replicating older models. The Olmo 3 family includes three models: the best 32B base model, the best 7B Western-origin thinking & instruct models, and the first 32B or larger fully open reasoning model.

articles.title: Latest open artifacts (#16): Who's building models in the U.S., China's model release playbook, and a resurgence of truly open models
articles.summary: The article highlights the US-based AI labs that are actively releasing high-quality open models, comparable to China's 20 labs. The list includes notable recent models from companies such as Ai2, Google, HuggingFace, IBM, and Microsoft, among others. These models are often smaller in size but have more restrictive licenses, limiting their impact. The article also mentions some US-based labs that are not actively releasing open models, including Meta, Reka, and xAI. The author emphasizes the importance of truly open models and highlights a few players with significant momentum, such as Ai2, Nvidia, Arcee, and Reflection.

articles.title: Premium: The Hater's Guide To NVIDIA
articles.summary: The article provides an in-depth analysis of NVIDIA, a company that has become a dominant player in the stock market. Despite its significant size, few people understand the company's inner workings. NVIDIA sells GPUs that power large language models and other AI-related services, which have become crucial for the tech industry. The company's proprietary software layer, CUDA, gives it an advantage over competitors. NVIDIA acquired Mellanox in 2019, allowing it to sell high-speed networking technology alongside its GPUs. This acquisition created a strong value proposition for data center customers, leading to billions of dollars in revenue. The article aims to explain the complexities of NVIDIA's business model and raise questions about the company's dominance.

articles.title: Premium: The Ways The AI Bubble Might Burst
articles.summary: The article discusses the potential bursting of the AI bubble, citing inconsistencies in NVIDIA's GPU shipments and Anthropic's revenue claims. It questions why Gemini 3 is considered significantly better than other AI models, and whether this is a genuine improvement or an excuse to cover up ChatGPT's slowing growth. Experts suggest that OpenAI's growth was decelerating before the release of Gemini 3, which may be used as a convenient explanation for their struggles. The article also mentions OpenAI's efforts to improve features of ChatGPT and other AI models.

articles.title: NVIDIA Isn't Enron - So What Is It?
articles.summary: NVIDIA released an internal memo addressing concerns about the company's accounting practices and comparisons to Enron. The memo, which was leaked to Barron's reporter Tae Kim, aims to reassure investors that NVIDIA is not like Enron and has transparent financial dealings. However, critics have pointed out flaws in NVIDIA's arguments, including a piece by Shanaka Anslem Perera that alleged the company's involvement in a circular financing scheme. Despite these concerns, the author of this article agrees with NVIDIA that it is "nothing like Enron" and attributes the comparison to misinformation spread by critics.

articles.title: New Talk: Building Olmo 3 Think
articles.summary: The author has released a public version of their talk on building Olmo 3 Think, a reasoning model. The talk covers the entire process, from pretraining to post-training, with a focus on reinforcement learning infrastructure and evaluating reasoning models. The author has given this talk at various conferences, including COLM and The PyTorch Conference, and is now sharing it publicly. The talk includes discussions on midtraining data, long-context necessity, building SFT data, and scaling RL. The author invites feedback and suggestions for improvement.

articles.title: 2025 Open Models Year in Review
articles.summary: The article highlights the growth and advancements of open models in the AI ecosystem over the past year. In 2025, open models have become more capable and widespread, rivaling closed models on key benchmarks. The article mentions specific models such as DeepSeek R1 and Qwen 3, which have gained popularity and influence. It also notes that Chinese companies have started to adopt open models, contributing to the ecosystem's growth. The article concludes by announcing a tier list of model makers across the US, China, and globally.

articles.title: Premium: Mythbusters - AI Edition
articles.summary: Oracle's recent earnings report revealed a significant increase in capital expenditures, exceeding analyst estimates by $4 billion. The company also announced $523 billion in remaining performance obligations (RPOs), including new commitments from Meta and NVIDIA. However, it was discovered that NVIDIA had agreed to buy $26 billion in cloud compute deals, sparking questions about the true nature of AI demand. Analysts and journalists have been accused of perpetuating a "mythology" around AI, where companies are buying GPUs for imaginary demand and software is sold based on unproven claims. This has led to a culture of propaganda and lies, with those who question the narrative facing skepticism and ire.

articles.title: 2025 Interconnects year in review
articles.summary: The author of the Interconnects blog reflects on the year 2025, which was marked by significant growth in readership and influence. The blog's content focused on AI research, with a particular emphasis on reinforcement learning and open models. The author launched two major projects: the ATOM Project and the SAIL Bundle, both of which aim to promote American open models. Despite feeling tired from a busy year, the author is content with their contributions to the AI world and plans to continue investing in these projects in 2026.

articles.title: Open models: Hot or Not with Nathan Lambert & Florian Brand
articles.summary: Nathan Lambert hosts a discussion with Florian Brand, an open model analyst, to review the year 2025 in open models. They delve into which labs won and lost momentum, discussing Reflection 70B, Huawei's repackaging of someone else's model as their own, and the fall of Llama. The conversation also touches on the nuances not covered in a previous post, predictions for GPT-OSS 2, and the American-Chinese balance at the end of 2026.

articles.title: Premium - How The AI Bubble Bursts In 2026
articles.summary: The AI industry has faced a grim week with several negative developments. Disney is investing $1 billion in OpenAI, but the deal involves OpenAI paying for licensing rights to Disney's characters in stock warrants. Amazon is also considering a $10 billion investment in OpenAI at a valuation of over $500 billion, but this may be a situation where money changes hands between the two companies without actual funding being secured. Oracle has delayed several data centers being built for OpenAI due to labor and material shortages, and Blue Owl has pulled out of funding a $10 billion deal for an Oracle/OpenAI data center in Michigan. These developments suggest that the AI industry may be facing financial difficulties.

articles.title: The Fight Against Presidential Targeting of Law Firms: 2025 in Review
articles.summary: The US legal profession faced a significant threat in 2025 when the Trump administration targeted law firms that had supported investigations against him or litigated against his interests. The retaliation included stripping security clearances from lawyers and threatening to revoke government contracts. Despite some law firms capitulating, others sued to undo the actions against them, with EFF joining amicus briefs in each case. Over 500 law firms across the country joined supportive amicus briefs, and eventually, other organizations began to speak out against the administration's actions. The incident highlighted the importance of pro bono work and the need for legal professionals to stand up against government overreach.

articles.title: AI Police Reports: Year In Review
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has been tracking the use of artificial intelligence (AI) in police reports, citing concerns over transparency and accountability. Despite warnings from prosecutors in Washington state, AI-generated police reports have proliferated, with Axon's Draft One being a popular tool for law enforcement agencies. EFF has published reports highlighting the lack of transparency in Draft One, which erases initial drafts and makes it difficult to determine what parts of the report were written by AI or an officer. However, two states, Utah and California, have passed bills requiring police departments to disclose when AI-generated reports are used and to retain original drafts for auditing purposes.

articles.title: How to Sustain Privacy & Free Speech
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) is calling on supporters to donate to their cause, which aims to protect digital rights and promote free speech. The organization has set a Year-End Challenge goal, where donations made by December 31 will unlock bonus grants that increase in size as more people support the cause. EFF members have raised over $400,000 for digital rights in the past year, funding court motions, software development, educational campaigns, and investigations. The organization fights for tech users in courts, lobbies lawmakers, and develops free privacy-enhancing technology to protect individuals online. Donations of any size can help make a difference and support EFF's mission.

articles.title: Politicians Rushed Through An Online Speech “Solution.” Victims Deserve Better.
articles.summary: The TAKE IT DOWN Act, a bill aimed at combating non-consensual intimate imagery (NCII) online, was passed by Congress and signed into law despite concerns from digital rights groups. The bill creates an unneeded notice-and-takedown system that threatens free expression, user privacy, and due process. Critics argue that the law's broad definition of NCII could lead to the removal of lawful speech, and its fast timeline discourages providers from standing up for users' free speech rights. Digital rights organizations had asked for changes to protect legitimate speech and include safeguards for encryption, but their efforts were unsuccessful.

articles.title: EFF’s ‘How to Fix the Internet’ Podcast: 2025 in Review
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has released its sixth season of the "How to Fix the Internet" podcast, which explores creative solutions to tech challenges. The podcast features conversations with leading minds in law and technology, including EFF Executive Director Cindy Cohn and Activism Director Jason Kelley. This season's episodes focus on topics such as digital autonomy, human-centered internet design, and the importance of loving technology before criticizing it. Guests include experts like Kate Bertash and Molly White, who discuss how to center people in the digital world and create a more open and participatory internet.

articles.title: Age Verification Threats Across the Globe: 2025 in Review
articles.summary: Governments worldwide have implemented or attempted to introduce age verification legislation to protect young people online. However, critics argue that such measures are ineffective and infringe on users' rights to anonymity, privacy, and security. The UK's Online Safety Act has been criticized for its chaotic rollout, while France's highest court ruled in favor of age verification for porn websites. Australia has implemented a ban on under-16s accessing social media, requiring platforms to introduce age assurance tools. The European Commission is testing an age-verification app, and the EU Parliament has proposed a digital minimum age of 16 for access to social media. Critics argue that these measures are censorship laws that hurt marginalized communities.

articles.title: Artificial Intelligence, Copyright, and the Fight for User Rights: 2025 in Review
articles.summary: The year 2025 saw a surge in copyright lawsuits against AI developers, threatening the beneficial uses of AI in creative expression, legal research, and scientific advancement. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) intervened to defend fair use, promote competition, and protect user rights. Courts began to consider the application of fair use to AI training, with some cases reaching appeals courts. EFF filed amicus briefs in several key cases, advocating for fair use rights and sensible limits on copyright. Meanwhile, rightsholders attempted to control fair uses through state laws and technical standards that could harm the open web.

articles.title: Defending Access to Abortion Information Online: 2025 in Review
articles.summary: Reproductive rights activists and healthcare providers rely on the internet to access and share information about abortion, especially in states where it is heavily restricted or banned. However, both governments and private platforms are increasingly censoring abortion-related speech online, making it harder for people to find critical resources and discuss legal options. Social media platforms have been cracking down on abortion-related content, leading to suppression, shadow-banning, and removal of posts and accounts. In response, the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) launched a campaign to expose social media censorship and hold platforms accountable. The campaign collected nearly 100 submissions from users who had their abortion-related content censored, revealing a pattern of over-enforcement, lack of transparency, and arbitrary moderation decisions.

articles.title: Fighting to Keep Bad Patents in Check: 2025 in Review
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) fought to prevent two damaging bills, PERA and PREVAIL, from passing in Congress. These bills aimed to weaken the patent system by overturning key court decisions and limiting challenges to bad patents. Despite EFF's efforts, the bills stalled out due to public opposition. Meanwhile, the US Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) made moves to dismantle systems that protect the public from bad patents, including a proposal to make inter partes review (IPR) nearly unusable.

articles.title: States Take On Tough Tech Policy Battles: 2025 in Review
articles.summary: State legislatures across the US took on various tech policy battles in 2025, with some notable wins and losses. Washington became the eighth state to enshrine the right to repair, while several states protected location data and health privacy. California passed a law making it easier for people to exercise their privacy rights under the state's consumer data privacy law. However, other states introduced bills that threatened digital rights, including Florida's anti-encryption bill and age verification laws in South Dakota and Wyoming. These laws can incentivize data collection and force users to verify their identity to access basic content or products.

articles.title: Local Communities Are Winning Against ALPR Surveillance—Here’s How: 2025 in Review
articles.summary: In 2025, local communities across the US successfully campaigned against automated license plate reader (ALPR) surveillance systems, winning contract cancellations in cities such as Austin, Texas; Cambridge, Massachusetts; and Eugene, Oregon. The campaigns combined three key elements: a motivated city council champion, grassroots community pressure, and technical assistance at critical decision moments. By focusing on the practical wins of contract termination rather than perfect policies, organizers were able to stop surveillance where it starts – at the checkbook. These victories built a culture of refusal that made future rejections easier, demonstrating the effectiveness of the "ugly" win approach.

articles.title: From Speakeasies to DEF CON—Celebrating With EFF Members: 2025 Year In Review
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) celebrates its members and supporters in a year-end review. The organization highlights its efforts to protect digital freedom, including lawsuits against the government and industry players. EFF members were invited to exclusive meetups, known as Speakeasies, which took place across the US and online. The group also participated in summer security conferences, including DEF CON, and hosted a poker tournament at the event. Throughout the year, EFF staff connected with supporters, handed out swag, and engaged in conversations about digital rights.

articles.title: Lawmakers Must Listen to Young People Before Regulating Their Internet Access: 2025 in Review
articles.summary: Lawmakers have introduced proposals to restrict internet access for children and teenagers, citing concerns over "harmful" content. However, these efforts ignore the positive experiences of young people online and violate their First Amendment rights. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has advocated for minors' rights, reminding lawmakers that they have a right to express themselves online and control how they access information. Restricting internet access harms minors who rely on it for community, resources, and health information. These laws also threaten adults' rights by promoting invasive age-verification technology and infringing on the right to anonymity online.

articles.title: Defending Encryption in the U.S. and Abroad: 2025 in Review
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has been fighting to defend encryption against various attempts to break it around the world. In Europe, the EU Council's "Chat Control" proposal, which would require secure messaging providers to scan messages, was repeatedly rejected due to concerns about breaking end-to-end encryption. France also tried to pass legislation allowing law enforcement to silently join encrypted chats, but it was rejected by the National Assembly. Meanwhile, in the UK, Apple was ordered to backdoor its iCloud encryption, and although the demand was later rewritten, EFF continues to monitor developments. In the US, attempts to compromise encryption included the re-introduction of the STOP CSAM Act and a bill in Florida that demanded a backdoor into encryption services.

articles.title: Procurement Power—When Cities Realized They Can Just Say No: 2025 in Review
articles.summary: In 2025, cities across the US began to treat surveillance technology purchases as political decisions rather than administrative necessities. This shift led to at least 23 jurisdictions canceling or rejecting Flock Safety ALPR programs, with some cities citing concerns over lack of safeguards and community pressure. The change in approach was driven by audit findings, growing community organizing, and elected officials recognizing the power of saying "no" to surveillance technology renewals. Cities like Austin, Oak Park, and Eugene have set a precedent for treating surveillance procurement as a political decision rather than an administrative routine. This shift has broken the dynamic of information asymmetry between cities and vendors, where cities became dependent on vendors for critical data governance decisions.

articles.title: EFFector Audio Speaks Up for Our Rights: 2025 Year in Review
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has been actively advocating for digital rights and civil liberties in 2025. Through its revamped newsletter, EFFector, the organization has launched an audio companion that features exclusive interviews with experts on various topics such as surveillance, free speech, and innovation. The podcast has covered issues like social media spying schemes, mass surveillance of drivers through Automated License Plate Readers (ALPRs), and face recognition in consumer devices. EFF's lawyers, activists, and technologists have also shared tips on how to protect online privacy and security. The organization has been actively involved in lawsuits challenging government and corporate actions that infringe on digital rights.

articles.title: Drone as First Responder Programs: 2025 in Review
articles.summary: Drone as First Responder (DFR) programs experienced significant growth in 2025, with more normalization of the technology and its integration into real-time crime centers. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) streamlined the waiver process for deploying drones beyond visual line of sight, approving over 400 waivers in just two months. Major drone manufacturers, including DJI, faced regulatory challenges, while police departments and tech companies collaborated on automated drone deployment and advanced surveillance capabilities. Transparency around DFR deployments remains a concern, with EFF encouraging citizens to use public records laws to investigate local programs.

articles.title: EFF in the Press: 2025 in Review
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) had a significant presence in the media in 2025, with thousands of mentions across various outlets. EFF's work on digital civil liberties, including street-level surveillance and automated license plate readers, generated substantial press attention. The organization also filed three lawsuits against the federal government, which received widespread coverage. EFF staffers appeared on national television shows, such as NBC Nightly News and ABC's Good Morning America, to discuss topics like police use of private doorbell cameras and digital price tags. Additionally, EFF was cited in mainstream national media outlets, including The Washington Post, CNN, and the New York Times, as well as tech and legal media publications.

articles.title: Operations Security (OPSEC) Trainings: 2025 in Review
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) provided operations security (OPSEC) trainings to over 66 groups and organizations, reaching at least 2000 participants, in 2025. The trainings focused on digital privacy and information security strategies for liberation movement workers, including threat modeling, cybersecurity basics, secure communications practices, and doxxing self-defense. These efforts were particularly aimed at under-resourced groups advocating for abortion access, transgender rights, and climate justice. EFF's work in this area allows them to stress-test their Surveillance Self-Defense project and inform blog posts on topics such as tech-enabled violence against transgender people and digital threats in the abortion access movement.

articles.title: The Enshittifinancial Crisis
articles.summary: The author reflects on the Enshittifinancial Crisis, a phenomenon where companies prioritize growth over actual problem-solving, leading to financial waste and neglect of essential social needs. The crisis is fueled by private equity firms, business development companies, venture capitalists, and banks that seek short-term gains through reckless investments. This era is characterized by the "free market" being a con, where individuals are exploited for profit, while entities that can funnel more money into the economy are incentivized to survive. The author argues that this crisis meets Cory Doctorow's Enshittification Theory and their own Rot Economy Thesis in a fourth stage of Enshittification.

articles.title: Fighting Renewed Attempts to Make ISPs Copyright Cops: 2025 in Review
articles.summary: The Supreme Court is set to make a crucial decision on whether internet service providers (ISPs) should be held liable for copyright infringement committed by their subscribers. A lower court's ruling, if upheld, could force ISPs to terminate internet access based on mere accusations of infringement, threatening innocent users who rely on broadband for essential daily activities. The case has significant implications for public libraries, universities, hospitals, and local governments that share internet connections, as well as households in low-income communities. EFF and other organizations have filed an amicus brief urging the Court to reverse the lower court's decision, citing patent law precedent.

articles.title: EFF's Investigations Expose Flock Safety's Surveillance Abuses: 2025 in Review
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) conducted investigations throughout 2025 into Flock Safety's automated license plate reader (ALPR) network, revealing a system designed for mass surveillance with potential for grave abuses. The research exposed how law enforcement agencies used the system to track protesters exercising their First Amendment rights, target Romani people with discriminatory searches, and surveil women seeking reproductive healthcare. EFF's findings sparked state and federal investigations, landmark litigation, and drove Flock Safety to implement feature updates that ultimately cannot make ALPRs safe. The investigations also highlighted the dangers of Flock's business model, which relies on building a nationwide surveillance network that creates inherent risks.

articles.title: Site Blocking Laws Will Always Be a Bad Idea: 2025 in Review
articles.summary: Site blocking laws, which would allow the government and copyright holders to quickly shut down entire websites based on allegations of piracy, have been proposed again in 2025 despite being widely criticized over a decade ago. Three Congressional drafts of site-blocking legislation were introduced this year, but none gained significant traction. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) opposes these efforts, arguing that site blocking is a flawed idea and a disaster for free expression. They claim that the technical means of implementing site blocking are blunt and can cause digital collateral damage, while also being trivially easy to evade.

articles.title: States Tried to Censor Kids Online. Courts, and EFF, Mostly Stopped Them: 2025 in Review
articles.summary: In 2025, lawmakers in multiple states attempted to pass laws restricting minors' access to social media or requiring parental permission before logging on. However, courts across the country have largely ruled these laws unconstitutional, citing First Amendment rights violations. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has filed friend-of-the-court briefs in numerous cases, arguing that such laws burden both young people's and adults' rights to free speech, privacy, and data security. EFF emphasizes that minors have long had the same First Amendment rights as adults and that these laws are an overreach. The organization will continue to fight for internet access, free speech, and online organizing.

articles.title: Congress's Crusade to Age Gate the Internet: 2025 in Review
articles.summary: Congress introduced numerous bills in 2025 aimed at "protecting kids online" through age-verification checks, which would have undermined privacy and stifled free speech. The Kids Online Safety Act (KOSA) was a major threat, with its broad definition of harms to minors potentially sweeping up online speech about sensitive topics. Despite claims that the bill wouldn't censor viewpoints, experts argue it's an unconstitutional censorship measure that would incentivize age-verification systems, burdening adults' rights to read and speak anonymously online. The bills stalled, but KOSA remains a concern due to its momentum in previous Congresses.

articles.title: 2025, A Retrospective
articles.summary: The author of the newsletter "Where's Your Red?" reflects on their accomplishments in 2025, which they consider an "insane" year. They highlight several notable achievements, including being quoted by Cory Doctorow in his new book, recording over 110 episodes of their tech podcast "Better Offline," and winning a Webby Award for best business podcast episode. The author also mentions writing over 440,000 words, growing their newsletter from 47,000 to 88,500 subscribers, and publishing several notable articles on topics such as AI, the tech industry, and business. They express gratitude to their readers and encourage them to support their work by subscribing to their premium newsletter.

articles.title: Surveillance Self-Defense: 2025 Year in Review
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation's (EFF) Surveillance Self-Defense (SSD) guides had a significant year, with several large updates to existing guides and the release of three new ones. The most popular guide remained "Attending a Protest," which was updated to reflect current events. The SSD team also slimmed down their encryption guides, making them more concise and accessible. New guides were launched on iPhone and Android privacy settings, as well as managing one's digital footprint. Other updates included overhauling device encryption guides for Windows, Mac, and Linux, and updating the password manager and VPN guides.

articles.title: The Year States Chose Surveillance Over Safety: 2025 in Review
articles.summary: In 2025, age verification laws swept across the United States, with half of the country now mandating age checks for accessing adult content or social media platforms. However, courts have blocked many of these laws, citing concerns over censorship and infringement on free speech rights. Despite this, nine states implemented age verification measures, which have largely been circumvented by users who continue to access restricted content through alternative means. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has launched a resource hub to educate the public about the risks associated with age verification and provide guidance on protecting online privacy and security.

articles.title: Latest open artifacts (#17): NVIDIA, Arcee, Minimax, DeepSeek, Z.ai and others close an eventful year on a high note
articles.summary: The latest open artifacts from NVIDIA, Arcee, Minimax, DeepSeek, Z.ai, and others have been released, marking a strong end to 2025. These models include the GLM 4.7 and MiniMax M2.1, which are considered "good enough" in the Claude Code form factor. NVIDIA has also released an updated Nemotron series, featuring a MoE architecture and two new sizes slated for release in H1 2026. Additionally, LLM360 has released a fully open-source model series, including a 70B dense model with pre-training data and multiple checkpoints from various stages of training. These releases demonstrate the growing trend towards openness in the AI model community.

articles.title: The Homeland Security Spending Trail: How to Follow the Money Through U.S. Government Databases
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) and the Heinrich Boell Foundation have released an updated database of vendors providing technology to components of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS). The dataset includes new vendor profiles, fields, and data on top contractors, making it easier for journalists and researchers to investigate DHS spending. A guide is provided to help navigate government databases, including FPDS.gov and USASpending.gov, which track federal discretionary spending and contracts. The guide covers research methods and tips for searching these sites efficiently.

articles.title: EFFecting Change: The Human Cost of Online Age Verification
articles.summary: Age verification mandates are spreading globally, requiring websites and apps to collect sensitive user data through invasive methods. These laws aim to protect children online but have unintended consequences, including increased surveillance, censorship, and exclusion of certain groups. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) is hosting a livestream event to discuss the human cost of online age verification and its impact on free expression and privacy for people of all ages.

articles.title: 8 plots that explain the state of open models
articles.summary: The article discusses the current state of open models in AI, specifically highlighting China's growing lead in adoption metrics. Chinese companies such as Qwen and DeepSeek have dominated the market, with their models being used across various tasks. The US and EU-based models that defined the early eras of open language models are no longer the default choice. Despite this, there is still opportunity for US-based models to regain prominence, particularly in areas where GPT-OSS has shown strength. The article presents several plots illustrating the adoption metrics and market share of different models.

articles.title: ICE Is Going on a Surveillance Shopping Spree
articles.summary: U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) is set to receive a significant budget increase of $28.7 billion for 2025, nearly tripling their previous year's budget. This allocation would make ICE one of the most well-funded agencies in the world, rivaling national militaries. The agency has been criticized for its surveillance practices, which have targeted various groups including undocumented immigrants, asylum seekers, and even U.S. citizens. A 2022 report found that ICE had access to driver's license data and was tracking the movements of drivers in many cities. With this increased budget, ICE is expected to expand its surveillance capabilities, creating one of the largest domestic surveillance machines in history.

articles.title: How Hackers Are Fighting Back Against ICE
articles.summary: Hackers are fighting back against ICE by developing counter-surveillance technologies to protect their communities. One such project is Flock, a company behind automated license plate readers (ALPR) and other camera technologies that have been installed in many US cities. To combat this, the OUI-SPY, an open-source hardware device, has been developed to detect Flock cameras and other surveillance technologies. The Wigle app, primarily designed for mapping out Wi-Fi, also has the ability to alert users when specific devices are detected. Additionally, a YouTuber has discovered a way to fool Flock cameras into not recording license plates by adding visual noise. These efforts aim to expose and counter ICE's widespread surveillance.

articles.title: Claude Code Hits Different
articles.summary: The author is ecstatic about the latest version of Claude Code with Opus 4.5, calling it a "watershed moment" that has revolutionized software creation by making it an industrial process rather than an artisanal one. The model's performance jump seems to have occurred weeks after its release, and the author attributes this to a small product change or perceived gain in performance. They believe that Claude Code is now capable of building complex applications with ease, making it accessible to people who don't know how to code. This development has significant implications for the software industry, favoring small organizations and startups over large corporations.

articles.title: Use multiple models
articles.summary: The author discusses their current AI stack, which includes a mix of models from various providers for different tasks such as chat, code generation, and image processing. They rely heavily on GPT 5.2 Thinking/Pro for research and information gathering, Claude Opus 4.5 for coding and feedback, and Gemini 3 Pro for general-purpose conversations. The author also uses other models like Grok 4 and Nano Banana Pro for specific tasks. They highlight the strengths and weaknesses of each model and provide insights into their usage patterns.

articles.title: So, You’ve Hit an Age Gate. What Now?
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) opposes mandatory age verification laws and guides users on how to navigate age gates with minimal risk to personal information. The article provides questions to ask when selecting a verification method, including data requirements, access, retention, audits, visibility, and answers these questions for popular social media sites. EFF recommends submitting the least amount of data possible and being aware of potential biases in facial age estimation solutions. Users are encouraged to consider their own needs and preferences when deciding how to verify their age.

articles.title: Bandcamp bans purely AI-generated music from its platform
articles.summary: Bandcamp has announced a new policy prohibiting purely AI-generated music on its platform. The decision aims to protect the community of human artists and maintain the authenticity of creative work on the site. While some argue that AI tools can be used as creative assistance, Bandcamp's policy targets music generated entirely or substantially by AI. Users are encouraged to flag suspected AI-generated content through reporting tools. This move contrasts with Spotify, which permits AI-generated music but has faced issues with artificial streaming fraud and an influx of AI-created tracks.

articles.title: A single click mounted a covert, multistage attack against Copilot
articles.summary: Microsoft has fixed a vulnerability in its Copilot AI assistant that allowed hackers to steal sensitive user data with a single click on a legitimate URL. White-hat researchers from Varonis demonstrated the attack, which bypassed enterprise endpoint security controls and detection by endpoint protection apps. The multistage attack extracted user secrets, sent web requests, and obtained additional details such as username and location. The vulnerability was exploited through a carefully crafted prompt that embedded malicious instructions in the form of a query parameter. The attack continued to run even after the user closed the Copilot chat window. Microsoft has since fixed the issue.

articles.title: Wikipedia signs major AI firms to new priority data access deals
articles.summary: The Wikimedia Foundation has announced new API access deals with major AI firms, including Microsoft, Meta, Amazon, Perplexity, and Mistral AI. These companies will pay for high-volume access to Wikipedia's 65 million articles through the foundation's commercial subsidiary, Wikimedia Enterprise. The deals are part of an effort to get tech giants to financially support Wikipedia, which relies on small public donations despite its content being widely used in AI model training. The revenue generated from these deals will help offset infrastructure costs for the nonprofit organization. With Google already signed up in 2022, most major AI developers have now joined Wikimedia Enterprise's program. The foundation did not disclose the financial terms of the new deals.

articles.title: Report: ICE Using Palantir Tool That Feeds On Medicaid Data
articles.summary: A recent report by 404 Media reveals that Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) is using a Palantir tool called Enhanced Leads Identification & Targeting for Enforcement (ELITE) to identify potential deportation targets. The tool populates a map with addresses from various sources, including Medicaid data, and provides a "confidence score" on the person's current address. This tool has raised concerns about the consolidation of government records and the potential for abuse of power. EFF had previously warned about the dangers of Palantir's involvement in government surveillance and had challenged ICE's grab for Medicaid data. The revelation comes as ICE is increasing its presence in Minneapolis, sparking concerns about civil rights.

articles.title: Pluralistic: How the Light Gets In (15 Jan 2026)
articles.summary: The author reflects on the importance of hope versus optimism in navigating dark times. They distinguish between happiness as a fleeting experience and optimism as a toxic mindset that denies human agency. Hope, on the other hand, is the belief that collective action can lead to positive change, even if it's incremental. The author cites their recent speech at the 39th Chaos Communications Congress, where they argued that the decline of the US market for global exporters has created an opportunity to challenge anti-circumvention laws and create "disenshittification nations" that can disrupt the dominance of tech giants.

articles.title: TSMC says AI demand is “endless” after record Q4 earnings
articles.summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) reported record fourth-quarter earnings and expressed optimism about future demand for artificial intelligence (AI) chips. CEO C.C. Wei stated that AI chip demand is "endless" and will continue for years, driven by its growing presence in daily life. TSMC's strong performance signals continued growth expectations from companies designing AI chips, including Apple, Nvidia, AMD, and Qualcomm. The company's factories in Taiwan are a critical component of the global electronics supply chain and have become a focal point of US-China tensions over technology and trade. Wei emphasized that while he cannot predict the long-term trajectory of the semiconductor industry, he is bullish on AI's potential. TSMC's record earnings and spending plans indicate sustained growth in the AI chip market. The company's confidence in AI's future prospects has implications for the broader electronics industry.

articles.title: Premium: This Is Worse Than The Dot Com Bubble
articles.summary: The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) 2026 was a showcase of empty promises and exaggerated claims from tech companies. Many demos were nothing more than marketing gimmicks, with products that had no intention of being released or were simply rehashed versions of existing technology. The article highlights the misuse of AI-powered Large Language Models (LLMs) in various products, such as Lenovo's Qira chatbot, which is essentially a forced feature on Lenovo PCs. Other companies like Samsung and Google are also peddling LLM-based features that consumers don't need or want. The article concludes that CES 2026 was a reflection of the industry's lack of innovation and its reliance on gimmicks to generate buzz.

articles.title: Pluralistic: Catch this! (16 Jan 2026)
articles.summary: The author discusses their enthusiasm for "lifehacking" or improving their organizational processes to increase productivity. They share their personal experiences with various tools and habits, such as browser tabs, to-do lists, and RSS readers, which they claim have transformed their life. The author acknowledges that some people may view these practices as "productivity porn" or a way to deny actual work, but argues that there is a solid foundation beneath the hype. They emphasize the importance of finding tools and systems that work for each individual and encourage experimentation.

articles.title: Congress Wants To Hand Your Parenting to Big Tech
articles.summary: The Senate Commerce Committee held a hearing on the impact of technology on America's youth, with lawmakers discussing a bill called the Kids Off Social Media Act (KOSMA) aimed at protecting children and empowering parents. However, critics argue that the bill actually hands control to Big Tech, rather than giving parents more say in their child's online activities. The bill would ban kids under 13 from social media, but this is already a rule followed by most major platforms. Studies show that most under-13 social media use is family-mediated and with parental knowledge or direct help. KOSMA forces platforms to police families, overriding the decisions made by parents.

articles.title: Baton Rouge Acquires a Straight-Up Military Surveillance Drone
articles.summary: The Baton Rouge Police Department has acquired a military-grade surveillance drone, the Stalker VXE30, designed by Lockheed Martin and Edge Autonomy. This marks one of the first times a local police department in the US has deployed an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) with extensive surveillance capabilities. The $1 million drone can fly for dozens of miles, access private property, and be equipped with additional camera-based surveillance tools like automated license plate readers and face recognition software. Concerns about drones accessing private spaces, storing and sharing footage, and installing biometric analysis raise red flags about the militarization of local law enforcement. The acquisition sets a concerning precedent for other police departments to follow.

articles.title: Mandiant releases rainbow table that cracks weak admin password in 12 hours
articles.summary: Mandiant has released a rainbow table that can crack weak administrative passwords protected by Microsoft's NTLM.v1 hash algorithm in under 12 hours using consumer-grade hardware. The database is designed to nudge users who continue to use the deprecated function despite known weaknesses. NTLMv1 remains in use on some sensitive networks due to legacy app compatibility issues and concerns about downtime during migration. Mandiant aims to lower the barrier for security professionals to demonstrate the insecurity of Net-NTLMv1, making it easier for them to crack passwords and raise awareness about the risks. The table is hosted in Google Cloud and can be used by defenders, researchers, and malicious hackers alike.

articles.title: OpenAI to test ads in ChatGPT as it burns through billions
articles.summary: OpenAI has announced plans to test advertisements within its ChatGPT app for some US users, marking a reversal from CEO Sam Altman's previous stance on advertising. The move aims to expand the customer base and diversify revenue streams. Ads will appear at the bottom of answers in the free version of ChatGPT and the new $8 per month ChatGPT Go plan, but not for users on more expensive tiers. OpenAI believes that a diverse revenue model, including ads, can make intelligence more accessible to everyone. The company has also introduced shopping features to ChatGPT Search, which some saw as a potential step towards advertising. This move follows Google's similar testing of AdSense ads in chatbot experiences through partnerships with AI startups.

articles.title: EFF to California Appeals Court: First Amendment Protects Journalist from Tech Executive’s Meritless Lawsuit
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) is urging a California appeals court to uphold a lower court's decision to dismiss a lawsuit brought by tech executive Maury Blackman against journalist Jack Poulson and others. The lawsuit aimed to silence reporting on Blackman's felony domestic violence arrest, which was deemed a matter of public interest. EFF argues that the First Amendment protects Poulson's right to publish truthful information about the incident, and that Blackman's claims are meritless.

articles.title: Rackspace customers grapple with “devastating” email hosting price hike
articles.summary: Rackspace has implemented a significant price hike for its email hosting services, with some customers facing increases of up to 706%. The new pricing model charges $10 per mailbox per month for the standard plan, with additional fees for add-ons. This change has been met with criticism from Rackspace's reseller partners, who claim it will have a major impact on their ability to make money. Some partners were given only a month-and-a-half notice of the price increase, which they argue is insufficient time to adjust. The move has sparked concerns about the long-term viability of email hosting services for small businesses and individuals.

articles.title: EFF Condemns FBI Search of Washington Post Reporter’s Home
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has condemned the FBI's search of Washington Post reporter Hannah Natanson's home, seizing her phone, laptops, and other devices. The EFF joined 30 other press freedom and civil liberties organizations in criticizing the action as a form of government intimidation against journalists. The First Amendment is designed to prevent such abuses of power, which threaten not only journalists but also the public's right to know about government activities. The EFF has called on Congress to exercise oversight over the Department of Justice (DOJ), reintroduce and pass the PRESS Act, reform the Espionage Act, and confirm that recording law enforcement activity is protected by the First Amendment.

articles.title: Pluralistic: The world needs an Ireland for disenshittification (17 Jan 2026)
articles.summary: Ireland has become a tax haven, allowing companies to evade taxes by pretending to be headquartered there. This has given Ireland an economic boost, but also made it a captured state beholden to corporate interests. The article suggests that other countries could follow Ireland's example and create their own "disenshittification" nations, where they can offer services or products that are not available elsewhere. This could potentially disrupt the global order and create new opportunities for growth and innovation.

articles.title: 10 things I learned from burning myself out with AI coding agents
articles.summary: The author shares their personal experience of using AI coding agents, including Claude Code and Codex, to develop software projects. They highlight the excitement and ease of use of these tools, which can generate prototypes and simple applications with minimal effort. However, they also emphasize that creating production-level code or complex projects still requires human expertise, patience, and skill. The author notes that while AI agents can be useful for small-scale development, they are not a replacement for experienced developers. This experience is presented as a cautionary tale about the limitations of current AI technology.

articles.title: Pluralistic: Social media without socializing (19 Jan 2026)
articles.summary: The article discusses the tension between social media platforms and socializing, with a focus on Mark Zuckerberg's approach to relationships on Facebook. The author argues that Zuckerberg views friends as a problem to be solved, rather than as complex and qualitative entities. This is exemplified in Facebook's early days when users found ways to circumvent the platform's restrictions on forming friendships based on shared interests. As social media grew into a massive industry, this struggle between how platforms demanded we socialize and how we wanted to socialize intensified. The author critiques Zuckerberg's approach as being at odds with the inherent complexity of relationships.

articles.title: Pluralistic: AI is how bosses wage war on "professions" (20 Jan 2026)
articles.summary: The article argues that the increasing use of artificial intelligence (AI) is being used by bosses as a tool to wage war on "professions" - fields bound by codes of conduct and professional associations. The author suggests that while AI may not be able to replace professionals in their jobs, it can be used to justify replacing them with machines. This phenomenon is particularly concerning for professions such as lawyers, accountants, medical professionals, librarians, teachers, and engineers, which are often seen as being at risk of replacement by chatbots. The author argues that the use of AI in these fields is not about augmenting human capabilities but rather about creating "reverse centaurs" - machines who are assisted by people.

articles.title: EFF Joins Internet Advocates Calling on the Iranian Government to Restore Full Internet Connectivity
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has joined internet advocates in calling on the Iranian government to restore full internet connectivity, which was severely disrupted earlier this month. The disruption was one of the most severe in recent years, with a near-total shutdown from the global internet and major restrictions on mobile access. This is not the first time Iran has suppressed internet access, particularly following an activist movement that gained global attention after the death of Mahsa Amini. EFF maintains that governments should not disrupt internet or telecommunication access, as it violates basic human rights and attacks people's ability to access information and communicate with each other.

articles.title: 💾 The Worst Data Breaches of 2025—And What You Can Do | EFFector 38.1
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has released its latest newsletter, EFFector 38.1, which highlights the worst data breaches of 2025 and provides tips on how to protect oneself from such incidents. The newsletter also covers ICE's surveillance spending spree and how hackers are countering it. Additionally, it invites readers to a free livestream on online age verification mandates. An audio companion is available on YouTube and the Internet Archive, featuring EFF Security and Privacy Activist Thorin Klosowski discussing data breach protection strategies for individuals and companies.

articles.title: Statutory Damages: The Fuel of Copyright-based Censorship
articles.summary: The article discusses how the statutory damages regime in US copyright law is broken and has led to censorship online. The current system allows juries to award penalties of up to $150,000 per work without considering actual financial losses or illicit profits. This creates a chilling effect on online speech, as users and platforms risk unpredictable and potentially devastating penalties for reusing copyrighted material.
