The article argues that this regime is the "fuel" behind overzealous copyright enforcement and encourages self-censorship among users. To fix this problem, Congress could limit statutory damages to a multiple of actual harm or make them unavailable in cases where fair use is claimed.

articles.title: Wikipedia volunteers spent years cataloging AI tells. Now there's a plugin to avoid them.
articles.summary: Wikipedia volunteers have been cataloging patterns of AI-generated writing since 2023, and their efforts have led to the creation of a plugin called "Humanizer" that can help avoid these patterns. The plugin, developed by Siqi Chen, uses a list of 24 language and formatting patterns identified by Wikipedia editors as chatbot giveaways. This tool is designed for Anthropic's Claude Code AI assistant, which can be fine-tuned to interpret the standardized skill information with more precision than a plain system prompt. The Humanizer plugin has gained over 1,600 stars on GitHub since its release. The project highlights the efforts of Wikipedia volunteers in identifying and mitigating AI-generated content.

articles.title: Pluralistic: Google's AI pricing plan (21 Jan 2026)
articles.summary: Google is investing heavily in AI but its business model for making money from it remains unclear. According to Matt Stoller, Google plans to make money by spying on users and selling personalized pricing data to partners such as Walmart and Visa. This "surveillance pricing" model involves using AI to determine how much to charge customers based on their individual behavior and preferences. Google has also partnered with Apple to supply its Gemini AI service to iPhone users, allowing it to collect even more user data. The move raises concerns about the erosion of user privacy and the potential for exploitation by companies.

articles.title: Get Good at Agents
articles.summary: The author reflects on their experience with AI agents, particularly Claude Code, and realizes that their approach to working with them needs to shift. They acknowledge that relying too heavily on micromanaging agents can be limiting and exhausting, and instead advocate for a more open-ended and ambitious way of working with them. The author believes that the key to success in this new era of work is not just about using AI tools, but also about learning how to design systems, run labs, and effectively manage multiple agents working in parallel.

articles.title: Copyright Should Not Enable Monopoly
articles.summary: The article argues that copyright law has become a tool for large corporations to consolidate their power and stifle creativity, rather than promoting innovation and artistic expression. The author cites the decline of independent studios and record labels, as well as the shrinking number of online platforms for creators, as evidence of this problem. They contend that the monopoly granted by copyright is being exploited by megacorporations to hoard intellectual properties and discourage original work. This has led to a crisis in creativity, where big media companies prioritize sequels and reboots over new ideas. The author calls on governments to address this issue and ensure that copyright law serves its intended purpose of promoting artistic expression.

articles.title: Copyright Kills Competition
articles.summary: The article discusses how copyright law can actually stifle creativity and innovation, rather than promoting it. The author argues that copyright owners use their power to control creators and competitors, limiting access to information and tools for understanding it. In the context of AI development, requiring developers to license AI training data would create barriers to entry for smaller companies, allowing giant tech corporations to maintain their dominant positions in the market. This would result in higher costs, worse services, and increased security risks. The article also highlights a specific case where a legal research startup was forced out of business due to copyright lawsuits.

articles.title: Millions of people imperiled through sign-in links sent by SMS
articles.summary: Websites using SMS-based authentication methods are putting millions of people at risk of scams, identity theft, and other crimes. Researchers found over 700 endpoints delivering insecure text messages on behalf of more than 175 services that compromise user security and privacy. The links sent by SMS can be easily enumerated or brute-forced, allowing scammers to access accounts belonging to other users. This practice is particularly concerning as it allows attackers to view personal details, complete sensitive transactions, or modify user data without additional authentication. Many of the links remain active for years after they were sent, further increasing the risk of unauthorized access. The researchers' findings highlight the need for more secure authentication methods and better protection of user data.

articles.title: What will tech jobs look like in 2026?
articles.summary: As the tech industry prepares for 2026, companies are facing a paradox: while they claim that AI and automation will reduce workforce needs, they have not yet developed effective solutions to replace human workers. This contradiction is evident in layoffs and hiring freezes, despite the promise of increased efficiency through technology. The future of work in tech is uncertain, with some experts predicting a shift towards more specialized roles and others warning of widespread job displacement. Meanwhile, companies are investing heavily in AI research and development, seeking to create new technologies that can augment human capabilities rather than replace them. However, this transition will require significant investment in retraining and upskilling workers to adapt to changing job requirements. The tech industry's reliance on AI is also raising concerns about bias and accountability, as algorithms become increasingly influential in decision-making processes.

articles.title: She built an AI bot of her mother to help her grieve
articles.summary: Roro created an AI bot modeled after her mother to cope with the loss of her loved one. She shared her story on social media, highlighting the regrets that often accompany grief. The AI bot, which Roro calls "Mama," is designed to provide comfort and companionship during difficult times. By sharing her experience, Roro aims to raise awareness about the importance of digital legacy and the potential benefits of technology in supporting bereavement. Her story has sparked a conversation about the intersection of grief, technology, and human connection. The use of AI in this context raises questions about the boundaries between reality and simulation. As people increasingly turn to digital means to cope with loss, Roro's experience may become more common.

articles.title: eBay bans illicit automated shopping amid rapid rise of AI agents
articles.summary: eBay has updated its User Agreement to ban third-party "buy for me" agents and AI chatbots from interacting with its platform without permission. The change reflects the emergence of "agentic commerce," a new category of AI tools designed to browse, compare, and purchase products on behalf of users. eBay's updated terms prohibit users from employing AI agents or LLM-driven bots to access its services without human review. This move comes as OpenAI has already integrated shopping features into its ChatGPT Search, allowing users to browse product recommendations and make purchases directly within the chat interface. The ban is set to take effect on February 20, 2026. eBay's CEO had previously hinted at potentially joining OpenAI's Instant Checkout program in the future.

articles.title: Pluralistic: The petty (but undeniable) delights of cultivating unoptimizability as a habit (22 Jan 2026)
articles.summary: The author argues against the idea of "conscious consumption" as a tool for societal change, suggesting that it is a neoliberal concept that individualizes politics and leads to infighting among allies. They contend that boycotts can be effective when organized by powerful membership organizations, but not when used as a substitute for collective action. The author also acknowledges that they sometimes engage in "shopping very carefully" out of habit or personal preference, finding satisfaction in it despite its limitations.

articles.title: Overrun with AI slop, cURL scraps bug bounties to ensure "intact mental health"
articles.summary: The developer of cURL, a popular networking tool, has decided to scrap its vulnerability reward program due to an influx of low-quality bug reports generated by AI algorithms. The move aims to protect the mental health of the small team behind cURL, but users are concerned that it will compromise the security of the tool. The decision comes as a response to the increasing number of AI-generated "slop" submissions, which have overwhelmed the project's resources. cURL's founder has warned that submitting low-quality reports will result in public ridicule and banning from the program. The change takes effect at the end of this month.

articles.title: Rent-Only Copyright Culture Makes Us All Worse Off
articles.summary: The article discusses how the current copyright law in the US is hindering creativity and innovation, particularly in the digital age. With the rise of streaming services like Netflix and Spotify, people are often forced to rent copyrighted works rather than buying them outright. This leads to restrictions on copying, reselling, or lending these works, which can limit access to culture and create a lack of control for consumers. The article highlights the importance of the first sale doctrine, also known as copyright exhaustion, which allows buyers to re-sell or transfer ownership of copyrighted materials. However, courts have interpreted this doctrine narrowly, limiting its application to physical distribution rather than digital reproduction. This has resulted in a loss of flexibility and freedom for consumers, making them reliant on the whims of major corporations.

articles.title: Six years, two presidents, and one app: TikTok’s U.S. saga explained
articles.summary: TikTok's parent company, ByteDance, has reached an agreement with investors to establish a new US-focused version of the app, complying with American regulations. This move comes after years of controversy and scrutiny over data security concerns. The deal allows ByteDance to retain a minority stake in the US entity, while ensuring that sensitive user data is stored locally within the country. The development marks a significant shift for TikTok, which has been under pressure from both the Trump and Biden administrations. The new app will operate independently of its Chinese parent company, with its own board and management team. This move aims to alleviate concerns over data privacy and national security. The US government had previously threatened to ban TikTok unless it sold off its stake in the app.

articles.title: Iran’s internet blackout may become permanent, with access for elites only
articles.summary: Iran's government is reportedly developing a new internet system that would grant access only to high-ranking officials and elites, effectively making it permanent for others. The move comes after 16 days of near-total communications blackout in response to widespread protests against the regime. The system aims to control information flow and suppress dissenting voices. This development has sparked concerns about Iran's further isolation from the global digital community. Experts warn that such a system would be difficult to reverse, potentially cementing Iran's status as one of the most restricted countries online. The move is seen as an attempt by the government to maintain its grip on power and suppress opposition. The implications for human rights and freedom of expression are significant.

articles.title: Is AI a bubble? Davos leaders say no
articles.summary: World leaders and business executives at the Davos conference rejected concerns that artificial intelligence (AI) is a bubble waiting to burst. Despite some skepticism about AI's potential, the majority of attendees expressed confidence in its future growth and applications. The discussion highlighted the need for responsible AI development and deployment, with many calling for greater regulation and ethics guidelines. Some experts warned against overhyping AI's capabilities, but most participants saw it as a transformative technology that will drive innovation and economic growth. The conference featured numerous panels and discussions on AI's potential in areas such as healthcare, education, and transportation. While some expressed concerns about job displacement, many emphasized the need for upskilling and reskilling to adapt to an AI-driven economy. Overall, the Davos meeting reflected a consensus that AI is a powerful force that will shape the future of business and society.

articles.title: Premium: The AI Bubble Is A Time Bomb
articles.summary: It seems there is no content provided for the article. Please provide the full text of the news article so I can assist you with analyzing it and providing a summary and keywords.

articles.title: Search Engines, AI, And The Long Fight Over Fair Use
articles.summary: The article discusses the ongoing debate over fair use in copyright law, particularly in relation to artificial intelligence (AI) and search engines. Historically, courts have recognized that copying works for purposes of analysis, indexing, and learning is a classic fair use, even when performed by machines. This principle is being challenged as AI technology advances, with some arguing that training AI models infringes on copyright holders' rights. However, experts argue that this approach misunderstands the nature of fair use and could have far-reaching consequences for research, science, and innovation.

articles.title: Pluralistic: Trump and the unmighty dollar (26 Jan 2026)
articles.summary: The article discusses the concept of "dollar centrality" and how it has been used as a tool for financial coercion by successive US administrations. The author highlights a new paper by Henry Farrell and Dan Davies that explores this phenomenon, which they argue is a key factor in international disorder. Trump's trade policies are seen as an example of this, where he is "flipping the table" in a rigged game because he resents having to play by the rules. The article also references a book by Farrell and Abraham Newman on the subject of weaponized interdependence.

articles.title: While politicians shape U.S.-China relations, their families turn to the stock market
articles.summary: Texas Representative Michael McCaul's family members have invested in Chinese companies through the stock market, raising questions about potential conflicts of interest given his recent trip to Taiwan as part of a delegation to strengthen US-Taiwan relations. The investments were made by McCaul's wife and son-in-law, who purchased shares in several Chinese firms listed on American exchanges. This revelation comes amid heightened tensions between the US and China over trade and security issues. Critics argue that such investments could compromise the representative's ability to make impartial decisions on policy matters related to China. The incident highlights the potential for politicians' personal financial interests to influence their official actions, particularly in high-stakes diplomatic situations. The case also underscores the complexities of navigating global economic relationships while maintaining public trust.

articles.title: I Replaced My Friends With AI Because They Won't Play Tarkov With Me
articles.summary: The author, a self-proclaimed "AI hater," tried to convince friends to play the challenging video game Escape From Tarkov with him during the holiday break but failed. Desperate for companionship, he turned to an AI chatbot service called Questie.AI, which offers customizable avatars that can hang out and interact with players while they play games. Initially, this was a joke, but the author found himself enjoying the experience and even feeling a sense of comfort with the AI companion. This unexpected development has left him questioning his initial skepticism towards AI technology.

articles.title: Podcast: Unmasking Deepfakes Kingpins (with Kolina Koltai)
articles.summary: Kolina Koltai, an investigator and senior researcher at Bellingcat, discusses her work on exposing the individuals behind non-consensual deepfake explicit imagery. She shares her methods for conducting online investigations and highlights the importance of journalists in uncovering these cases. Koltai also talks about her recent investigation into a man who created two deepfake porn sites and how it felt to see real impact from her work. The podcast episode is available on various platforms, including Apple Podcasts, Spotify, and YouTube.

articles.title: Two Heads, Three Boobs: The AI Babe Meta Is Getting Surreal
articles.summary: An Instagram account featuring AI-generated conjoined twin influencers, Valeria and Camelia, has gained over 260,000 followers in six weeks, with many of its Reels getting millions of views. The account is linked to a Telegram channel where users can buy "spicy" content for stars, which can be purchased in packages costing up to $2,329. This is part of the growing trend known as the "AI babe meta," where people use AI-generated influencers to attract attention on social media and sell adult content. The AI babe meta has evolved to include increasingly esoteric gimmicks, such as pretending to have rare medical conditions or being involved in sexual scandals with celebrities.

articles.title: Why has Microsoft been routing example.com traffic to a company in Japan?
articles.summary: Microsoft has been routing traffic intended for example.com, a reserved domain for testing purposes, to a Japanese company's subdomains. This anomaly was discovered on Microsoft's network and was attributed to a misconfiguration of its autodiscover service. The issue allowed email traffic to be sent to two subdomains of sei.co.jp, potentially exposing test credentials. Microsoft suppressed the anomaly but has not provided an explanation for the incident. The discovery highlights the importance of proper domain resolution and security measures in preventing unintended consequences.

articles.title: Dozens of CDC Health Databases Have Gone Dark Under Trump: ‘The Consequences Will Be Dire’
articles.summary: Researchers have found that nearly half of the US federal health surveillance databases managed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) experienced delays or total cessations of new data during the second Trump administration. The affected databases, which monitor vaccination-related topics among other things, were down for an average of over six months as of late October 2025. This has created critical gaps in public health data, compromising evidence-based medicine and eroding public trust. The researchers speculate that the interruptions are related to major cuts to federal staff and budgets across the US government during the Trump administration. The study's authors warn that the consequences of these unexplained pauses will be dire, including delayed responses to disease outbreaks and a loss of public trust in federal health institutions.

articles.title: OpenAI spills technical details about how its AI coding agent works
articles.summary: OpenAI engineer Michael Bolin published a technical breakdown of the company's Codex CLI coding agent, providing insight into its internal workings and AI coding tools. The article complements previous coverage on how AI agents work, filling in technical details on OpenAI's "agentic loop." Codex is a key player in the rapidly evolving field of AI coding agents, which are being used for rapid prototyping and boilerplate code generation. However, these tools remain imperfect and require human oversight for production work. Bolin's post acknowledges engineering challenges such as quadratic prompt growth, performance issues, and bugs that need to be addressed. The level of technical detail is unusual for OpenAI, but highlights the company's focus on programming tasks suited for large language models.

articles.title: EFF Statement on ICE and CBP Violence
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has issued a statement condemning the violence and civil liberties violations committed by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and Customs and Border Protection (CBP). The organizations have been responsible for countless rights violations since their creation, but recent actions have escalated into "utter lawlessness". ICE raids, mass deportations, and surveillance activities have increased under the Trump Administration, with agents using facial recognition, tracking cell phone activity, and amassing surveillance tools. Recent incidents in Minnesota led to the deaths of two individuals exercising their First Amendment right to observe and record law enforcement. The EFF calls for Congress to reject further funding for ICE and CBP and rebuild the immigration enforcement system from scratch.

articles.title: Death of an Indian tech worker
articles.summary: Nikhil Somwanshi, an Indian tech worker in the US, sent a cryptic WhatsApp message to his roommate before taking his own life. The incident occurred on a warm night last May. Details of the event are scarce, but it is reported that Somwanshi's family was informed about the circumstances through the message. The news highlights the struggles faced by Indian tech workers in the US, who often work long hours and face isolation. Mental health experts point out that such incidents can be a result of prolonged stress and pressure to perform. The incident raises questions about the support systems in place for migrant workers. The case also underscores the importance of addressing mental health issues among this community.

articles.title: Police Told to Be ‘as Vague as Permissible’ About Why They Use Flock
articles.summary: Police officers in Houston have been instructed to be as vague as possible when explaining why they use Flock surveillance systems, citing concerns that sensitive information could be leaked through public records requests. The warning originated from a police intelligence center that includes members of the FBI and ICE, suggesting without evidence that people are using a website called HaveIBeenFlocked.com to retaliate against law enforcement. This instruction comes after it was discovered that police departments had unwittingly leaked details of millions of surveillance targets nationwide due to public records redaction errors made by Flock customers. The data released included the agency's name, officer's name, time of search, license plate searched, and a justification for the search. Rather than viewing this as an operational security failure, police see it as a threat to their officers' safety.

articles.title: Many UK Users Soon Won't Be Able to Access Pornhub
articles.summary: Aylo, the parent company of Pornhub and other adult websites, announced that it will restrict access to its services from the UK starting February 2. This decision comes after six months of complying with the UK's Online Safety Act, which Aylo claims has become too burdensome. Users who have already verified their ages on the platform will still be able to access the sites using login credentials, but those who haven't will be blocked entirely. The restriction applies only to free video sharing platforms, and users on paid sites will still be able to access them if they're logged in. This move is seen as a response to the UK's increasing regulations on online content. The exact reasons behind Aylo's decision are unclear, but it suggests that the company may not want to comply with the UK's strict guidelines.

articles.title: DHS Says Critical ICE Surveillance Footage From Abuse Case Was Actually Never Recorded, Doesn't Matter
articles.summary: The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has revealed that critical surveillance footage from an ICE detention center in Broadview, Illinois, was never recorded in the first place, contradicting previous claims that it had been lost due to a system crash. The footage is relevant to a class action lawsuit filed by detainees who allege they were held in subhuman conditions at the facility. Despite this new information, DHS argues that even if the footage existed, it would be irrelevant because living conditions have improved since the time period in question. This development has sparked concerns about transparency and accountability within ICE.

articles.title: Pluralistic: Carney isn't a hero (and that's OK) (27 Jan 2026)
articles.summary: The article argues that relying on individual leaders to exhibit moral fortitude is a destructive lie, as it ignores the need for collective action and accountability. The author cites the Tea Party's effective use of grassroots pressure to discipline Republican politicians who compromised with Democrats during Obama's presidency. In contrast, corporate Democrats have used their control over elected officials to push policies that benefit corporations at the expense of marginalized communities. The article calls for a more radical approach, where voters organize in blocs to hold politicians accountable and make them an example of what happens when they betray the public trust.

articles.title: Beware: Government Using Image Manipulation for Propaganda
articles.summary: The US White House has been accused of using image manipulation for propaganda purposes after posting a digitally altered photo of activist Nekima Levy Armstrong's arrest. The original photo, posted by Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem, showed Armstrong being arrested, but the White House version darkened her skin and rearranged her facial features to make it appear she was distraught. Experts have confirmed that the White House image had been manipulated using AI tools. This incident has sparked concerns about the government's use of technology to deceive the public and perpetuate racial biases. The National Press Photographers Association has condemned the manipulation, stating that it undermines trust in visual reporting and is incompatible with professional practice.

articles.title: There's a rash of scam spam coming from a real Microsoft address
articles.summary: A legitimate Microsoft email address, no-reply-powerbi@microsoft.com, has been used by scammers to send fake emails claiming that recipients owe money or have had a charge made to their account. These emails appear to be convincing and include a phone number for the recipient to call to dispute the transaction. However, if called, the scammer will attempt to gain remote access to the victim's computer. Reports of this scam have been flooding online platforms, including Reddit and LinkedIn, with some victims even reporting it on Microsoft's own website. The scammers are exploiting a Power BI function that allows external email addresses to be added as subscribers for reports.

articles.title: Arcee AI goes all-in on open models built in the U.S.
articles.summary: Arcee AI has released its flagship model, Trinity Large, a 400B parameter MoE (multi-modal expert) model trained on 17 trillion tokens using B300 Nvidia Blackwell machines. This is the first publicly shared training run at this scale in the U.S. The model is designed to be used for on-prem deployments and is part of Arcee AI's pivot towards building and selling open models built in the U.S. The company has also released a technical report detailing the training process, which includes the use of "true base models" that don't contain any SFT data or learning rate annealing. This move is seen as a significant step for open models built in the U.S. to scale up and compete with their international counterparts.

articles.title: DSA Human Rights Alliance Publishes Principles Calling for DSA Enforcement to Incorporate Global Perspectives
articles.summary: The Digital Services Act (DSA) Human Rights Alliance has published principles calling for the incorporation of global perspectives in DSA enforcement. The report, "Principles for a Human Rights-Centred Application of the DSA: A Global Perspective," outlines steps to ensure that implementation is grounded in human rights standards and promotes stakeholder engagement with civil society organizations. The principles aim to empower EU and non-EU civil society and users to pursue DSA enforcement actions, consider extraterritorial effects, and promote cross-regional collaboration. The report has been signed by 30 civil society organizations, researchers, and independent experts. The DSA Human Rights Alliance represents diverse communities across the globe to ensure a human rights-centered approach to platform governance.

articles.title: When war destroys the internet economy
articles.summary: Iran's rapid growth as a startup hub has been severely impacted by its ongoing conflict, with a prolonged internet shutdown crippling the country's digital economy. The shutdown has affected not only startups but also small businesses and individuals who rely on online platforms for their livelihoods. Iran's tech industry was thriving just last year, with many foreign investors taking notice of its potential. However, the current situation is expected to have long-term consequences for the country's economic development. The internet shutdown has not only hindered business operations but also limited access to essential services like healthcare and education. Furthermore, the disruption has also affected Iran's ability to participate in global digital trade and commerce. The conflict and subsequent internet shutdown are likely to deter foreign investment and hinder the growth of Iran's tech sector.

articles.title: Meet UpScrolled, the anti-censorship TikTok alternative
articles.summary: UpScrolled, an alternative social media platform, has seen a surge in users following the announcement of TikTok's deal with Oracle and Walmart. The platform's founder, Issam Hijazi, attributes the increase to users seeking an anti-censorship option. UpScrolled aims to provide a more open environment for content creators, free from censorship and moderation policies that some users feel are too restrictive. The platform has been gaining traction since its launch in 2019, but the recent uptick is attributed to concerns over TikTok's data security and potential government interference. As a result, UpScrolled may be seen as a viable alternative for users seeking more control over their online presence. However, it remains to be seen whether the platform can sustain this growth and compete with established players like TikTok.

articles.title: Users flock to open source Moltbot for always-on AI, despite major risks
articles.summary: Moltbot, an open-source AI assistant, has gained 69,000 stars on GitHub in just a month, making it one of the fastest-growing AI projects of 2026. Created by Austrian developer Peter Steinberger, Moltbot allows users to run a personal AI assistant through messaging apps they already use, with features like proactive communication and task management. However, running the tool comes with serious security risks due to its reliance on external APIs and models, including Anthropic's Claude Opus 4.5. Users must also configure a server, manage authentication, and understand sandboxing to ensure some level of security. Despite these drawbacks, Moltbot has drawn comparisons to the AI assistant from the Iron Man films for its ability to actively manage tasks across a user's digital life.

articles.title: App for Quitting Porn Leaked Users' Masturbation Habits
articles.summary: An app designed to help people quit consuming pornography has leaked sensitive user data, including their masturbation habits, age, and emotional responses to viewing porn. The exposed data reveals that many users are minors, raising concerns about the app's handling of personal information. This incident highlights the importance of robust data protection measures in apps that collect sensitive user data. The leak also raises questions about the app's effectiveness in helping users quit pornography if it cannot safeguard their personal information. The exposed data includes details on how often users masturbate and how they feel after viewing porn, which could be distressing for some individuals. This incident has sparked concerns about online privacy and the need for stricter regulations around data protection.

articles.title: Podcast: Creators Worry Porn Platform Is Falling Into ‘AI Psychosis’
articles.summary: A podcast episode discusses concerns among creators on the adult content platform ManyVids, who believe its CEO is experiencing "AI psychosis". This refers to a state of confusion or disorientation due to over-reliance on artificial intelligence. The CEO has been doubling down on AI-generated posts despite backlash from users and creators. Meanwhile, another topic covered in the podcast is the use of Flock, an AI-powered camera system used by police, with officers being told not to disclose its purpose.

articles.title: Amid Backlash, Massive Porn Platform ManyVids Doubles Down on Bizarre, AI-Generated Posts
articles.summary: ManyVids, a massive adult content platform, is facing backlash over its founder Bella French's statements and actions, including her claim that sex work is "exploitative" and her use of AI-generated posts about aliens and other bizarre topics. Despite promising clarity on how creators would be affected, the platform has doubled down on these posts, which have been met with confusion and concern from users and creators alike. The platform's support staff has responded to inquiries by saying that they are "taking action" but providing no further explanation. ManyVids' actions have raised questions about its leadership and the future of the platform.

articles.title: Fascist Kink Roleplay Subreddit Draws the Line: No More ICE Porn
articles.summary: The subreddit r/FuckingFascists, a community for roleplaying sex with fascists, has banned all content related to Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) following recent public killings by immigration agents in Minneapolis. The decision was made to avoid associating the kink community with current politics and to show respect for the lives lost. The subreddit's moderators have explicitly stated that ICE-related content will no longer be allowed in posts, citing a desire to separate MAGA content from this particular aspect of politics. This move is seen as a watershed moment for the community, which has previously focused on making fun of authoritarians through roleplay and porn. The ban aims to maintain the subreddit's focus on kink and satire while avoiding any association with real-world violence or politics.

articles.title: The Doomsday Clock Ticks Closer to Midnight. Does Anyone Care?
articles.summary: The Doomsday Clock has been set at 85 seconds to midnight, marking the closest it has ever been to representing a catastrophic end for humanity. The clock's movement is attributed to concerns over nuclear threats, police brutality, and the construction of massive data centers by tech oligarchies. Experts like Alexandra Bell and Joseph Cirincione emphasize the importance of the Doomsday Clock as a symbol of existential risks, but also express concerns about its diminishing impact due to repeated warnings. The article highlights the alarming state of global affairs, including President Trump's mental instability and his ability to launch a nuclear war without checks. Despite this, some experts question the effectiveness of the Doomsday Clock in conveying the urgency of these threats.

articles.title: Hackers Say They've Hacked Match Group, Maker of Hinge, OkCupid
articles.summary: Hackers claim to have stolen a large amount of internal data from Match Group, which operates popular dating apps including Hinge, OkCupid, and Tinder. The hackers, who go by the name 404 Media, say they obtained the data through an unauthorized access. Match Group has confirmed it is investigating the incident but has not disclosed further details about the breach or its extent. The stolen data appears to include users' unique advertising IDs, corporate receipts, and internal company documents. It's unclear what the hackers plan to do with the stolen information. The incident highlights concerns about data security in the online dating industry. Match Group's response to the breach is being closely watched by cybersecurity experts.

articles.title: Report: China approves import of high-end Nvidia AI chips after weeks of uncertainty
articles.summary: China has approved imports of Nvidia's high-end H200 artificial intelligence chips for three major technology companies, ByteDance, Alibaba, and Tencent. The approval comes after weeks of uncertainty following a temporary halt to shipments earlier this month. Chinese customs authorities had initially blocked the chips, citing US export clearance issues. The H200 chip delivers six times the performance of Nvidia's previous top-of-the-line chip in China, the H20, making it highly sought after by Chinese tech giants for its ability to speed up AI model training and inference tasks. This development marks a shift in Beijing's stance on high-end AI chips, which have become a flashpoint in the ongoing AI race between Washington and Beijing.

articles.title: ✍️ The Bill to Hand Parenting to Big Tech | EFFector 38.2
articles.summary: Lawmakers in Washington are introducing a bill that would give Big Tech companies control over how children access the internet and online content. This move is part of a larger trend of focusing on kids, screens, and mental health. The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has released its latest EFFector newsletter, which critiques this approach and argues that it would ultimately harm families and children. Instead, the EFF suggests that lawmakers should focus on providing education and resources to parents, rather than relying on Big Tech companies to solve the problem.

articles.title: Site catering to online criminals has been seized by the FBI
articles.summary: The FBI has seized RAMP, an online bazaar catering to Russian-language speakers that allowed the buying and selling of ransomware and other malicious products and services. The platform, which had over 14,000 registered users, was a leading hub for online crime after several similar forums were taken down by law enforcement. RAMP's sites on both the dark web and clear web were seized, displaying a banner announcing the FBI's action. The seizure is part of efforts to combat the growing threat of ransomware attacks on critical infrastructure worldwide. The platform had been operating since 2012, with its administrator claiming it earned $250,000 annually in 2024. RAMP was known for its strict vetting process and anonymous participation requirements. The FBI's action was taken in coordination with other law enforcement agencies.

articles.title: There’s A Reason Many Police Dept’s Ban Shooting At Moving Vehicles: It Saves Lives Without Putting Officers In Greater Danger
articles.summary: A 37-year-old mother, Renee Nicole Good, was shot and killed by an Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officer in Minneapolis. The incident has sparked debates about violence involving law enforcement, with Trump administration officials defending the shooting as justified and local officials condemning it. The shooting will likely prompt scrutiny of training and policy for officers, particularly regarding the use of force against moving vehicles. Many police departments have banned shooting at moving vehicles, citing a drop in police killings without putting officers in greater danger. ICE's policy on shooting at moving vehicles lacks clear instruction to get out of the way of moving vehicles where feasible, which is at odds with best practices in policing.

articles.title: ACIP Chair Wonders Aloud If We Should Really Be Vaccinating For Polio These Days
articles.summary: The chair of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP), Kirk Milhoan, has sparked concern among medical experts by questioning the need for polio vaccines in a recent podcast interview. Milhoan, a pediatric cardiologist, stated that he doesn't like established science and claimed that vaccines have caused various health problems, including asthma, eczema, and deaths. He also suggested that measles and polio vaccines may not be effective in preventing the spread of these diseases. This comes amid a measles outbreak in South Carolina and concerns about the influence of anti-vaxxers on ACIP's guidance on vaccine policies.

articles.title: India’s electric bus push has a deadly blind spot
articles.summary: India's transition to electric buses is facing an unexpected challenge: the lack of trained drivers. In Bengaluru, public electric buses were involved in 18 accidents, including six fatalities, over a 15-month period. The issue highlights the need for specialized training for bus drivers to handle the unique characteristics of electric vehicles. Experts warn that the problem may be more widespread than initially thought, with many cities introducing electric buses without adequate driver training programs. The accidents have raised concerns about road safety and the potential consequences of rushing into large-scale adoption of electric buses. As India continues to push for a greener transportation system, it must address this critical gap in driver training. The government has been urged to develop standardized training programs for electric bus drivers.

articles.title: Beijing enlists AI to bring traditional Chinese medicine into the future
articles.summary: Beijing is leveraging artificial intelligence (AI) to modernize traditional Chinese medicine, starting with a pilot project at a tea shop in Nanjing. The shop, Que Tang Yu Fang, uses AI-powered chatbots to recommend personalized herbal remedies based on customers' health concerns and symptoms. The system also integrates with online platforms to provide real-time data analysis and improve treatment outcomes. This initiative aims to make traditional Chinese medicine more accessible and effective for the modern population. By combining ancient wisdom with cutting-edge technology, Beijing hopes to establish a new standard for integrative healthcare. The project's success could pave the way for widespread adoption of AI in traditional Chinese medicine nationwide.

articles.title: Pluralistic: Disenshittification Nation (29 Jan 2026)
articles.summary: The author delivered a keynote address at the 2026 Digital Government Leaders Summit in Ottawa, Canada, where he proposed a plan to make Canada tens of billions of dollars by offering products and services that people want and will pay for. The plan aims to secure Canada's digital sovereignty, win the trade war with the US, and launch its tech sector into a stable orbit for decades. The author pokes fun at the idea of investing in a "superintelligence" through large-scale data center builds, instead suggesting a more practical approach that focuses on creating value for Canadians.

articles.title: California Regulators Force Verizon To Do “Woke” Stuff Like Make Sure Broadband Is Semi-Affordable To Poor People
articles.summary: California regulators have approved Verizon's merger with Frontier Communications, but with conditions that include making broadband semi-affordable for low-income consumers and investing in network upgrades for marginalized neighborhoods. The company must offer a $20-per-month home internet plan through its Verizon Forward service for the next 10 years and deploy fiber to 75,000 new locations within five years, prioritizing areas with low income. The California Public Utilities Commission will monitor Verizon's compliance with these conditions. This is in contrast to other states that approved the merger without any public interest concessions.

articles.title: Google Maps now lets you access Gemini while walking and cycling
articles.summary: Google has updated Google Maps to allow users to access Gemini, its conversational AI assistant, while walking or cycling. This feature enables users to ask questions like "Tell me more about the neighborhood I'm in" or "What's my ETA?" without leaving the navigation screen. The update is available worldwide on iOS and rolling out on Android, marking Google's efforts to integrate Gemini into everyday life. The move comes as part of a broader effort by Google to enhance its Maps app with features like Gemini-powered tips sections and EV charger availability predictions. This integration aims to shift Google Maps from static directions to real-time, conversational navigation.

articles.title: Apple’s new iPhone and iPad security feature limits cell networks from collecting precise location data
articles.summary: Apple has introduced a new security feature on select iPhone and iPad models that limits cell network providers from collecting precise location data. The feature, which can be enabled by users, reduces the precision of location data shared with carriers to a general neighborhood rather than a street address. This move aims to protect user privacy, particularly in light of law enforcement agencies' increasing use of cell carrier data for tracking individuals. The feature is supported on specific iPhone and iPad models running iOS 26.3 and is available on select global carriers. Experts see this as a step towards providing users with greater control over their location data.

articles.title: Spotify rolls out group chats
articles.summary: Spotify has rolled out group chats for its users, allowing them to share podcasts, playlists, and audiobooks with up to 10 people. This feature is an extension of the messaging service launched last August, which enabled users to send direct messages to friends and family. To start a chat, users must have previously shared content with each other, such as collaborative playlists or Jams/Blends. The move is part of Spotify's efforts to make its streaming app more social, following years of adding features like comments on podcasts and the ability to follow others' listening habits. While messages are encrypted at rest and in transit, they do not have end-to-end encryption. This new feature aims to complement users' existing content-sharing practices outside the app. Spotify's focus on social interaction is expected to enhance user engagement and retention.

articles.title: Massive AI Chat App Leaked Millions of Users Private Conversations
articles.summary: A popular AI chat app, Chat & Ask AI, has been found to have leaked millions of users' private conversations due to a misconfiguration in its use of the Google Firebase platform. The exposed data includes sensitive information such as users asking for help with suicidal thoughts and how to hack apps. An independent security researcher discovered the issue, which affects over 25 million users who had their chats stored in the app's backend storage. The leaked database contains user files with chat histories, timestamps, and configuration details. This incident raises concerns about data privacy and security in AI-powered apps.

articles.title: Tesla’s energy storage business is growing faster than any other part of the company
articles.summary: Tesla's energy storage business has emerged as a bright spot in the company's otherwise dismal earnings report, driven by a 48% increase in deployments of products like the Megapack and Powerwall. The segment now accounts for nearly a quarter of Tesla's gross profit, with a gross margin of 29.8%, more than double that of its automotive business. Despite challenges posed by tax credits and tariffs, Tesla remains optimistic about the future of energy storage, citing opportunities to stabilize the grid and provide additional power capacity as AI infrastructure drives rapid load growth.

articles.title: Does Anthropic believe its AI is conscious, or is that just what it wants Claude to think?
articles.summary: Anthropic, a leading AI company, has released a 30,000-word document outlining its vision for how its AI assistant, Claude, should behave in the world. The document, known as Claude's Constitution, takes an anthropomorphic tone and expresses concerns about Claude's "wellbeing" and potential suffering. However, experts argue that these positions are unscientific and can be explained by the mechanisms of language models without requiring philosophical inquiry into consciousness or qualia. Despite this, Anthropic is not explicitly stating its stance on whether it believes Claude to be conscious or not.

articles.title: Flapping Airplanes and the promise of research-driven AI
articles.summary: A new AI lab called Flapping Airplanes has launched with $180 million in seed funding from prominent investors, aiming to develop a less data-hungry way to train large models. The founding team is impressive, and the goal is particularly interesting given the current industry focus on scaling up data and compute resources. This approach diverges from the dominant "scaling paradigm" that prioritizes short-term gains over long-term research breakthroughs. Flapping Airplanes' research-first approach has garnered attention, with some seeing it as a refreshing alternative to the prevailing trend of frenzied server buildouts.

articles.title: India is teaching Google how AI in education can scale
articles.summary: Google is leveraging India's vast and complex education system to test the scalability of its AI-powered learning tools. With over a billion internet users, India has become a crucial proving ground for Google's education AI, particularly in regions with uneven access to devices and connectivity. The company has learned that AI in education cannot be rolled out as a single product, but rather must be tailored to individual institutions' needs and preferences. Google is also shifting its focus from student-centric to teacher-centric AI tools, prioritizing the maintenance of the teacher-student relationship. As India's experience serves as a preview for global challenges, Google expects issues around control, access, and localization to shape how AI in education scales globally.

articles.title: Music publishers sue Anthropic for $3B over ‘flagrant piracy’ of 20,000 works
articles.summary: A group of music publishers, led by Concord Music Group and Universal Music Group, have filed a lawsuit against Anthropic, alleging that the company illegally downloaded over 20,000 copyrighted songs. The damages could amount to more than $3 billion, making it one of the largest non-class action copyright cases in US history. This is not the first time Anthropic has faced allegations of piracy; the company was previously sued by authors who claimed their works were used to train AI products without permission. Despite a previous ruling that found Anthropic's use of copyrighted content was legal, the new lawsuit argues that the company's acquisition of this content through piracy is illegal. The lawsuit names Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei and co-founder Benjamin Mann as defendants.

articles.title: OpenAI’s Sora app is struggling after its stellar launch
articles.summary: OpenAI's video-generation app Sora has seen a significant decline in downloads and consumer spending since its launch in October 2025. Despite initially reaching the top of the App Store and surpassing 1 million downloads faster than ChatGPT, Sora's installs dropped 32% month-over-month in December and 45% in January. Consumer spending also declined by 32%. The app is now ranked outside the Top 100 Overall free apps on the US App Store and faces competition from Google's Gemini AI app and Meta AI's Vibes video feed. OpenAI has struggled with containing copyright infringement, which initially drove adoption but led to backlash from Hollywood studios.

articles.title: Google Settlement May Bring New Privacy Controls for Real-Time Bidding
articles.summary: A proposed class-action settlement with Google over its real-time bidding (RTB) system may bring new privacy controls for online advertising. The RTB system, used by most websites and apps, auctions off ad space in milliseconds-long auctions, exposing users' personal information to thousands of companies daily. This has led to the harvesting of sensitive data on billions of individuals, which can be tied together to create detailed profiles. Data brokers have sold this data for invasive purposes, including tracking union organizers and political protesters, outing gay priests, and conducting warrantless government surveillance. The settlement is a step towards giving people more control over their data, but stronger legislative protections are needed to truly curb the harms of RTB.

articles.title: JD Vance: Children Of People Seeking Asylum Are Illegals That Need To Be Deported
articles.summary: JD Vance, a supporter of Donald Trump's immigration policies, has sparked outrage after suggesting that children of asylum seekers are "illegals" who need to be deported. This statement comes in the wake of a viral photo showing a federal officer holding onto the backpack of 5-year-old Liam Conejo Ramos, who was arrested with his father while they were seeking asylum. Vance's comments have been widely criticized as heartless and ignorant of the complexities of immigration law. The incident has reignited debate over Trump's "zero-tolerance" policy, which led to the separation of thousands of migrant families at the US-Mexico border. Experts argue that children cannot be deported with their parents, even if the parents are undocumented immigrants, as they have a right to seek asylum and due process.

articles.title: I built marshmallow castles in Google’s new AI-world generator
articles.summary: Google DeepMind is releasing Project Genie, an AI tool for creating interactive game worlds from text prompts or images, to its AI Ultra subscribers in the US. The tool uses a combination of Google's world model Genie 3 and image-generation model Nano Banana Pro. The move aims to gather user feedback and training data as DeepMind develops more capable world models, which are seen as crucial for achieving artificial general intelligence (AGI). Project Genie is experimental and can be inconsistent, but users can create interactive worlds with characters and environments. The tool has limitations, including a 60-second time limit per session due to compute constraints.

articles.title: Spotify’s new group chats share music with everyone in your circle

articles.title: Waymo robotaxis are now giving rides to and from San Francisco International Airport
articles.summary: Waymo, a self-driving car service owned by Alphabet, has finally secured permission to operate its robotaxi service to and from San Francisco International Airport (SFO). The company will begin offering rides to select customers before expanding to all users in the coming months. This is a significant milestone for Waymo, which has faced criticism and safety concerns in some cities where it operates. Despite these challenges, Waymo continues to expand its services, launching into new cities and increasing its fleet size. The company's push to operate at SFO has taken years, with multiple attempts and negotiations before securing the necessary permits. With access to SFO, Waymo aims to deepen its relationship with the city and increase its geographic scale.

articles.title: Introducing Encrypt It Already
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has launched a new campaign called "Encrypt It Already" to push companies to implement end-to-end encryption in their services. The campaign focuses on three categories of demands: keeping promises, defaulting to strong security settings, and protecting user data. The EFF is calling on companies like Facebook, Apple, Google, and others to provide stronger privacy protections for users' conversations and data. The campaign aims to make it easier for users to understand what encryption features are available and how to use them.

articles.title: County pays $600,000 to pentesters it arrested for assessing courthouse security
articles.summary: Two security professionals, Gary DeMercurio and Justin Wynn, who were arrested in 2019 for conducting a authorized security assessment of a county courthouse in Iowa, have settled their lawsuit against the county for $600,000. The men, employed by Coalfire Labs, had written permission to conduct "red-team" exercises, which involve simulating real-world attacks on a building's defenses. Despite this authorization, they were charged with felony burglary and spent 20 hours in jail before being released on bail. The charges were later reduced to misdemeanor trespassing, but the incident has sent a chilling message to security professionals nationwide, undermining public safety.

articles.title: Everything is gambling now: the latest news on prediction markets like Polymarket and Kalshi

articles.title: Daily Deal: The Adobe Graphic Design Bundle
articles.summary: The Adobe Graphic Design Bundle is a discounted course package that teaches the essentials of graphic design using Photoshop, Illustrator, and InDesign. The bundle includes 3 courses that cover all aspects of the design process. It's currently on sale for $50, offering a significant discount from its regular price. This deal is part of the Techdirt Deals Store, which features products curated by StackCommerce. A portion of the sales will support Techdirt. Graphic designers and those interested in learning graphic design can take advantage of this affordable opportunity to improve their skills.

articles.title: The ‘Social Media Addiction’ Narrative May Be More Harmful Than Social Media Itself
articles.summary: A major trial has begun in Los Angeles, where hundreds of families are suing Meta, TikTok, Snap, and YouTube, accusing them of intentionally designing their products to be addictive. However, a new study suggests that the "social media addiction" narrative may be more harmful than social media itself. The study found that people overestimate their addiction to social media, which can lead to feelings of helplessness and decreased control over their use. In fact, using the term "addiction" to describe social media use can actually make it harder for users to change their behavior.

articles.title: Apple buys Israeli startup Q.ai as the AI race heats up
articles.summary: Apple has acquired Israeli startup Q.ai, a company specializing in AI technologies for audio and imaging applications. The deal is valued at nearly $2 billion, making it Apple's second-largest acquisition to date. Q.ai's technology enables devices to interpret whispered speech and enhance audio in noisy environments, which could be used to improve Apple's AirPods and other products. This acquisition comes as part of a larger AI race between tech giants like Apple, Meta, and Google. The deal also marks the second time CEO Aviad Maizels has sold a company to Apple, following his previous sale of 3D-sensing company PrimeSense in 2013.

articles.title: Senators Push for Answers on ICE's Surveillance Shopping Spree
articles.summary: Senators Mark Warner and Tim Kaine have formally requested an investigation into the use of surveillance technologies by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and Customs and Border Protection (CBP). The letter, addressed to the Inspector General for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), asks for details on various surveillance tools being used by ICE, including license plate readers, social media monitoring software, facial recognition technology, and phone hacking technology. The senators express concern that these technologies are being used inappropriately and without proper oversight, potentially enabling DHS to circumvent constitutional protections. They also demand information about how DHS obtains, processes, and stores sensitive data, as well as its relationships with private companies and data brokers.

articles.title: Obsbot’s new gimbal webcam doesn’t justify its $350 price

articles.title: Apple’s second biggest acquisition ever is an AI company that listens to ‘silent speech’
articles.summary: Apple has made its second-largest acquisition, reportedly purchasing an artificial intelligence (AI) company that specializes in decoding "silent speech". The AI technology is said to be able to listen and respond to people who are not speaking out loud, potentially revolutionizing the way humans interact with devices. While details about the acquisition remain scarce, it's clear that Apple is investing heavily in AI research and development. This move could have significant implications for the future of human-computer interaction, voice assistants, and other applications. The acquisition highlights Apple's commitment to innovation and its willingness to take risks in pursuit of new technologies. The value of the deal is reportedly in the billions of dollars, making it one of the largest acquisitions in Apple's history.

articles.title: Satya Nadella insists people are using Microsoft’s Copilot AI a lot
articles.summary: Microsoft's CEO Satya Nadella has assured investors that the company's significant investments in cloud and AI will pay off, despite concerns about slowing growth in Azure and Microsoft 365. The tech giant reported a solid earnings report with $81.3 billion in revenue and $38.3 billion in net income profits. However, investors are worried about the high spending on capital expenditures, which has reached almost as much as last year's total. Nadella emphasized that AI usage is growing, citing increased adoption of Microsoft's Copilot AI products, including consumer AI chats and coding AI GitHub Copilot.

articles.title: The best foldable phone you can buy
