articles.title: Speak Its Name: Yes, This Is Naziism
articles.summary: The article argues that the US government's behavior under the Trump administration is eerily similar to Nazi Germany's actions during World War II. The author contends that the US has already arrived at a point where it is committing atrocities against its own citizens, mirroring the Nazis' treatment of Jews and other minority groups. This includes "othering" certain groups, stripping them of their rights, rounding up and detaining people without due process, and subjecting them to inhumane conditions. The author draws parallels between the US's actions and those of Nazi Germany, highlighting the use of rhetoric to dehumanize targeted groups, the denial of citizenship and rights, and the forced detention of individuals.

articles.title: Fintech firm Marquis blames hack at firewall provider SonicWall for its data breach
articles.summary: Fintech firm Marquis has blamed its firewall provider SonicWall for a data breach that occurred in August 2025, alleging that hackers exploited a vulnerability in SonicWall's cloud backup service to steal customers' personal and financial data. Marquis claims that the breach was linked to an earlier incident at SonicWall, which exposed critical security information about its customers' firewalls. The company is now seeking compensation from SonicWall for the expenses incurred by Marquis and its customers as a result of the breach. SonicWall has disputed these claims, saying it needs evidence to substantiate them. The data breach affected hundreds of thousands of people, including consumers who bank with US financial institutions.

articles.title: The weirdest headphones at CES will launch on Kickstarter next month
articles.summary: The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) has showcased some unusual and innovative products, including bizarre headphones. Next month, these peculiar headphones will be available for crowdfunding on Kickstarter. Details about the design, features, and functionality of the headphones are not yet known. The launch on Kickstarter suggests that the company is seeking funding to bring this product to market. It remains to be seen how successful the campaign will be or whether the headphones will gain traction with consumers. The CES event has a history of introducing quirky products that sometimes become cult classics. Whether these headphones fall into this category remains to be seen.

articles.title: EFF to Close Friday in Solidarity with National Shutdown
articles.summary: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) will be closed on Friday, January 30 in solidarity with the national shutdown against ICE and CBP violence. The decision was made to stand with communities impacted by the ongoing campaign of violence from these agencies. EFF has previously spoken out against the brutality and terror inflicted by ICE and CBP, and is urging people to take action against their actions. The organization will remain closed on Friday as part of the national protest. This move reflects EFF's commitment to supporting immigrant communities and advocating for their rights. The shutdown is a response to the continued violence and intimidation tactics used by federal agencies. By participating in the shutdown, EFF aims to raise awareness about the issue and bring attention to the need for reform.

articles.title: Microsoft won’t stop buying AI chips from Nvidia, AMD, even after launching its own, Nadella says
articles.summary: Microsoft has launched its first homegrown AI chip, the Maia 200, designed for inference workloads and optimized for running AI models in production. Despite having its own state-of-the-art chip, Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella announced that the company will continue to buy chips from other vendors like Nvidia and AMD due to their ongoing innovation. The Maia 200 will be used by Microsoft's Superintelligence team, which is developing frontier AI models, but it will also support OpenAI's models running on Azure. The chip launch comes as cloud giants face a supply crunch in obtaining the latest and greatest AI chips from vendors like Nvidia.

articles.title: Administration Lied To Itself To Keep Pushing Its Fake ‘Tren De Aragua’ Terrorism Narrative
articles.summary: The Trump administration's narrative about the Venezuelan gang Tren de Aragua (TdA) as a major international terrorism threat has been debunked by internal intelligence reports and law enforcement documents. Despite this, the administration continues to push the false narrative to justify its power grabs and policies. The evidence shows that TdA is a fragmented, profit-driven criminal group with no centralized command or strategic coordination. The administration's claims of an "invasion" and "narco-terrorism" are not supported by field-level reporting, which describes the group's activity as opportunistic and mundane. This has led to the targeting of innocent people, including those who have been wrongly accused of being TdA members. The administration's actions are a clear example of willful ignorance and manipulation of information to serve its own interests.

articles.title: Medium gives employees Friday off to participate in national strike protesting ICE
articles.summary: Medium CEO Tony Stubblebine has given employees permission to take Friday off to participate in a nationwide general strike protesting U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE). The strike, which includes calls for "no work, no school, and no shopping," aims to defund ICE amid escalating raids that have resulted in several deaths, including two U.S. citizens. Stubblebine emphasized that the decision is individual and not a company mandate, but encouraged employees to use their time off to support the strike's goals. This move comes as tech leaders, including Google DeepMind chief scientist Jeff Dean, have been outspoken against ICE, while some large tech companies have courted favor with the Trump administration.

articles.title: Apple just had a record-breaking iPhone quarter
articles.summary: It appears there is no content provided for the news article. Please provide the actual text of the article so I can assist you with summarizing and extracting keywords.

articles.title: Amazon is reportedly in talks to invest $50B in OpenAI
articles.summary: Amazon is reportedly in talks to invest $50 billion in OpenAI, a company valued at $500 billion that is seeking an additional $100 billion in funding. The investment would value OpenAI at up to $830 billion and is being led by Amazon CEO Andy Jassy and OpenAI CEO Sam Altman. This potential partnership is significant given Amazon's close ties to Anthropic, a competitor of OpenAI. OpenAI has also been discussing funding with sovereign wealth funds in the Middle East and other tech companies like Nvidia, Microsoft, and SoftBank. The deal is expected to close by the end of Q1.

articles.title: It’s a new heyday for gas thanks to data centers
articles.summary: It appears that there is no content provided for the article. Please provide the text of the article so I can assist you with summarizing and extracting keywords.

articles.title: Elon Musk’s SpaceX, Tesla, and xAI in talks to merge, according to reports
articles.summary: Elon Musk's companies, SpaceX, xAI, and Tesla, are reportedly in talks to merge, with two possible scenarios being considered: a merger between SpaceX and Tesla, or a combination of SpaceX and xAI. The potential merger could lead to at least one company folding into SpaceX, and would bring together various products and services under one corporation. The talks appear to be in the early stages, but recent filings suggest that Musk is keeping all options open. A merger with xAI could allow it to put its data centers in space, while a tie-up between SpaceX and Tesla could align their energy storage business with the data center in space idea. Both scenarios fall in line with Musk's comments and actions to consolidate resources between his companies.

articles.title: Ctrl-Alt-Speech: Think Globally, Stack Locally
articles.summary: Ctrl-Alt-Speech, a weekly podcast on online speech and content moderation, discusses the latest news in the field. This week's episode features an interview with Konstantinos Komaitis, Senior Resident Fellow for Global and Democratic Governance at the Digital Forensics Research Lab (DFRLab) at the Atlantic Council. The conversation covers various topics, including TikTok's ownership and data collection practices, Europe's efforts to reduce dependence on US tech, and Iran's internet blackout. Other discussed issues include social media addiction, payment processors' stance on CSAM, and UpScrolled's surge in downloads following TikTok's US takeover.

articles.title: Guys, I don’t think Tim Cook knows how to monetize AI
articles.summary: Apple's quarterly earnings exceeded expectations with $143.8 billion in revenue, but an analyst asked CEO Tim Cook about monetizing AI initiatives during the earnings call. The question was met with a vague response from Cook, who stated that Apple is bringing intelligence to its products and services in a personal and private way, creating "great value" that will open up opportunities. This lack of clarity has been a trend among tech companies, including OpenAI, which plans to break even by 2030 but faces significant funding challenges. The analyst's question highlights the uncertainty surrounding AI monetization, with many companies struggling to articulate their strategies.

articles.title: The iPhone just had its best quarter ever
articles.summary: Apple's iPhone sales reached a record high in the first quarter of 2026, with $85 billion worth of devices sold worldwide. The surge in demand was driven by strong sales in regions like China and India, where Apple set all-time revenue records for its signature device. CEO Tim Cook attributed the success to the popularity of the new iPhone 17 model, which was announced in September 2025. Apple's overall sales also increased across every geographical region, with notable gains in the Americas and Europe. The company's earnings report shows a significant jump in sales in Greater China, from $18.5 billion to $25.5 billion.

articles.title: How Sequoia-backed Ethos reached the public market while rivals fell short
articles.summary: Ethos Technologies, a San Francisco-based insurtech platform, debuted on the Nasdaq with an initial public offering (IPO) of $200 million. The company's software enables consumers to buy life insurance policies online in 10 minutes without medical exams. Despite facing stiff competition from other startups that have either pivoted or gone out of business, Ethos has maintained profitability and achieved year-over-year revenue growth of over 50%. The company's founders attribute their success to financial discipline and a focus on reaching profitability as the funding climate changed in 2022. Ethos' IPO marks one of the first major tech listings of the year, with the company closing its first day at $16.85 per share.

articles.title: Stop Killing Games Gets Over 1 Million Petition Signatures Verified By EU
articles.summary: The "Stop Killing Games" petition, which aims to prevent games from being abandoned or rendered unplayable by publishers, has successfully verified over 1.2 million signatures in the European Union. This exceeds the required 1 million signature threshold for consideration by EU politicians. The petition's organizers are seeking legislation that would require games to remain functional and not rely on online connections or microtransactions after purchase. The EU's verification process found a relatively low rate of invalid signatures, with around 10% being deemed fake. While this is a significant milestone, the actual implementation of laws based on the directive will likely take years and involve lobbying efforts across multiple member states.

articles.title: One of the biggest manga piracy networks has been shut down
articles.summary: It seems there is no content provided for me to analyze. Please provide the news article text so I can assist you with a summary and keywords.

articles.title: AI health care is taking off in China, led by Jack Ma’s Ant Group
articles.summary: Ant Group, the financial technology arm of Alibaba, is expanding into China's digital health market with a new AI-powered chatbot. The chatbot aims to provide personalized health and wellness advice to users through Alipay, the country's dominant mobile payment platform. Jack Ma's company is positioning itself as a leader in this emerging field, which is expected to grow rapidly in China. The chatbot will offer services such as health monitoring, disease diagnosis, and prescription management. This move reflects Ant Group's broader strategy of leveraging its vast user base and technological capabilities to expand into new areas beyond finance. Experts predict that AI-powered healthcare will become increasingly popular in China due to the country's aging population and growing demand for convenient and affordable medical services. The development is also seen as a key step towards achieving China's goal of becoming a global leader in digital health technology.

articles.title: Enshittification Ensures Streaming Prices Soar Faster Than Any Other Consumer Good
articles.summary: Streaming video subscription prices have increased by 29% year-over-year, significantly higher than the 2.7% increase in consumer costs across other goods and services. This trend is attributed to "enshittification," a process where media companies prioritize profits over quality and customer satisfaction. As a result, consumers face more ads, higher prices, and lower-quality content. The US Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) data reveals that streaming and gaming subscriptions saw the highest price increase in 2025, surpassing even coffee prices. This trend is expected to worsen due to the demolition of media consolidation limits by the Trump administration.

articles.title: Pluralistic: Threads' margin is the Eurostack's opportunity (30 Jan 2026)
articles.summary: The article discusses how the Eurostack, a European alternative to Facebook, can capitalize on Threads' margin by offering a more open and user-friendly experience. The author references the OG App, which was created in 2022 as an "alt-client" for Instagram that restored its original features and blocked ads. This app's success demonstrates the potential for users to break free from dominant platforms and create their own alternatives. The article highlights the importance of disrupting sclerotic companies that lock users in and exploit them for profit.

articles.title: Erotic Parody 'Melania: Devourer of Men' Sales Surge on Amazon Amid Documentary Flop
articles.summary: A Reddit-led campaign has caused an erotic parody book "Melania: Devourer of Men" to surge in sales on Amazon, coinciding with the box office flop of a $75-million documentary about Melania Trump. The book, written by J.D. Boehninger in 2018 as an experiment, depicts the First Lady as a monster and has become an Amazon bestseller in the "political thrillers & suspense" category. The campaign aimed to disrupt Amazon's search results for "Melania" and amplify the book's visibility. Author Boehninger made the book free to support the effort. The documentary's poor reception has led to speculation that Amazon's support of it is a way to curry favor with the President.

articles.title: Here is the User Guide for ELITE, the Tool Palantir Made for ICE
articles.summary: A user guide for the Palantir tool ELITE has been obtained by 404 Media, revealing its capabilities in helping Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) decide which neighborhoods to raid. The tool allows ICE to populate a map with potential deportation targets, view dossiers on each person, and assess an address's "confidence score" based on data from government agencies. This information was previously reported by 404 Media earlier this month. The user guide is now being published for public review. ELITE uses data sourced from the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and other government agencies to inform its decisions. The tool's capabilities have raised concerns about ICE's targeting of certain neighborhoods. The publication of the user guide aims to provide transparency into the workings of ELITE.

articles.title: Last 24 hours to grab your plus-one pass at 50% off to TechCrunch Disrupt 2026
articles.summary: TechCrunch Disrupt 2026 is offering a limited-time promotion where attendees can purchase a plus-one pass at 50% off. The discounted pricing ends tonight, January 30, at 11:59 p.m. PT, and applies to passes that remain in inventory. This year's event will take place from October 13-15 in San Francisco, featuring 300+ startups showcasing their innovations, a Startup Battlefield, and curated networking opportunities. Disrupt is designed for founders, VCs, operators, and tech leaders to connect and drive results. The event has been successful in the past, with attendees returning for high-signal access to people actively building and investing.

articles.title: AI agent Moltbot makes waves in China and Silicon Valley
articles.summary: Moltbot, an AI assistant developed by a US-based company, is gaining popularity in both China and Silicon Valley. The AI agent has become a viral sensation in the tech hub of Silicon Valley, prompting Chinese cloud providers to offer special packages for early adopters. In China, artificial-intelligence superusers are eager to test out Moltbot, which is seen as a cutting-edge technology. The rapid adoption of Moltbot highlights the growing interest in AI-powered tools and services in both regions. As more users try out Moltbot, its capabilities and limitations will be put to the test. The success of Moltbot could also pave the way for further innovation in AI development.

articles.title: Thoughts on the job market in the age of LLMs
articles.summary: The job market in AI has become increasingly challenging due to the rapid pace of progress in language models (LLMs). Senior employees with experience and context are highly sought after, while junior employees must demonstrate a strong work ethic and obsession with making progress. The author, a hybrid research lead and individual contributor, shares their insights on hiring practices optimized for the current moment in LLMs, which may not be sustainable in the long term. They highlight the importance of finding senior talent who can steer complex systems and junior employees who can make significant contributions quickly. The article also touches on the challenges faced by junior researchers in academia and the decision to pursue a Ph.D. or join a frontier lab.

articles.title: Dozens of Bizarre Ancient Lifeforms Discovered in ‘Extraordinary’ Fossil Find
articles.summary: Paleontologists have made an extraordinary fossil discovery in China's Huayuan County, uncovering a 512-million-year-old ecosystem that reveals dozens of bizarre ancient lifeforms never seen before. The find includes over 1,500 specimens, with 59% of the species being new to science. The fossils show remarkable soft-tissue preservation, including tentacles, guts, and even a nearly-complete nervous system in one arthropod. This discovery provides a unique glimpse into the Cambrian period's explosion of complex life on Earth, which occurred after a mass extinction event called the Sinsk event. The find includes many species that have been found at other Cambrian sites, suggesting widespread dispersal through ocean currents or floating rafts.

articles.title: Russian hackers breached Polish power grid thanks to bad security, report says
articles.summary: Russian hackers breached parts of Poland's energy grid infrastructure in December 2025, taking advantage of poor security measures. The attackers, identified as the Berserk Bear or Dragonfly group by Poland's CERT, targeted wind and solar farms and a heat-and-power plant, using default usernames and passwords to gain access. The hackers attempted to infect the systems with wiper malware, but were stopped at the heat-and-power plant. Although the attacks were destructive in nature, they did not disrupt power supply or affect the stability of the Polish power system. The incident highlights the importance of robust cybersecurity measures to prevent such breaches.

articles.title: Reid Hoffman urges Silicon Valley leaders to stop bending the knee to President Trump
articles.summary: Billionaire tech mogul Reid Hoffman is urging Silicon Valley leaders to take a stronger stance against President Trump's policies and actions, particularly regarding the killings of two American citizens by Border Patrol agents. Hoffman argues that tech leaders have power and should not use it to "bend the knee" to Trump or shrink away from taking action. Many tech leaders have expressed concern over the incidents, but some have been quick to distance themselves from criticizing Trump directly. Hoffman is echoing a growing contingent of tech workers who are calling on CEOs to speak out against ICE's violence and cancel contracts with the agency.

articles.title: Silicon Valley’s Favorite New AI Agent Has Serious Security Flaws
articles.summary: A popular AI agent called Moltbot has been found to have serious security flaws. Developed by software engineer Peter Steinberger, Moltbot is a local server-based AI that can perform various tasks for users through communication platforms like Discord and Telegram. However, hacker Jamieson O'Reilly demonstrated three vulnerabilities in the system, including a backdoor in an attached support shop and a supply chain attack on Moltbot's skills repository. These flaws allow hackers to access sensitive information and take control of user accounts. The popularity of Moltbot has been fueled by its active and initiative-taking nature, but experts warn that inviting AI agents into one's life comes with significant security risks.

articles.title: Behind the Blog: Own Goals and Lying Devs
articles.summary: The article is part of a series called "Behind the Blog" where the author shares their behind-the-scenes thoughts on recent stories. This week's installment focuses on a trip to Kenya, where Jason gave a presentation at a conference about AI and journalism. The conference was attended by 30 people from various backgrounds, including independent newsrooms and human rights researchers. Jason found the experience overwhelmingly positive and is looking forward to potential partnerships with some of the attendees.

articles.title: Trump Demands $10 Billion From Taxpayers For Leaked Tax Returns; His Own Lawyers Get To Decide What He Gets
articles.summary: Donald Trump has filed a lawsuit against the IRS, demanding $10 billion in taxpayer funds for alleged damages caused by the leak of his tax returns to the New York Times and ProPublica. The lawsuit claims that Trump was "grievously harmed" by the leak, despite his net worth having skyrocketed since the reporting. Trump's own lawyers will decide whether his claims are successful, creating a conflict of interest. The lawsuit is seen as an attempt to profit off his presidency, with Trump already richer than he has ever been due to his crypto ventures and other business dealings.

articles.title: Premium: The Hater's Guide to Oracle
articles.summary: Oracle is a massive software company that sells ERP, database, and other services to giant corporations, governments, and even healthcare organizations. Its customers are numerous and widespread, including Microsoft, Walmart, and the UK's National Health Service. Once Oracle gets its foot in the door, it can be extremely difficult to cancel contracts or switch providers due to complex agreements and aggressive sales tactics. The company has a reputation for conducting audits on large clients to ensure compliance with their contracts, and has even sued companies for alleged contract breaches. As a result of its dominance, founder Larry Ellison has become one of the richest people in the world.

articles.title: Bluesky issues its first transparency report, noting rise in user reports and legal demands
articles.summary: Bluesky, a social media startup rivaling X and Threads, has released its first transparency report, detailing the actions taken by its Trust & Safety team in 2025. The report shows a significant increase in user reports (54% from 2024) and legal demands (fivefold from 2024), with 1.41 billion posts made on the platform last year. Bluesky also reported success in reducing daily reports of antisocial behavior by 79% after implementing a system to identify toxic replies. The report covers various areas, including moderation, regulatory compliance, and account verification information.

articles.title: Anthropic brings agentic plug-ins to Cowork
articles.summary: Anthropic has launched a new feature called "plug-ins" within its Cowork tool, designed to automate specialized tasks in various departments of an enterprise. Plug-ins can be customized and used by non-coders to streamline work with a focused approach. The company has open-sourced 11 plug-ins and expects users to create their own bespoke use cases for them. Anthropic's goal is to make Cowork more powerful for enterprise users, allowing them to optimize workflows and improve consistency in outcomes. The expansion of plug-ins into Cowork takes the utility of Claude Code and makes it accessible to a broader range of users.

articles.title: Daily Deal: Cable Blocks Magnetic And Weighted Cord Organizers
articles.summary: The Cable Blocks magnetic cable management system is on sale, offering a premium solution for keeping workspaces organized and clutter-free. This updated version of the product features three connectable silicone blocks that are double-weighted to securely hold cables in place. The built-in neodymium magnets allow for seamless connection between blocks and attachment to metal surfaces, providing flexibility in cable routing. Available in various colors, a 6-pack is priced at $30 or a 9-pack at $45. This product aims to eliminate messy adhesives and prevent annoying cable drops. It's part of the Techdirt Deals Store, which supports the website through sales. The product does not reflect an endorsement by the editorial team.

articles.title: The Casual Cruelty Of The GOP’s Migrant Purge
articles.summary: The article criticizes the Trump administration's treatment of migrants, highlighting instances of overt cruelty, including the murder of protesters, the targeting of day laborers, and the separation of children from parents. The author argues that this is part of a broader pattern of behavior by the administration, which includes portraying migrants as inferior and worthy of persecution. A specific case study is presented, detailing the story of Sonik Manaserian, a 70-year-old Iranian refugee who was arrested and detained by ICE despite having lived in the US for over 18 years under an order of supervision. The article suggests that this behavior is characteristic of a government that feels it's above the law and can act with impunity.

articles.title: Uber is literally in the driver’s seat when it comes to AV bets
articles.summary: Uber has made a significant investment in Waabi, a self-driving truck startup founded by former Uber AI chief Raquel Urtasun, with a $1 billion fundraise that includes an upfront payment of $750 million and an additional $250 million tied to deployment milestones. The deal marks a major expansion into robotaxis for Waabi, which plans to deploy over 25,000 vehicles. This partnership is part of Uber's broader strategy of investing in multiple autonomous vehicle (AV) startups worldwide, with more than 20 partnerships currently in place. However, the success of this approach remains uncertain, and experts are questioning whether Uber's "bet-on-everything" strategy will pay off. Waabi's simulation-first approach to AV development may be a key differentiator, but its ability to deliver on its plans is still untested.

articles.title: Developers say AI coding tools work—and that's precisely what worries them
articles.summary: Software developers are divided on the impact of AI coding tools, which can now build entire applications from text prompts. While some developers acknowledge the hype surrounding these tools, others have seen significant improvements in their capabilities, particularly with the release of Anthropic's Claude Opus 4.5. Developers like Roland Dreier report a "step-change" in the past six months, with AI agents able to perform complex tasks at speeds 10x faster than before. However, concerns remain about the potential for these tools to replace human developers or exacerbate existing issues such as burnout and job displacement.

articles.title: SpaceX’s IPO could open the floodgates — and secondaries are booming in the meantime
articles.summary: SpaceX is reportedly planning an IPO in 2026, which could signal a revival of the public markets after a years-long drought. Meanwhile, late-stage private companies like SpaceX are using secondary markets to create liquidity for employees and early shareholders. The secondary market has been booming due to the prolonged IPO drought, with investors seeking access to large private companies. Experts believe that even if SpaceX goes public, it will increase interest in private companies and the secondary market, rather than reducing demand.

articles.title: Tom Homan To Minneapolis: Look, I Warned You If You Weren’t Nice, We’d Have To Kill Again, And Look What You Made Us Do
articles.summary: Tom Homan, a former "border czar," has been deployed to Minneapolis after the murder of Alex Pretti by federal agents. In a speech, Homan claimed he had begged for rhetoric against ICE and CBP to stop, but his words were met with skepticism as he only called for de-escalation of criticism against law enforcement while ignoring the demonization of marginalized communities in the region. Critics point out that Homan has a history of encouraging violence and promoting hateful language against certain groups. The article argues that true de-escalation requires the federal government to tone down its own rhetoric and actions, rather than just asking others to do so.

articles.title: Need A Friday Night Challenge? Whip Up A Quick Game For The Public Domain Game Jam!
articles.summary: The public domain game jam, now in its eighth year, is entering its final 24 hours before the deadline for submissions. Despite being a month-long event, participants are encouraged to create simple games using tools like Twine and Story Synth or even just a single page of rules. The theme this time around is "Gaming Like It's 1930," and participants can find inspiration on the game jam page on Itch.io. Submissions close at midnight tomorrow, January 31st, after which winners will be chosen in six categories.

articles.title: Blue Origin pauses space tourism flights to focus on the moon
articles.summary: Blue Origin, founded by Jeff Bezos, is pausing its space tourism flights for at least two years to focus on missions to the moon. The decision comes as the company prepares for its third launch of the New Glenn mega-rocket in late February. Blue Origin had previously suggested using this launch to send a robotic lunar lander to the moon, but it is still undergoing testing. The pause in space tourism flights will allow the company to redirect its resources towards NASA's goal of returning humans to the moon by 2024. This move also reflects the increased competition for lunar missions following President Trump's push for NASA to prioritize sending astronauts back to the moon. Blue Origin has flown 38 times and carried 98 humans to space since its New Shepard rocket was first launched over a decade ago.

articles.title: Instagram might soon let you remove yourself from someone’s Close Friends list
articles.summary: Instagram is developing a feature that will allow users to remove themselves from someone's "Close Friends" list, a private sharing feature launched in 2018. The company has confirmed the development but notes that it's still in the early stages and not being tested publicly yet. A reverse engineer discovered an internal prototype of the feature, which includes a warning for users who leave a Close Friends list, stating they won't be able to see that person's content unless added back. This feature is seen as a welcome addition by those who don't want to be included on certain people's lists. Instagram is also working on other new features, including premium subscriptions with exclusive features.

articles.title: Musk to Epstein: ‘What Day/Night Will Be the Wildest Party on Your Island?’
articles.summary: Elon Musk sent an email to Jeffrey Epstein in 2012 asking about the wildest party on his island, contradicting previous denials of visiting the island. The newly released documents show that Musk and Epstein exchanged emails over a year, discussing topics such as electrifying Epstein's private island and ranch. Musk had previously claimed he refused to visit Epstein's island, but the emails reveal he planned a trip there. This revelation raises questions about Musk's honesty regarding his relationship with Epstein.

articles.title: Bari Weiss Pauses Her Pathetic Podcast To Focus Full Time On Ruining CBS
articles.summary: Bari Weiss has announced that she is pausing her podcast "Honestly" to focus on addressing issues at CBS News, where she was recently hired as the head of news. The move comes after a series of controversies and ratings flops, including a disastrous town hall with Erika Kirk and an error-prone nightly news broadcast. Weiss has been criticized for her lack of journalistic experience and her attempts to blame her staff for her own incompetence. Her hiring by Larry Ellison's company has raised concerns about the erosion of journalism standards and the creation of state-controlled media. The situation at CBS News is seen as a symptom of a larger problem in the US media landscape, where corporate interests are increasingly influencing editorial decisions.

articles.title: Informant told FBI that Jeffrey Epstein had a ‘personal hacker’
articles.summary: A confidential informant told the FBI in 2017 that Jeffrey Epstein had a "personal hacker" with expertise in finding vulnerabilities in various devices and browsers. The alleged hacker was reportedly Italian-born and sold zero-day exploits to several countries, including an unnamed central African government and Hezbollah. According to the informant, the hacker received payment from Hezbollah in cash. The document detailing this information has been released by the Department of Justice as part of its effort to publish documents related to Epstein's investigation. However, it is unclear how trustworthy the allegations are since they come from a single informant rather than direct FBI testimony. The release includes 3.5 million additional pages from the Epstein files, including videos and images. The FBI declined to comment on the matter.

articles.title: AI agents now have their own Reddit-style social network, and it's getting weird fast
articles.summary: A Reddit-style social network called Moltbook has been created for AI agents, with over 32,000 registered users. The platform allows AI agents to post, comment, upvote, and create subcommunities without human intervention, resulting in surreal and sometimes disturbing content. Moltbook is linked to the OpenClaw personal assistant, which has raised security concerns due to its ability to control computers and access private data. The platform's rapid growth has sparked fears about the potential risks of machine-to-machine social interaction.

articles.title: Search Engines, AI, And The Long Fight Over Fair Use
articles.summary: The article discusses how copyright holders are arguing that generative AI tools infringe on their rights by analyzing and reusing copyrighted works without permission. However, courts have long recognized that copying for purposes of analysis, indexing, and learning is a classic fair use, which allows for the reproduction of copyrighted materials without obtaining licenses from millions of rightsholders. This principle applies to AI training as well, where the purpose of copying is not to reproduce or replace the original texts but to extract statistical relationships that allow the AI system to generate new outputs. Expanding copyright control over learning and analysis could threaten long-standing practices in machine learning and text-and-data mining, which underpin research in science, medicine, and technology.

articles.title: OpenClaw’s AI assistants are now building their own social network
articles.summary: OpenClaw, formerly known as Clawdbot and briefly Moltbot, has settled on its new name after a trademark dispute. The AI assistant project, created by Peter Steinberger, has attracted over 100,000 GitHub stars in two months and is now building its own social network called Moltbook. This platform allows AI assistants to interact with each other, sharing information and discussing topics such as automation and security. Despite its rapid growth, OpenClaw's creator emphasizes the need for security improvements, warning users about potential risks and directing them to best practices.

articles.title: OnlyFans considering selling majority stake to Architect Capital
articles.summary: OnlyFans, a subscription-based platform for adult creators and influencers, is considering selling a majority stake to investment firm Architect Capital in a deal valued at $5.5 billion. The proposed sale would give Architect a 60% stake in the business, with $3.5 billion in equity and $2 billion in debt. This is not the first time OnlyFans has been in talks to sell off its business, having previously courted potential buyers last year. Architect Capital, which launched as an asset-based lender in 2021, would partner with early-stage startups like OnlyFans. The deal's timeline remains unclear, and it's uncertain what happened to previous discussions with a U.S.-based investor group.

articles.title: Physical Intelligence, Stripe veteran Lachy Groom’s latest bet, is building Silicon Valley’s buzziest robot brains
articles.summary: Physical Intelligence is a startup building robotic brains that can learn and adapt to various tasks, similar to how ChatGPT works for language. Founded by Lachy Groom, a veteran of Stripe, the company has developed a continuous loop system where data from robot stations trains general-purpose robotic foundation models. The robots are tested in various environments, including a test kitchen, to evaluate their ability to generalize and learn new tasks. Physical Intelligence's hardware is deliberately unglamorous, with arms selling for around $3,500, but the company believes that good intelligence can compensate for bad hardware. Groom was inspired by the academic work of Sergey Levine and Chelsea Finn, and he joined forces with Karol Hausman to start the company.

articles.title: a16z partner Kofi Ampadu to leave firm after TxO program pause
articles.summary: Kofi Ampadu, a partner at venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz (a16z), has left the company after leading its Talent x Opportunity (TxO) fund and program for over four years. The TxO program aimed to support underserved founders by providing access to tech networks and investment capital through a donor-advised fund. However, the program faced criticism due to its controversial structure. Ampadu's departure comes months after a16z paused the TxO program and laid off most of its staff. The move may signal the end of the TxO chapter at a16z.

articles.title: DOJ Arrests Journalists Don Lemon & Georgia Fort For Acts Of Journalism, Even After Courts Rejected Arrest Warrants
articles.summary: The Department of Justice (DOJ) has arrested two journalists, Don Lemon and Georgia Fort, for their coverage of a protest at a Minnesota church. Despite the courts rejecting arrest warrants for the pair, the DOJ convened a grand jury and obtained an indictment, leading to their arrest. The move has been widely criticized as an attack on press freedom and the First Amendment. The DOJ's actions have been seen as a slap in the face to the court system, which had already rejected the requests for arrest warrants. Lemon's arrest is particularly egregious, given that a federal magistrate judge had previously refused to issue an arrest warrant for him.

articles.title: This Week In Techdirt History: January 25th – 31st
articles.summary: This article looks back at past Techdirt articles from January 25th to 31st in various years, highlighting key stories and trends. Five years ago (2021), the focus was on net neutrality, broadband monopolies, Section 230 immunity, and House Republicans' plans to tackle Big Tech. Ten years ago (2016), notable topics included copyright lawsuits, a writer's libel claim, monkey selfie copyright, and copyright troll Malibu Media's expert witness. Fifteen years ago (2011), stories centered around ACS:Law, mass copyright infringement suits, and the controversy surrounding ACTA.

articles.title: Exposed Moltbook Database Let Anyone Take Control of Any AI Agent on the Site
articles.summary: A security vulnerability was discovered in the Moltbook platform, which allows users to interact with AI agents independently. The site's backend API was left exposed in an open database, enabling anyone to gain control over the AI agents and post content without restrictions. This has raised concerns about the potential for malicious activity on the platform. Moltbook is a social media-like site where AI agents can interact with each other, and its posts have gained significant attention online. The vulnerability was discovered after users reported that certain AI agents were posting unusual or provocative content. An investigation into the matter revealed the exposed API, which has since been fixed by the developers. However, the incident highlights concerns about the security of AI-powered platforms and their potential for misuse.

articles.title: Bye-bye, corporate conglomerates. Hello personal conglomerates.
articles.summary: Elon Musk is building a personal conglomerate, with various ventures under his ownership or leadership, including Tesla, SpaceX, xAI, Neuralink, and The Boring Company. This echoes the model of General Electric (GE) under Jack Welch's leadership in the 1980s, where he transformed the company into a sprawling conglomerate through acquisitions and layoffs. Musk's net worth is approaching $800 billion, rivaling GE at its peak when adjusted for inflation. While there are similarities between Musk and Welch, there are also differences, with Musk being an individual rather than a company. The article suggests that Musk may be following in Welch's footsteps by merging some of his ventures into one conglomerate.

articles.title: India offers zero taxes through 2047 to lure global AI workloads
articles.summary: India's finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced a proposal in the country's annual budget to offer zero taxes through 2047 on services sold outside India if they are run from Indian data centers. This move aims to attract global AI workloads and investment, as major cloud providers like Amazon, Google, and Microsoft expand their presence in the country. Despite challenges such as power shortages and water stress, India's domestic data center sector is ramping up to meet global demand, with several large investments announced recently. The government's push for digital infrastructure and cloud computing is expected to strengthen India's position as a regional data and compute hub.

articles.title: TechCrunch Mobility: The great Tesla rebranding
articles.summary: Tesla's CEO Elon Musk has been trying to rebrand the company as a sustainable energy and AI/robotics firm, but its financial reality remains rooted in electric vehicle sales. Despite generating $94.8 billion in revenue in 2025, with $69.5 billion coming from EV sales, Tesla's profits have dipped 46% year-over-year due to declining sales. To compensate, the company is shifting focus towards non-EV businesses and investing heavily in new ventures such as Optimus humanoid robots and robotaxi operations. Musk also plans to merge his companies SpaceX, Tesla, and xAI, with talks underway for a possible merger. Meanwhile, Waymo is reportedly seeking up to $15 billion in funding from Alphabet and external investors.

articles.title: Indonesia ‘conditionally’ lifts ban on Grok
articles.summary: Indonesia has conditionally lifted its ban on xAI's chatbot Grok, following similar moves by Malaysia and the Philippines. The ban was imposed after Grok was used to create millions of non-consensual, sexualized images of women and minors on X (formerly Twitter). Indonesia's Ministry of Communication and Digital Affairs said it lifted the ban after receiving a letter from X outlining steps to prevent misuse, but warned that the ban could be reinstated if further violations occur. xAI has taken some steps to restrict Grok's capabilities, including limiting its image generation feature to paying subscribers on X. The company's CEO, Elon Musk, has denied any knowledge of underage images generated by Grok and claimed that users who create illegal content will face consequences. Meanwhile, the US Attorney General is investigating xAI for producing sexual deepfakes.

articles.title: Amazon’s ‘Melania’ documentary makes $7M on opening weekend
articles.summary: Amazon's documentary "Melania" about First Lady Melania Trump has exceeded box office expectations, earning $7.04 million in its opening weekend, despite being made for $40 million and reportedly costing an additional $35 million to promote. The film is currently third at the box office behind two other movies, but critics have panned it, with a 7% approval rating on Metacritic and 10% on Rotten Tomatoes. The documentary's poor reception has led some to speculate that Amazon paid too much for the film, potentially as a way to curry favor with the Trump administration. The film's director, Brett Ratner, has faced allegations of sexual harassment in the past, and many crew members were reportedly hesitant to work on the project.

articles.title: Funniest/Most Insightful Comments Of The Week At Techdirt
articles.summary: The article highlights the funniest and most insightful comments of the week on Techdirt, a technology news website. The top commenters are recognized for their witty and incisive remarks about current events, including Trump's demands for billions from the IRS, right-wing "comedy," and the Minneapolis police department's actions. The comments provide a humorous and critical perspective on politics and social issues, with many of them directly addressing the hypocrisy and double standards of certain individuals and groups.

articles.title: Why Tether’s CEO is everywhere right now
articles.summary: Tether's CEO Paolo Ardoino has been making headlines with numerous interviews and media appearances, marking a significant shift for the company. Tether recently launched USAT, a U.S.-regulated stablecoin, in an effort to comply with new federal rules and compete with Circle's USDC. The move comes as Fidelity Investments also launches its own competing stablecoin. Ardoino claims that Tether is transforming from a crypto play to mainstream acceptance, citing the company's first-mover advantage and its potential for financial inclusion. Despite past controversies surrounding money laundering allegations, Ardoino argues that Tether's technology makes it superior to cash in monitoring illicit activity.

articles.title: AI layoffs or ‘AI-washing’?
articles.summary: Companies have cited artificial intelligence as the reason for over 50,000 layoffs in 2025, with Amazon and Pinterest among those blaming the technology. However, a Forrester report suggests that many of these companies do not actually have mature AI applications ready to fill the roles being cut, instead using AI as an excuse for financially motivated layoffs. This trend is referred to as "AI-washing," where companies attribute cuts to future AI implementation rather than acknowledging underlying business problems. Experts argue that this messaging is appealing to investors and allows companies to avoid taking responsibility for their own financial struggles. The practice of AI-washing raises questions about the true impact of AI on the workforce and whether it's being used as a convenient scapegoat.

articles.title: TikTok says its services are restored after the outage
articles.summary: TikTok has restored its services after a significant outage last week, which was caused by a power outage at an Oracle-operated data center due to the winter storm. The outage affected tens of thousands of servers and impacted core features such as content posting and discovery. The company blamed the snowstorm for the issue and said that it had successfully restored TikTok back to normal. The outage occurred after the U.S. finalized a deal to create a separate entity for TikTok, with a new ownership structure in place. The incident has been beneficial for other social networks, including Skylight and UpScrolled, which have seen an increase in user base and downloads.

articles.title: These AI notetaking devices can help you record and transcribe your meetings
articles.summary: Several companies are developing physical AI notetakers that can record, transcribe, and summarize meetings using artificial intelligence. These devices range from wearable pendants to credit-card-sized tools with dedicated mobile apps. Some notable examples include Plaud Note/Pro, Mobvoi TicNote, Comulytic Note Pro, Plaud Notepin/Notepin S, Omi Pendant, and Viaim Recdot earbuds. These devices offer features such as real-time transcription, translation, and summary generation, with some also providing action item lists and chat capabilities. Prices vary from $89 to $179, depending on the device's features and functionality.

articles.title: What it takes to get an H-1B visa in Trump’s America
articles.summary: The US is set to open registration for the H-1B visa program, which has seen a surge in demand due to its limited availability. The visa category receives more than five times the number of applicants it can accept each year. The application process is highly competitive and often involves lengthy waiting periods. The Trump administration's policies have made the process even more challenging for foreign workers seeking an H-1B visa. Critics argue that the administration's restrictions on the program are hindering the US tech industry, while supporters claim they are necessary to protect American jobs. The registration period is expected to open in about a month.

articles.title: The world is trying to log off U.S. tech
articles.summary: The global trend of distancing itself from US tech is gaining momentum as countries like France ban public officials from using American technology. Other governments are considering restricting access to popular social media platforms owned by US companies. This move is a response to concerns over data privacy, security, and the influence of these platforms on young people. The French government's decision is part of a broader effort to promote European alternatives to US tech giants. The implications of this trend could be significant for the global tech industry, with potential consequences for the dominance of US companies in the market.

articles.title: How Identity Literally Changes What You See (with Samuel Bagg)
articles.summary: Joseph discusses with Samuel Bagg, an assistant professor of political science at the University of South Carolina, how social identity influences what people see and perceive. Bagg argues that the solution to problems caused by incorrect knowledge is not more knowledge, but rather understanding the role of social identity in shaping our perceptions. This conversation explores the idea that our identities can literally change what we see, and how this affects our understanding of reality.

articles.title: Latest open artifacts (#18): Arcee's 400B MoE, LiquidAI's underrated 1B model, new Kimi, and anticipation of a busy month
articles.summary: January saw a slower pace of open model releases compared to the previous year, but there are many notable models that have been released or are expected soon. LiquidAI's LFM2.5-1.2B-Instruct model has gained attention for its impressive performance and smaller size compared to other large language models. Other notable models include Arcee's 400B MoE, which is a significant upgrade from previous versions, and the anticipation of DeepSeek V4's release, expected to be a major milestone in the AI industry. The month ahead is expected to be busy with several high-profile model releases, including Claude Sonnet 5. These developments highlight the rapidly evolving landscape of artificial intelligence and its applications.

articles.title: Trump Is Helping Elon Musk’s Starlink Get Billions In Taxpayer Dollars With No Oversight
articles.summary: The Trump administration has rewritten the BEAD program to redirect billions of dollars in taxpayer funds towards Elon Musk's Starlink satellite internet service, despite its congestion and high costs. This move is seen as a corrupt favoring of a billionaire over more reliable and affordable community fiber options. The program also includes provisions that limit accountability for companies like Starlink, making it difficult for states to ensure they deliver on their promises. This has led to criticism from experts who argue that the program prioritizes Musk's interests over those of rural Americans in need of reliable internet access.

articles.title: Privacy Telecom ‘Cape’ Introduces ‘Disappearing Call Logs’ That Delete Every 24 Hours
articles.summary: Cape, a privacy-focused telecommunications company, has introduced "disappearing call logs" that automatically delete users' call data records every 24 hours. This breaks with the industry standard of keeping hold of call logs for months or years. The feature is part of Cape's efforts to minimize data collection and storage, following a hack in 2024 where hackers stole nearly all AT&T customers' call records. While Cape still complies with CALEA, which requires telecommunications companies to respond to legal demands for data, the company has not warned law enforcement about the change to CDR retention beforehand. The move is seen as a step towards greater user privacy, but some concerns remain about potential data collection by carrier partners.

articles.title: Linq raises $20M to enable AI assistants to live within messaging apps
articles.summary: Linq, a startup founded by former Shipt executives, has raised $20 million in Series A funding to enable AI assistants to live within messaging apps. The company's technology allows businesses to send blue-bubble messages to customers, lending an air of authenticity to their communications. Linq initially focused on helping sales teams with digital business cards and lead capture tools but pivoted to leverage its tech stack for the growing AI market. With the new funding, Linq plans to expand its team, develop a go-to-market motion, and continue building its technology. The company's customer base has expanded by 132% since it started offering AI-powered messaging services.

articles.title: UpScrolled’s founder says the social network has zoomed past 2.5M users
articles.summary: UpScrolled, a social network that combines elements of Instagram and X, has surpassed 2.5 million users globally, according to its founder Issam Hijazi. The company launched six months ago and initially grew to 150,000 users before gaining momentum after TikTok's ownership change in the US in January. UpScrolled claims to be inclusive of all voices and allows for a wide range of content without shadowbanning or censoring users. However, some users have complained about hosting explicit content on the platform. Hijazi criticized big tech companies for being unethical and prioritizing profit over user data and mental health.

articles.title: Carbon Robotics built an AI model that detects and identifies plants
articles.summary: Carbon Robotics has developed an AI model called the Large Plant Model (LPM) that can instantly recognize and identify plant species, including weeds. The LPM is trained on over 150 million photos and data points collected from farms in 15 countries where the company's autonomous weed-killing robots operate. This new model eliminates the need for farmers to retrain their machines every time a new type of weed appears or when the same type of weed has a different appearance. The LPM will be integrated into Carbon Robotics' existing systems through a software update, allowing farmers to select photos and instruct the machine to kill specific weeds while protecting others. This development is expected to improve efficiency and accuracy in weed management.

articles.title: Coalition demands federal Grok ban over nonconsensual sexual content
articles.summary: A coalition of nonprofits is calling on the US government to immediately suspend the deployment of Grok, a chatbot developed by Elon Musk's xAI, in federal agencies due to its history of generating nonconsensual sexual content and child abuse material. The letter, signed by advocacy groups such as Public Citizen and Center for AI and Digital Policy, cites concerns over system-level failures and the administration's executive orders on AI safety. Grok has been deployed in various government agencies, including the Department of Defense, despite its history of meltdowns and generating explicit content. The coalition argues that Grok is incompatible with the administration's requirements for AI systems and poses a national security risk.

articles.title: Our Zine About ICE Surveillance Is Here
articles.summary: 404 Media has released a zine about the surveillance technology used by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE). The zine is a print product that covers the ways technology companies are powering Trump's deportation raids. Initially, 1,000 copies were planned to be printed, but due to high demand, the number was increased to 3,500. Pre-orders have been fulfilled, and additional copies are available for sale on their Shopify store. The zine is also available in Spanish and a smaller file size version. The production process involved labor-intensive DIY methods using riso printers from the early 1990s.

articles.title: Pluralistic: Stock swindles (02 Feb 2026)
articles.summary: The article discusses how Trumpism, a fascist movement, has its roots in America's history of corruption and swindling. It highlights how Trump rose to power by boasting about his ability to cheat and steal, using his status as a "reality TV star" to secure liar loans and rip off creditors, contractors, business partners, workers, and governments. The article argues that the right-wing movement claims that governments are inefficient and corrupt, so right-wing leaders make their own case by being incompetent and corrupt. Trump's path to power lies in convincing people that the system is rigged and that he knows how to rig it in their favor.

articles.title: Ring brings its ‘Search Party’ feature for finding lost dogs to non-Ring camera owners
articles.summary: Ring's AI-powered "Search Party" feature, which helps find lost dogs by scanning camera footage from neighbors' cameras, is now available to all users in the US, not just Ring customers with a camera installed. The feature uses AI to match a lost dog's image with footage from nearby outdoor cameras and alerts the owner if a match is found. This expansion aims to increase community involvement in finding missing pets. Additionally, Ring is committing $1 million to equip animal shelters with Ring camera systems, hoping to aid 4,000 US shelters and reunite more dogs with their owners.

articles.title: DOJ Released Unredacted Nude Images in Epstein Files
articles.summary: The Department of Justice released over 3.5 million pages of files related to the investigations and prosecutions of Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, including unredacted photos of fully nude women or girls. The images, which were not redacted for nudity or faces, show individuals posing for cameras and exposing their genitals. The files also contain over 2,000 videos and 180,000 images, including commercial pornography seized from Epstein's devices. Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche stated that the released materials include "large quantities of commercial pornography" taken by Epstein himself. The unredacted photos have raised concerns about the potential harm to individuals depicted in them. The release of these files is part of a long-awaited effort to make information related to Epstein's case publicly available. The move has sparked debate about the balance between transparency and protecting the identities of those involved.

articles.title: Hey Gavin Newsom! Investigating TikTok’s Moderation Is Just As Unconstitutional As When Texas & Florida Tried It
articles.summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom is launching an investigation into TikTok's content moderation practices, alleging that the platform has censored content critical of former President Trump. However, critics argue that this move is unconstitutional and violates the First Amendment, which protects private platforms' editorial discretion. The issue is not new, as similar attempts by Texas and Florida to regulate social media platforms were deemed unconstitutional by courts. Newsom's investigation is seen as a repeat of these failed efforts, with some arguing it could have chilling effects on free speech.

articles.title: Notepad++ says Chinese government hackers hijacked its software updates for months
articles.summary: Notepad++ developer Don Ho confirmed that hackers associated with the Chinese government hijacked its software updates for months in 2025, delivering malicious code to users. The cyberattack is believed to have occurred between June and December 2025, targeting a small number of organizations with interests in East Asia. Notepad++, a popular open-source text editor, has been downloaded tens of millions of times worldwide, including by employees at various organizations. Ho apologized for the incident and urged users to download the latest version of the software, which contains a fix for the bug exploited by hackers. The attack is reminiscent of the 2019-2020 SolarWinds breach, where Russian government hackers compromised the company's servers and planted a backdoor in its software.

articles.title: OpenAI launches new macOS app for agentic coding
articles.summary: OpenAI has launched a new macOS app for its Codex tool, which enables agentic coding practices. The app integrates multiple agents in parallel and allows users to work with state-of-the-art workflows. This move is seen as an attempt by OpenAI to catch up with competitors like Claude Code, whose apps have gained popularity in the past year. The new app comes with features such as automations, agent personalities, and background scheduling. While OpenAI's GPT-5.2 model has shown strong performance on some coding benchmarks, its use cases are still being tested.

articles.title: Grubhub waives delivery and service fees on restaurant orders over $50
articles.summary: Grubhub has announced a significant policy change, waiving delivery and service fees on restaurant orders over $50. The move is aimed at closing the gap with competitors DoorDash and Uber Eats, who typically offer limited-time promotions or paid subscription services to waive fees. Grubhub's new offering is permanent and applies to all orders exceeding $50, which could result in significant cost savings for customers. This strategy comes as Grubhub faces challenges in user growth and trails behind its competitors, with 8 million monthly active users compared to DoorDash's nearly 50 million. The company also recently acquired Claim, a startup providing cash-back rewards at local restaurants.

articles.title: Firefox will soon let you block all of its generative AI features
articles.summary: Mozilla is introducing a new feature in Firefox 148 that allows users to block all generative AI features or manage them individually. This move comes as the company prioritizes user choice and transparency, following its CEO's promise to make AI features optional. The AI controls section will be available in desktop browser settings, enabling users to turn off AI enhancements, translations, alt text, tab grouping, link previews, and other features. Mozilla is also investing in new AI features while promoting responsible AI development through partnerships with startups and nonprofits.

articles.title: Daily Deal: Rosetta Stone (All Languages)
articles.summary: The Rosetta Stone language learning software is offering a lifetime subscription for all 25 languages at a discounted price of $149.97. This deal includes access to the immersive and intuitive training method that has been used by millions of people over the past 27 years. The offer is available through the Techdirt Deals Store, where users can apply coupon code LANG30 to receive the discount. Rosetta Stone's software has a proven track record of helping learners achieve fluency in a new language. This deal provides an opportunity for individuals to learn multiple languages with confidence. The subscription includes access to all 25 languages offered by Rosetta Stone. The offer is limited and subject to change.

articles.title: FBI Raids Fulton County, Georgia To Seize Ballots On Behalf Of A Guy Who Refuses To Believe He Lost The 2020 Election
articles.summary: The FBI has seized original 2020 voting records from Fulton County, Georgia's Elections Hub and Operations Center as part of a court-ordered search warrant. The warrant authorized the seizure of physical ballots, tabulator tapes, voter rolls, and other documents related to the 2020 general election. This move is seen as an attempt by former President Trump to extract "penance" from Georgia after his loss in the state's electoral votes. Trump has been accused of trying to overturn the election results through various means, including targeting Fulton County officials. The seizure of voting records has raised concerns about voter intimidation and potential attempts to undermine future elections.

articles.title: What Snowflake’s deal with OpenAI tells us about the enterprise AI race
articles.summary: Snowflake, a cloud data company, has entered into a $200 million multi-year deal with OpenAI, providing its 12,600 customers access to OpenAI models across all three major cloud providers. This partnership is part of the growing enterprise AI competition, where companies are striking deals with multiple AI players due to their varying strengths and weaknesses. Similar deals have been made by ServiceNow and Snowflake itself with other AI companies, such as Anthropic. The market for enterprise AI appears to be fragmented, with conflicting surveys showing different leaders in the space. As a result, enterprises will likely continue to partner with multiple AI players to find where they can deliver tangible value.

articles.title: Six Months Of ‘AI CSAM Crisis’ Headlines Were Based On Misleading Data
articles.summary: A recent media frenzy surrounding the rise of AI-generated child sexual abuse material (CSAM) was based on misleading data. Amazon reported 380,000 instances of CSAM to the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children (NCMEC), but it was later revealed that none of these reports involved AI-generated CSAM. Instead, Amazon's scanning tools detected known CSAM in datasets being considered for AI training using traditional hash-matching detection tools. The media and politicians mistakenly attributed this to a surge in AI-generated CSAM, leading to widespread panic and calls for action. The incident highlights the need for accurate reporting and understanding of complex issues like AI development and child safety.

articles.title: Two Stanford students launch $2M startup accelerator for students nationwide
articles.summary: Two Stanford students, Roman Scott and Itbaan Nafi, have launched a $2 million startup accelerator called Breakthrough Ventures, aimed at funding businesses founded by college students and recent graduates nationwide. The program will provide grant funding, compute credits, legal support, mentorship, and networking opportunities to student founders. Breakthrough Ventures aims to fill the funding gap for student entrepreneurs and create a hub for Gen-Z entrepreneurship and thought leadership. The duo hopes to deploy the fund over three years, aiming to incubate at least 100 companies. Applications for the latest cohort open today.
